review: The combat was fun, had me put in 50-something hours in just for the experience of the semi-turn-based bashing. But the gearing/looting system is so poor! All the items are the same, they just get class specializations and a few common modificators that up their stats, that's it! Did I perhaps miss every good "artifact item"? And the ones I *did* find were slightly above default inventory at best!... The only nice rewards from the entire playing experience were a sometimes half-decent story (maybe I didn't get to the "good bit" yet) and the process of combat itself. Oh, and I guess upgrading your fortress is fun for a bit, a shame it gets so tedious quick and the rewards quickly stop being exciting.
Underappreciated masterpiece
A cerebral game. Unfortunately this game isn't full voice acted and thus the game requires a lot of reading.  It seems like 10 books in a row, that's really insane! 7\10
Should be played before Avowed

Very fun old-school RPG, not that I ever played one back in the day haha. I am enjoying my time exploring the world and digging into the lore and characters. Pallengina is my fav. I'm using headcannon to romance her, since that's not an option in the actual game. There's no romance, as far as I can tell. 

So much of the game could be described as "not stupid" - a commodity which sometimes seems in short supply in media. If you like depth and you have patience, I definitely recommend picking this up. I'm stoked for Avowed :)

Edit: I should add though, I'm not a fan of some of the aspects of combat. I hate how there are like TEN BILLION different conditions that all boil down to some variation of "stunned" or "dazed" or "paralyzed" and so on. You have to hover over Durance's 400 spells one by one to see if you have a counter to that particular condition. Also characters have lots of interesting defensive capabilities, but they get pummeled so fast (and get "dazed etc." so often), they frequently can't use them before getting KO'd. I find myself lowering the difficulty again... and again... just because combat is getting too annoying and time-consuming.

What I could write about this game would never do it justice. In a few words I can sum up the positives of Pillars to a list that is only comprehensive in how little it actually does justice to the game that has dominated what I believe to be a good game. Amazing characters, beautiful setting, intricate world-building, and a fantastic story. A true 10/10 game and an experience that I have tirelessly begged others to play.
Played this years ago and loved it, played it again and loved it. Obsidian don't ruin Avowed please.

Just a pleasure to play 10/10 wish i could play the story again for the first time :D

Pillars of Eternity embodies nearly everything that’s great about old-school RPG experiences. and the quality of its writing and the attention given to every little detail of its world is such that it sometimes feels like Neil Gaiman is playing dungeon master here. Most importantly, Pillars of Eternity paves the way for what should become a landmark RPG series in its own right. It honors the classics, brings great ideas of its own, and in the process it emerges as a classic itself. Games like this are always about the journey, and it's sure as hell a journey worth taking. 9/10 - Amazing.
Great party based CRPG
I accept that even the wrong path is not a dead end
Much like Tyranny a CRPG that deserved more attention than it ever got. Solid all around game with classic mechanics and ideas. Good times. <3

Wonderfull game, loved the lore, the aesthetic and the combat mechanics, there's a lot of good things to be said :
- Companions are alive, with personality, history and goals, some banter were downright hilarious.
- Classes are distinct and offer a variety of strategy, i adopted dozens of combos and synergies through my play time.
- The whole Caed Nua situation was one of the most pleasant arc i've experienced in any video game, conquering it, exploring it, building it, defending it, discovering it's history and it's mega dungeon was great fun.

The negatives are few but consequential :
- Lots of loading screens.
- Some endgame enemies don't care about melee engagments and simply run around your party, i dealth with them easily enough but it made a lot of the endgame fights very chaotic.
- [SPOILER] The final fight has onyl one ace ups its sleeve and it's dominating your party members which makes this fight goes one of three cheap ways, you burn Thaos down, you click the correct prayer on your priest or you watch your party murder each other.

Played this after BG3 and loved it almost as much, now onto Deadfire.

An amazing and memorable RPG. The highlight of the game for me was the amazing world Obsidian made for this game. The lore of Eora is really cool and has a lot of depth and thought put into it. What was also fantastic was the way most of the side quests tied in to the game's world/lore in some way. It made the experience so much more immersive and made most the side quests feel worthwhile, even the smaller and more "insignificant" ones. I think the way the main quest ties into the lore is great too. It is a bit slower paced and the start, but it goes to some crazy places, asking questions about the nature of gods and theology, the nature of the soul and more. I also loved how the game uses its lore to explain how many of the classes work. Great stuff. 

It must be noted however that if you don't like reading a lot, DO NOT buy this game. I love reading myself, so I loved it, but it is very wordy so do keep that in mind. It's lore dense and deep, but a lot of that is in written form. There is voice acting (which is largely great) but a lot of text is not voiced. This didn't bother me at all, but this may be a turn off to some people.

Outside of that, I think the gameplay is really fun, challenging and strategic and kept me interested the whole way through. The character creation and progression is great and very impactful every time you level up. The characters are mostly excellent, especially the priest Durance and wizard Aloth, among other memorable characters. Some were a bit less memorable but overall very solid.  

As mentioned above, the main story takes its time to get truly going. I think the White March DLC is better than anything in the base game. It's really good and should be experienced, but its placing in the main story is a bit awkward. It cannot be done after the game is finished, and it doesn't really fit storywise anywhere in the base game. 

You also often have to mircomanage your party, especially party members that do a lot of casting. This could get a little tedious, since the AI when left automated kinda sucked, so managing them was often necessary.

Overall, this is a brilliant RPG. Well written, fun and immersive.

I guess someone really liked the old Baldur's Gate PC games and made a new upgraded version of that. It stays close to the source material, but also includes all the flaws those games had. This is for a certain type of gamer and I don't think that's me. You still have to pause every two seconds to either send a command or react to an enemy. And when you're not doing that it's lore upon lore upon lore. Lots of reading.
Great modernization of the original BG type of CRPG, and even though it is 10 years old now, it is still enjoyable.

This game throws a lot of lore at you early on, which can seem off-putting but as you play things fall into place. There is no need to Wiki search everything. Unlike a lot of RPGs I didn't feel put off if I didn't quite have the skills for a speech or action check as there were often multiple paths and you're never fully blocked off. The companions are very engaging and I greatly enjoyed their interactions in quests, it's a shame some didn't have more and that you could only have six companions.

The combat seemed almost too simple at first, however as you level up and unlock more spells/prayers for any wizards or priests in party things develop more. There was some very engaging combat and I enjoyed altering companion gear over time to fight what I wanted them to do, there are some things that aren't as good but, especially on normal, lots of styles are viable and there's no clear OP item a lot of the time.

Probably my one criticism is quite a specific one, and that's that whilst it seems they try to have the game in a sort of 16th/17th century-esque setting what with arquebusses, blunderbusses and pistols other parts struggle to get away from the typical medieval fantasy aspects what with kite shields and the like. I wish there had been a more concerted effort to have a 16th century arms and armour feel to the game which I feel would've made it more refreshing and stand out in that aspect versus other fantasy RPGs.
I've played it 3 times and loved it all three times.

Didn't finish it, but the story and setting is enthralling. Beautiful soundtrack, too.

As my first proper introduction into the CRPG genre it made a remarkable impression upon me.
Really addictive game to play after completing Baldur's Gate 3 and missing an open world adventure
Really good CRPG in the style of the original Baldur's gate games. An engaging story set in the Realm of Eora. Highly recommend this game to get the lore & background to the upcoming game Avowed.

I've had this game for years, put it down, restarted years later and it's still worth playing. I wish it had a option to turn off real time combat for turn based. That's my only complaint. Until you get used to it there is just crap flying everywhere and you have to micromanage the combat through slowing time down and pausing constantly. Again, don't let that turn you off. There is some great adventure, fights and time spent optimizing your party once you understand in what ways it's different than D&D rules.

Great CRPG. I have to say this: go to the first inn and fill out your party to 6. You can replace these mercenary stand-ins with the named companions as you go, but even on Normal the game balances pretty much everything around being a newbie with a 6 person team. I almost gave up on this one as I only had one other party member and was getting wrecked by the monsters.

The game's companion AI system is fair but you will really want to order your party to cast buffs and debuffs yourself to avoid them being squandered on random monsters and then having none available on a harder monster or boss.

I love BG3, but I like PoE1 more.

Wish they would make a PoE3...

10/10

Excellent CRPG. Reminds me of when I first played Baldur's Gate 2. Combat system is a refreshing twist as well. You're gently encouraged to not have to force a fight with everyone to gain exp. Much more engrossing roleplaying exprience.
I gathered my party and ventured forth, slowly and painfully.

This is a very good CRPG. It is almost 10 years now so it is a bit dated, and the combat has some clunky elements, but the game is solid. I also enjoyed the story and character development quite a bit. The interaction between mortals and gods in this world is excellent. The DLC is also worth it. It not only increases the level cap of your character but also adds a lot of lore and context to the game. Overall, easy recommendation.

I'm trying so hard to enjoy this game, but it really does feel unfinished. 

The story is paper thin, and little is done to endear you to any character, or place.  Half the dialog is voiced, and half of it's not, which is incredibly odd when you're interacting with NPCs.  Parts of the conversation are voiced, and others aren't.  The inconsistency is bizarre, and any action described by the "DM" or narrator is not voiced.  As a result, you're often reading action descriptions in between lines of spoken dialog.  The voice recordings do not have a break for these descriptions so you're either reading these sentences while trying to listen to the voice actor's lines, or going back and reading them after.  I found this so off-putting, I turned the voices off and just read everything.

Speaking of reading - I love reading, but there are blocks of text in this game that are so tedious and pointless.  You play as a "watcher," which is someone who sees into people's souls I guess.  In looking around town trying to track down an NPC I needed to complete an early quest, I was bombarded with pages of text from half the people I tried to talk to.  It's not helpful dialog, it's their whole life story.  I just wanted to ask where Nonton was, man.  After a while it became clear this was all drivel, and I just stopped talking to people.  The sound design upon these interactions is also incredibly annoying to me.  Having the sound muffled every time a player tries to speak with one of these people is a seriously poor choice.

All that said, the worst aspect of this game so far is the combat.  It's an absolute dumpster fire.  It's boring to watch, and boring to play.  The effectiveness of any spell or action is unclear, and navigating between characters and their abilities is tedious.  It's unclear what benefits different types of armor have.  Some armor, like helmets, seem purely cosmetic.

The only things I've enjoyed are the art and music.  The music is peaceful, and the Foley for the character's movement during exploration is nice.  It's relaxing to walk around.  

I've heard the story and characters are much better in the sequel, and it looks like they implemented a turn-based option, so hopefully it's more engaging.
Love this game - there's so much to do, and so much thought put into the lore!

The most boring game I've ever played. Writers should never work on games if they would rather be writing a book. And I'm not talking about the kickstarter characters either. The regular dialogue was a wall of text. Do I really need to read a description of what the speaker is doing with his hands? Or the color and shape of his pipe? I'm pretty sure I didnt buy PoE the book.
All the characters are un-likeable and long winded, the plot is stupid, you have gods yelling at you. No freedom of choice. Combat mechanics are obtuse.
Every second I played this I just kept thinking I would rather be playing Baldurs Gate 2. For a game that came out in 2015, this would not have been in the top 10 games of the year 2000.

the intro gave me goosebumps. 


and the game is 10/10.

Amazing game so far, have 188 hours logged so far and will likely have more before I finish my second playthrough. Prior to playing this game I wasn't really fond of CRPGs having played pathfinder and not enjoyed it because it required such a degree of min-maxing (and the story itself felt bland and uninspiring if I'm being honest). 

This game has much less of a difficulty floor, and it has a more interesting and engaging lore behind it. I found myself easily enthralled very early into my first playthrough by the story and background of the world of Eora. Do be warned though, if you want to play this game I hope you like READING because it has a lot of lore dumps in conversations and throughout the world. I personally am an avid reader so I don't mind, but you may if you don't.

The game also has excellent sound design! 

Overall, if I had to rate the game out of 10 I would give it a 9 out of 10, and that's only me deducting one point just to be fair. I LOVE Pillars of Eternity, and I think the PoE franchise is Obsidians best IP and game so far.
Fiery whore!

Tedious, headache inducing, and expository in a bad way. The story isn't that bad but the way obsidian tries to build the universe in this game is confusing and doesn't make you want to pry deeper early on. The gameplay just sucks; you either turn the difficulty of the game down, or every single encounter is a mess of constantly pausing and micromanaging your characters positions and action bars. And this wouldn't even be such a terrible sin if every map wasn't FILLED with combat encounters; it's like they decided that good pacing wasn't important for the game. Overall, it's just not worth the  time sink if you're newer to these types of games.
Good little time consumer.

I can't say anything about the game's content. All I can say is the UI is wonky. As alluring as it seemed to be on first glance, I got quickly stuck setting up my hotkeys and realizing there's a lot to be fixed.

At the start, you learn about how to select your party members, [1] selects the first, [2] the second hero. Then that didn't work for me anymore, with [1] selecting the first and [2] also selecting the first hero. I tried to work around this by setting [2] to "Next Hero", so I thought [1] would select the first hero and [2] would then switch through the heroes. Turns out [2] then reliably selected the second hero and [1] reliably selected the first hero. I set it back to its previous value and it was like before. Then I set it back to [2] selecting the next hero again but it stopped working entirely. Also, I got caught in a loop confirming that I wanted to save changes, where I had to click "No" to have my changes saved because "Yes" would show me the confirmation dialog again.

Before that, there have been other confusing things, such as [Alt] being usable to toggle highlighting, but not to highlight, whereas [Tab] was usable for both. Both left and right mouse buttons would select and move characters and I wanted to have one select, the other move. I set the left mouse button to select, so it didn't move anymore. I set the right mouse button to move, so it would move, but it also selected heroes I clicked on.

It does suck a bit to leave a negative review because the game seemed to hold premise and the reviews speak of amazing content, but outside of an early access title, my standard is that most controls should work and only have a few manageable oddities at worst. Keys not working, the interface buttons not working, that's just not good practice.

By the way, if there is a 3rd party fix everyone knows about, like "why would you play without the community mod that fixes all those bugs", I'd be open to hear about it, although I'm of the opinion that bugfixes should be part of the base game.
Yes

Absolutely incredible game, it's the only rpg I've played where the narrative introduces a twist on your character late into the plot and *still*, *still*, allows you to flesh those choices out further. For sure it takes some getting used to, as crpgs go, this game's accessibility is on the low end. It took me three tries to finish this game originally, but it's worth every hour. With a fantastic, varied, and interesting cast of characters to support your endeavors, this game is a gem. If you're new or the game's leveling/building seems way too complicated, absolutely find a build online. There's a plethora of them and once you find one that resonates you'll be utterly absorbed. The reputation system in the game is incredibly thoughtful, and something I'd love to see more of in other titles, give it a shot.
Good.
Loved the story, loved the characters, loved the gameplay. I played a 100 hours when I got it, and now Im gonna replay it just for fun.
Loved the story, characters, atmosphere and setting, but I would rather wipe my arse with sand paper than play this game again, as the character progression and combat is aids.

I don't know how to explain it beyond this:

If modern first person rpgs hold your hand and treat you like a moron, a'la bethesda or bioware,

And if rebirth CRPGs like AoD and classics like arcanum or baldurs gate 1 are too difficult,

This is JUST right for people who want to get into CRPGs.  It runs the gamut from "holding your hand and introducing you to the genre," to "Holy CRAP I gotta start over AGAIN," and no matter what end you're playing on, it doesn't talk down to you.

It's pretty mid sometimes though. 

I would die for eder, my preferred playthrough is tag-team warrior with eder and everyone else is support.
For any considering purchasing; read both positive and negative reviews before. You'll likely then know if this game is what you're expecting. I made the mistake of not doing so.

Reminds me of Baldur's Gate 2, a game whose concept of adventure, story, world building, and discovery are appealing. But who's combat, movement system, endless reading, upgrades, actual implementation, etc bored me. Fundamentally this seems to be a style of game that does not appeal to me. Pillars of Eternity, as a successful attempt to capture that feeling, does not work for me. If you know you like these type of games, give it a shot. If you know you dislike them, you're unlikely to become a convert.

Great story with a slow burn, but it becomes more engaging as you get invested in the characters and the rising stakes.

The game's world is rich with lore, but the many places, names, and terms can be overwhelming to remember (like Engwithan, Glanfathan, Bîaŵac, Waidwen, Aedyran, Old Vailia, Readceras, etc.). The lore is heavily front-loaded, so I recommend spending some time looking up these terms on the wiki. It really helps you understand and appreciate the story.

Also, keep in mind that Animancer, Watcher, Cipher, and Chanter are different roles, but they're not mutually exclusive. A character or NPC can embody one or even a mix of all these roles simultaneously.
slow, tedious, and unbalanced

The Lore:
I know the game is lore heavy but I had no idea the amount of information that would be thrown at me upon starting the game. Took like 2 hours to just create my character. I didn't realize I'd have to read a book worth of lore and how stats worked (I still don't fully understand it) to understand what anything was. There is lore in the lores lore in this game. Jesus... Everything has a back story. Even random villagers have paragraphs of backstory that is needed for a single thing in game.

Character Creation:
Character creation would be alright if it wasn't for the fact that when you customize your character you cannot set a custom image of it in the HUD. Every image is a static pre-made image so if you create a character with custom features it wont reflect in their portrait... Why is that a thing?

Voice Overs:
The voice overs are hit and miss. One part will be voiced, then not, then voiced, then a lot will not be voice, then a random section will be voice, and then back to not being voiced... All in the same interaction. With dialogue heavy games like this it really needs to be fully voiced. Some 10 minute long dialogues are right before boss fights too. So if you die you have to click back through it.

The Fort:
I spent hours and hours on building my fort and spent all my money just for the first raid to wipe out every... single... building... WHY CAN IT DO THAT! I spent like 5000 coins and you have to rebuild ALL of it. And enemies don't respawn that I've seen in 17 hours to be able to farm money. That is brutal!

Leveling:
This game has the slowest leveling system I have ever seen in a game. I spent almost 20 hours and I'm level 4. FOUR!!! And when you do level up it's not even worth the time it took to get that level because the skills are mostly "per rest." I put 20 hours into the game and I'm only on the 2nd spell book out of 10........ This game is waaaaaaaaay to long. I can't spend 500 hours in one game playthrough.

Skills:
Most skills are "per rest" rather than "per encounter." The difference is that after you use your "per rest" skills you can't use them again until you go all the way back to an inn to sleep or use up a camp. You have to stop playing the game and leave the area to refill your skills after every... single... battle... Especially on higher difficulties. Your healer skills? Per rest... Your mage skills? Per rest... Later in the game the lowest level spells become "per encounter" but that's near the end of the game!!! I'm 20 hours in and STILL at "per rest" for my magic. I can't stand that mechanic and am dumbfounded that was a feature someone implemented and thought would be fun for players.

What the most frustrating feature about skills is that you get basically 1 or 3 skills to use per character when the game has like 100 or so to choose from. The level cap is 12 and you don't even get to pick a skill every level for your class. Every other level you can pick a skill not based off your class but you shouldn't because you need the passive buffs that the game offers you instead. Which is also available to every class. So what the absolute fuck is even the fucking point in having that many skills in the game when you can only use like 1 or 2 of them and they can only be used just one time!!!!!!!!! THAT'S HORRIBLE GAME DESIGN!!!!!

Do you like to debuff your opponents to give yourself a strategic advantage in battle? Well fuck you because debuffs in the game have accuracy. I'd say debuffs land maybe 50% of the time and last a measly 10 seconds on average if they land. Also they are mostly "per rest." Also enemies tend to not care that they are debuffed and just slaughter you anyways so have fun wasting your time on them like I did. I can't think of single case I encountered where debuffing was more advantageous than just attacking.

Combat:
I liked it at first but there are so many issues. I played it on hard and it's about impossible to keep your party alive. Every class feels weak and has only a sliver of skills. I avoid all skills that are "per rest." All mages skills are per rest also so after you use your allotted casts you are basically worthless. WHY!? Fight one battle, rest, fight one battle, rest, fight one battle....... Just sucks the fun right out of it.

It's essential to have a tank but if there is a mage enemy and it targets your tank well you're basically screwed. I thought having my own mage would be great until I discovered you have friendly fire. The enemies just gaggle around your characters so how the hell am I supposed to AoE them without killing my own people? The battle becomes chaos immediately so you can't really even use AoE spells. They generally hit just one enemy so why even AoE in the first place?

Classes:
I've found that every class except a Fighter with a shield is made of brittle glass. I thought having a Paladin would be an asset... No... They absolutely suck and do far worse than a Fighter. You'd think Paladins having healing abilities would come in handy well guess what... Fighters have plenty of healing abilities so it makes Paladins obsolete. If you don't stack Deflection on your one handed shield style class, you die... Don't duel wield, don't two hand, don't punch with a Monk. Get a Fighter with a shield and the entire rest of your party should be ranged attacks. Stupid game design...

I made an Archer and thought that a range class would be a great strategical asset... Hell no it wasn't. Virtually no skills and very weak. The skills they have are useless and "per rest" with only one use. They get a pet in battle and I can say without a doubt they are useless. They have no skills and just serve as enemy fodder and die almost instantly when attacked. I ended up giving the Archer a Gun and the damage improved but the DPS was so slow it still wasn't worth it.

Chanters are completely worthless. They have to spend roughly 20 seconds in battle chanting to activate just ONE attack. ONE!!! And you'd think the skill would be worth the wait but no... It isn't... You can summon skeletons to help you but they do like 2 or 3 damage per hit and die faster than the Archers pet. Other debuffs for NPCs last like 10 seconds and don't do anything to turn the tide of battle. Besides most battles are over before the Chanter can even use a single skill. Just don't use a Chanter.

Guess what? Healers are basically useless as well since their skills are "per rest." Oh you healed three times last battle? Well guess you are done having fun then. Go all the way back to town and sleep to get those spells back. Repeat, repeat, and repeat. That's not role play... That's just fucking annoying.

Items:
I'm sure items may get more plentiful later in the game but wow are they rare. Like potions are so rare that I'm scared to use them. Then when I do they are barely effective. Ever played a game where you can't drink potions in battle? This is the first for me. You have to be out of battle to drink a potion.

Maybe I shouldn't have played it on hard. I don't know. This is actually just scratching the surface with the issues I had with this game. After I lost my entire fort I was done with the nonsense. This game isn't for me at all.

I was intrigued by the character build system, but I found the game play uninteresting. There did not seem to be much strategy, other than maybe choosing your skills and equipment well. For instance, it seems almost impossible to kite or separate enemies. Not as in hard to figure out, just mechanically impossible. The world and quests also seems pretty linear, without much in the way of exploration options. Once you hit a hard spot, it's tough to go to other places to level up, find better equipment or new companions. On the plus side, I did like the music and the world in general. The mood was terrifically dark. Just couldn't get into the mechanics.

I really tried to enjoy this game, but my god is the combat awful. I can get past the dated graphics, numerous lore dumps, and annoying "kickstarter backer" content, but the game just isn't fun to play.

Excuse my English because Im not a native speaker. 

First the PROs
-Lovely isometric visuals and music
-Interesting Lore which takes you one step at a time through the history, traditions, etcetera.
-Interesting idea of classes: not the basic as ranger, warrior, wizard, etc, but also the monk, the bard and others.

Now the CONs
I come from other rpg games which are lot more like hack and slash, turn based or even text, but I have only played one -which also didnt quite find as epic- in which the spells would also have friendly fire. That's a big con... what's the purpose of having wizards and using their spells if you are going to kill/damage your party?
1. Friendly fire with spells

Almost all games I have played let you know what to do, what do expect, how to rest, how to cure yourself, what these bar means, how to use a class? Well, there are those which doesnt help you and you have to guess. If you think you are an expert guesser on the how-to-do-this or that, please, play this game.
2. No tutorial.

As you come from the no tutorial thing, you will find yourself with ... an inventory, but then with your stash, which it seems you are permanently carrying around. its seems, after 9 hours of playing this, that the normal inventory is the quick inventory.
3. Inventory is a pain in the ass

So... no tutorial, strange inventories... but also: vendors are really realistic (they dont sell anything useful) or if they do, those things are sold for the price of an eye.
4. Difficulty is too high to become a good warrior?

How do spells and magicians work? I mean, I came from D&D and Hack & Slash or even text games, but there's no tutorial and couldnt understand how to activate spells, or to learn them like in Skyrim or Dragon Warrior, it is kind of obvious that there's a limit of each spell level per rest, but the how many spells can I learn and the stats are really confusing (a.k.a.: tradition ... helps you understanding but wont give you extra damage). And if you consider that you will be also doing friendly fire without an option to deactivate that, well... 
5. This time the mage is not as good.

Be careful our there if you get wounded, because this is really realistic, you will only be able to heal / treat your wounds out of combat. Also, you get kind of a tiredness bar in which after each combat, you will be more tired and susceptible to damage or to become fainted so... extra difficulty.
6. Potions... please use them to heal instantly.

How do you farm for money? Once you kill something, that thing wont reappear and the area/monsters ratio is too high, leaving so much air, lack of loot and povertiness to deal with. Also, the mobs drop almost nothing and you have to buy all the jewels of the crown to be a decent warrior.
7. No Money and lots of things you need to buy.

What's up with the bard? Can he do something apart from chanting at the start of a combat?
8. I expected more from the bard.

These are some CONs and now Im tired of writing, I may try it again when I get bored of other games and curious enough to try this one again.

In conclusion: I really wanted to love this game. The visuals are really fantastic and the music and lore is really nice, but it has such big  cons in my point of view (not everyone will think these as cons), that I cant recommend it.

Intriguing story, but very vague. The controls are not only complicated, but the user interface is a mess. The first time I attempted Pillars of Eternity, I kept getting slaughtered because it's so non-intuitive. My whole purpose as the player-character was also smothered in question marks, so I frequently wandered around wondering wtf. The settings are pretty, and the characters seem to have a lot of potential, but after 50 hours I finally finished Act 1 - by complete accident. I'm still cursing under my breath whenever there's a fight because it's like an endless sequence of pause-click-pause-click for every member in my party. The data about what is going on is so...textual. Huge amounts of text, and in-dept, disconnected lore. So in all, I'll call this a C- video game (likely two stars, but possibly three). Great ideas, great potential, but way too much confusion and miserable micro-managing of each team member in every fight. Spend your money on a better game.

It's a fun game. Definitely reminiscent of games like Icewind Dale, Baldur's Gate 1&2. The mechanics and rules are different but similar, I think neither adding nor subtracting from the game, just requiring familiarization. I thoroughly enjoyed the game and found there are days and days of content, if not weeks and weeks. 

I did not really encounter any bugs that I can think of, I can't think of a time I was stopped from playing and frustrated by an obvious flaw or bug. 

I got enjoyment from both nostalgia for similar games from years, decades ago, and the sense of D&D style adventure and discovery, and the merit of the game itself and it's own storylines and exploration and battles. I REALLY liked that there is some light upgrading, crafting, and your own fortress and home base. That to me added another level that I don't remember from Icewind or Baldur. Having my own castle/home base, with hirelings and different rooms and local merchants, was a nice added touch. IMO that kind of thing added to any game, really gives you a sense of living in the world, like homes in Skyrim, and other games. And it does kind of give you a sense that you are escaping to your own world, with your own home, where you get a satisfaction of comfort and belonging.

So I can't really think of any negatives, and can only say I felt this is solid gaming and entertainment, worth the price.

My streak of reviewing games multiple years too late continues - I hope someone finds this useful! This was an absolutely wonderful experience from start to finish. Going to split this into three sections to keep everything organised.

[h3] What you're getting yourself into [/h3] 
PoE I is a very story-focused RPG with a main storyline divided into acts and a sea of side-quests and tasks for you to complete along the way. Its two expansions, White March I and II, are structured the same. Combat is real time with pause. The game lets you choose a variety of classes that impact your dialogue choices and quest choices throughout the story. Dialogue is partially voice-acted (important quests, most companion dialogue, etc.).

[h3] Positives [/h3] 
I absolutely adore this game, every minute of it was delightful. Here are some highlights:
[list]
    [*]  [b] Beautiful visuals [/b]  - Obviously the game didn't come out this year, but in my opinion it still looks gorgeous. The game is isometric, which mostly eliminates the threat of 'bad angles' for its environments. The maps all look wonderful, the models are detailed, and though the characters are of course small and took some getting used to after playing some newer games, all the armors and gear are really well-made in my opinion too. Even with the limitation of angle, the environments have a sense of depth and verticality.
    [*]  [b] Top-tier writing [/b]  - Sometimes, CRPGs kind of overwhelm you with text. I'm used to text-focused games, but there is an upper limit to everything. PoE however is not that kind of game. Its descriptions and dialogues are all to-the-point, and it honestly amazes me how they manage to get each character's unique personality and traits across in such a brief format. 
    [*]  [b] Intriguing story [/b]  - I enjoyed the story greatly. There were inevitably a few minor 'filler' tasks to complete here and there, but for the most part, even the side quests had really interesting storylines and outcomes. It isn't often that RPG quests are unpredictable in the direction they take after you've played enough of them, but here it happens fairly consistently, and I love the game for that. I like that there are choices throughout the game that impact the endings you get, too.
    [*]  [b] Extra quest/dialogue options [/b]  - I will never not bring this up as a major plus of this game; your class matters even outside of combat, and lets you resolve quests in unique, otherwise inaccessible ways. It makes your character feel so much more like an actual part of the in-game world, and I appreciate that a lot.
[/list] 

[h3] Negatives [/h3] 
I will try to include a quick note for overcoming/mitigating these for anyone wanting to play the game.
[list]
    [*]  [b] Early combat heavily favours strong melee characters [/b]  - My first quest, on which I went with my chanter PC and Aloth, resulted in me getting absolutely destroyed by a handful of ghosts because low level wizards can do very little before needing rest, and chanters aren't any better off. Later on, both of these characters did a complete 180° and became very powerful, but initially I was tempted to give up on them and just focus on fighters and other warrior-type classes. I recommend sticking with your wizard/chanter/cipher, or setting the game to an easier difficulty if you want - I did as well, and there's no shame in it because the game isn't at all easy at times.
    [*]  [b] Combat has a slower pace [/b]  - This I feel is kind of inevitable with RTWP combat setups, and where it's most glaring is probably in the weird limbo your party enters after killing their last current enemy but before exiting combat mode. To mitigate this, I recommend setting the time/pace to normal rather than slow (Key should be 'S'), which will make this transition faster.
[/list] 

All in all, I wholeheartedly recommend this game with both of its story DLCs. It was a great experience and definitely worth the nearly 100 hours I spent on it.

I was looking for a Baldur's Gate experience so thought i'd give this game a spin. Sadly for me it was mistake. There is some good stuff in this game, but ultimately i found that some of design choices stopped me from enjoying it.

The Good - the game world is beautifully made with a strong atmosphere. Decent music, sound effects and voice acting all combine to deliver a world you want to explore. The quality of this side of the game compares well with Baldur's Gate titles.

The Bad - Sadly the developers made some choices with how the game works that left me wondering why. They range from minor annoyances all the way up to "i don't want to play this any more."

Minor Annoyance: No damage reduction for helmets - wear nothing, a straw hat or a cast iron helm forged in by Odin himself and it makes no difference to your characters' armour or defence ratings at all. I guess no one ever gets hit in the head in Pillars of Eternity.

Disappointing: Characters only healed by sleep - Want to add a priest or healer to your party to patch up your warriors after battles? Don't bother, they can't actually do that. The only way to regain hp is to sleep. This not only renders healing characters pretty useless but also slows down the game considerably.

The final straw: No XP from fights - The big hook for me in these games is levelling up my crew. This is what drives me to explore every corner of the map, murder anything that moves, disarm all the traps and complete all the quests. I do it all just for that lovely juicy XP that i can make my characters awesome with.

But if i'm not getting XP for killing stuff as i explore, then the combat becomes a pointless time sink that i have to endure if i want to see what i might find in that cave or whatever.

Instead of finding a group of skeletons and thinking "Great! more XP for me, lets wipe them all out!" i'm thinking "Oh more skeletons, how annoying".

And so i gave up on the game.

If the XP for combat issue doesn't bother you then you'll probably enjoy this title - as it does feel well made and with love for the genre. But personally i couldn't get past that and lost interest pretty quick after i become aware of it.

Pillars of Eternity is one of the best written games of all time, period. This review contains minor spoilers, but nothing substantive enough to ruin your enjoyment of the game.

This game's writing is genuinely impeccable. All of the companions are well written and amazing, including, and especially the DLC companions. You truly need to listen to each of them, and the game gives you opportunities to both challenge their points of views, and learn from them. 

Durance in particular is an amazingly well written companion. He is a misogynistic priest that views his own goddess as a wh*re,  and damn does he make you yearn for his dialogue indicator to pop up so you can talk to him more. He is incredibly complex, and challenges your views at every turn throughout the game. 

However, aside from the excellent companions, Pillars does something extraordinary that I have not encountered since Planescape: Torment.

Pillars of Eternity makes you truly think about the questions it poses you. Near the end of the game, you encounter various gods, and must perform a task for each to earn a full conversation with that god. These are some of the best written, and most thought provoking conversations I've ever taken part of in a video game, and these conversations will end up deciding the end of the game. Whatever you think you will decide to do up until you have these conversations, you are likely wrong, and the gods will likely persuade you to do otherwise. I was very unsure the entire time of what ending to pick, until I finally came to a long thought decision, until speaking to all of the gods and completely changing my decision by the end of my discoveries.

In fact, all the dialogue with the gods in this game is amazing. In almost every conversation I had with the gods, I had multiple minute long moments of pause, attempting to decide on what stance I truly believe in, as they ask you such complex questions to attempt to change your logic and thinking, thus vastly changing the end and outcome of the game. All I can say is that Obsidian once again proves their writing team is the best in the industry.

However, one moment shines above all others. This is pretty major spoilers for the DLC, but this DLC does not effect the main story in any way other than adding on to the ending.

Specifically, in the White March Part II DLC, you speak with a god named Ondra. This is the best conversation in the ENTIRE game. You spend this entire DLC believing this goddess to be a mad, and evil goddess, as who else could drive their followers to commit such atrocities against you, a champion of the people?

And in a single conversation she flipped by beliefs upside down. I refuse to say more, because you need to experience this for yourself, truly.

If you're second guessing buying this game, play it, it's amazing. You will not regret it.

[h1] Has all the strengths and flaws of Western RPGs. Make of that what you will... [/h1]

Pillars of Eternity is classic throwback CRPG in the vein of Baldur's Gate 1 and 2, Neverwinter Nights and probably a bunch of other 90s computer RPGs I never played but have seen video essays about.
You play as a random shlubbo who gets embroiled in a cosmic scheme involving dethroned gods, reincarnation and a whole bunch of extremely setting-specific mystical goings-on.

PoE does not do a whole lot to hold the player's hand and ease them into the setting and gameplay mechanics, jump-scaring you with dense lore and setting details on frame one of the character creation screen. I assume this is somewhat faithful to the classic CRPGs, many of which assumed a degree of preexisting familiarity with their campaign settings. Pillars of Eternity relentlessly bombards the player with Proper Nouns, place names (most of which you never get to see) and random details about the history and lore of the setting, which may or may not be important later on. My problem with the writing is that for all the detail it crams into its script, the setting never felt particularly creative or enthralling to me. The combination of generic cod-Celtic place names, standard-issue Fantasy races, unmemorable costume design and brown-and-green landscapes made it very hard for me to get invested in the setting and story. I'm not going to read your 50-page centuries-spanning Lore Bible if you look and feel just like every other sub-Tolkien EuroWorld, guys...

Gameplay is similarly confusing at first. Combat is most similar to Final Fantasy XII; a timer-based real-time system that lets you pause to give specific directions. I never quite grasped what each of the stats do or what the various buffs and debuffs mean. Still, I did manage to muddle my way through to the end before losing interest, so even if you're unfamiliar with this type of game, you'll probably be fine. In the moments when you're dungeoneering, disarming traps, slinging spells and hoovering up loot, it's a lot of fun.

I did eventually lose interest, partially due to my play-style (which involved maximising the amount of loot and story content I got to experience at the cost of actual role-playing; though in my defense, it's hard to roleplay as a highly-intelligent wizard when you have to stop to ask very basic details about the world every other conversation...) and partially due to the limits and frustrations of the genre (Who am I playing as? Why is there all this shit lying around? Why would I do what I'm doing except for XP and loot? Why do I have to spend 90% of the game waiting for my little man to catch up with my mouse cursor?)
While I can't say I loved it, I did value the experience. I'm not a fan of what this is, but for what it does is, it's do it quite good...

It's a lot like... really any other isometric, tabletop-inspired RPGs with good voice acting and immersive lore.  What makes it better is that this one has an actually *good* system backing it, instead of something like D&D!

Pillars of Eternity is easily one of Obsidian's best works and is undoubtedly one of the finer CRPGs you can get your hands on. This is a game rife with player choice & customization, where no two people are going to have the same experience. From setting up your character's backstory, their stats, their beliefs, spells & grimoires, to even crafting/upgrading your equipment. There is no shortage of options here, and even better the lore/narrative is just as gripping as the gameplay. This is truly what most RPGs strive to be and yet often fall short of. 

One of Pillars' greatest strengths is its balance between combat, strategy, and dialogue. You unlock a home base after getting through the early game, and from there on out there exists a fun base management feature, that further lends itself to the narrative at times. You may have strangers visit your base and make requests of you, or you could even imprison people who have wronged you, or perhaps you just collect on property taxes to help get yourself the money needed to buy yourself something special this week. All the while, you'll be exploring the world and attempting to unravel the reason behind the mysterious affliction your player character has been afflicted with.

The dialogue choices in this game are often staggering in their quantity & are rarely poor in execution. There are countless well-written characters & exchanges and most of them are heavily influenced by your personal character's decisions, reputation, beliefs, and sometimes even their appearance. Being the gift that keeps on giving, Pillars of Eternity is only the first of two games (a 3rd spin-off is on the way "Avowed") in its franchise, and all of your choices directly carry over to the sequel, similar to games like "The Witcher" or "Mass Effect". 

If you are a fan of Isometric RPGs then you need to do yourself the favor and play this game, because the sequel only gets better. This is a game that rewards patience and one that is easily replayed time and time again. The only harsh thing I can say about it is that the combat has a somewhat steep learning curve if you are not familiar with this style of game beforehand. Otherwise, this is destined to become a gaming cult-classic if it isn't considered one already.

An absolutely magnificent masterwork of a videogame and a masterclass of how to sucessfully develop a well-oiled, all around great, epic R.P.G. Pillars of Eternity is an isometric RPG from the world-wide reputed developers Obsidian, yes, them dudes who will body you in your own saga, and the first installment in the series. It has everything a proper nerd will enjoy: deep, fleshed out lore, political intrigues, complex characters that evolve and voice their own opinions, great soundtrack, fantastic difficulty curve, amazing pacing, great mechanics and a rich, fantastically well designed combat where knowledge and understanding of the game's mechanics are key to succeed. The game is a long, slow-paced journey that will keep you entertained and intrigued from beginning to end, and a very well written story that demands respect and attention from the player in order to grasp a good idea of the whole picture. The DLCs are lovely, very entertaining, quite impressive additions to the already phenomenal main story, which could easily spawn entire books. 

It is a fine example of a no bullshit, no gimmicky, old school purebreed R.P.G., both punishing and rewarding, that will challenge both old cats, like me, and newcomers. I ended a 100% playthrough and started a second character straight away, so it's easy to recommend and a must have. Just buy it.

I've put over 100 hours into this game in the past. I'm just playing through again to prepare for Avowed.

You might think that Pillars are the underdog of the isometric RPG catalogue - but in my heart, this is the quintessential game of the genre. 
Character customisation & synergies, and combat complexity here are absolutely fantastic. The story is unique & awesome. Characters are super likeable in no small part thanks to brilliant voice acting. 
And, most importantly, the quality of worldbuilding is STELLAR. The world of Eora, its history and politics, its metaphysics and pantheon, has no equals among computer RPGs. It's mature, deep, complex, just so finely crafted. This game - and its successor too - is a true gem. <3

I played the enhanced editions of Baldur's Gate 1 & 2, Icewind Dale, and Planescape: Torment over the weeks leading up to my playthrough of Pillars of Eternity. I mention this, because Pillars explicitly tries to emulate those games. And unfortunately it just doesn't hit the mark.

To start with, I found the writing to be way too indulgent: too many lore dumps, too much descriptive language woven into the conversations, and too much character exposition. All of it is ultimately in service of a fictional world that just does not reach the same quality level as any of those old classics based on DnD campaign settings.

A major gripe I had: a lot of what's happening on a moment-to-moment basis within the writing ends up being really hard to follow due to how it's all set up. To elaborate (without major spoilers), your character is a "Watcher", someone who is capable of seeing soul essence, and reading the souls of other living beings. Souls in the world of Eora are recycled, and as a result, you're attuned to the past lives of both yourself and others. Functionally, this serves as a tool that allows the writer(s) to have you constantly jumping into past experiences, exposited in the form of elaborate, flowery text that (for me at least) starts to wear out its welcome really fast. Be ready for pages and pages of frustratingly vague yet colorful language that tends to meander a lot. In a massively missed opportunity you NEVER PLAY THROUGH any of these past experiences via gameplay, it's all just text!

The villain is a man who cannot be taken seriously: his hat is really f*cking stupid, he isn't intimidating at all. Seriously. His dumb hat makes him look like Rita Repulsa from the Power Rangers.

At the end of the game there is a big reveal. It sucked.

So what about combat? In retrospect, the old Infinity Engine games had a style of gameplay that was not particularly challenging if you knew what you were doing. Your knowledge of the game's mechanics (or lack thereof) were primarily what would lead to success or failure. This worked to the betterment of those games: you really felt like you were having a pen-and-paper adventure, where you were only at the mercy of your own understanding (and maybe also the dice rolls). With the right party configuration, spell selection, pre-buff routine, stash of potions, etc, and a little bit of luck, you could be unstoppable. That is less the case in Pillars of Eternity...

Pre-buffing is not possible, as you cannot cast defensive spells or use potions prior to combat. Also, you cannot access all of your potions or scrolls after a fight breaks out, but rather the particular item you want to be available has to be loaded into one of your character's quickslots prior to initiating an encounter (most characters will only have four quickslots).

On top of all this there are tank mechanics that did not exist in any of the old CRPGs. Tanking is primarily centered around the concept of "engagement". It works as such: each character will have an "engagement limit" that can be increased with specific talents, abilities, and gear. This represents the total number of enemies that hypothetically will be forced to focus down that character at any given time. Most tanks will only be able to get up to around four, maybe five with endgame items. This idea works well enough when there aren't many enemies on your screen, but quickly starts to fall apart during larger encounters, especially as you progress further toward the finale. It was particularly noticeable at the end of The White March 2 DLC, where it is possible to get into large fights which include opponents that can leap or teleport directly to your back line.

There can also be a ton of micromanaging depending on your playstyle and how your party is configured. Just like Infinity Engine games, it is possible to configure basic AI packages for your party members, but the AI isn't all that good. For example, Wizard characters will constantly run directly into melee range to cast certain touch abilities. Another problem is just how inflexible the AI is concerning a party member's role. Like, I don't think it's possible to set your priest character to automatically swap between healing and damage; you would have to pause and manually adjust the AI setting mid-combat.

Your reward for pushing through the (often tedious) combat segments usually ends up being just more tedious exposition dumps. A design decision that I found to be completely baffling: you do not get XP for kills in this game. Presumably this was to prevent over-leveling, but it doesn't even accomplish that goal, as there are enough sidequests to render the final dregs of the main story trivial unless you allow scaling.

There are four difficulties: Easy, Normal, Hard, and Path of the Damned. I played the game on Hard, and to be honest, I wish I had not. Apparently, on Hard and PotD enemies get completely slathered in a stat called Damage Reduction, or DR. In order to actually deal any substantial damage to your opponent, you need to hit hard enough to overcome their DR. This means that weapons that attack fast but for less damage per hit end up being pretty worthless, whereas slow-hitting, big chunky hits are what you want. So the majority of weapon types end up being basically trash: you want weapons that have innate DR reduction, or crushing damage, or raw damage, and they have to do lots of damage in a single hit. Why not just give enemies more health instead of this DR gimmick? A lot more character setups would be viable. Oh well.

For the positives: the pre-rendered backgrounds look great (however characters with their lumpy potato faces and weird hairstyles do NOT). The UI was really clean and functional. Uhh... that's about all I liked, to be honest.

It took me 70 hours to get through the main story, about half the sidequests, and all the DLC content. I ended up missing one of the party companions. Playtime could be reduced substantially by skim reading through all the text. The game crashed on me once.

Game Tips that would've been useful:
Followers die if they are downed while their recovery meter reaches zero.
The game is adequately balanced - Normal is challenging enough, but will never get you stuck.
Love this game, but it would be amazing to see some turn-base combat for future update.

First off, I'm gonna start with some beginner tips because omg I wish these were explained through the tutorial:

* Press "tab" to highlight intractable objects - I spent the first half of the game not knowing about this and OMG was it annoying. I thought "shift" would highlight interactable objects initially because this is the key I'm most familiar with using in CRPGs. 
* Set your controls to change the camera movement settings from arrow keys to W, A, S, and D. This helps a lot. 
* Make sure to mess around with the customizable formation tabs. Some formations may cause your characters to get stuck in doorways, which is a hassle to fix, so make sure to set up a "filing" formation and switch between formations before entering a doorway. 
* Do not explore a location unless its either a location you'll regularly visit (ex. a tavern or inn which you'll likely need to frequent). Otherwise, you'll waste time. Only explore the location once you receive the quest related to said location. 
* Do not feel bad or ashamed for looking things up. Trust me, I had to look up locations and major NPC locations far more than once. I highly recommend playing story mode first just so you can figure out quest objectives/locations. The game goes by MUCH faster once you know. 
* Storywise, I recommend playing Cipher because Cipher gets a lot of story content. The best way to play Cipher, however, is a major glass canon build, which can be hard for beginners to figure out. Melee Cipher is possible, but arguably less effective. I know storywise, none of the backgrounds and locations of origin have much content in POE1, but archipelgo islands and aristocrat backgrounds have much more content is POE2 if you plan on importing a POE1 save to POE2. 
* Make sure to set up your character properly stat and class-wise because you will not be able to make changes mid-game. Look up a guide if you're unsure of yourself. 
* You can change your party at any tavern. Just look for the party tab. You can change your skills (not stats/class) at any vendor. 

I honestly feel like my standards have gotten too high because of BG3. But here are my personal pros and cons. 

Cons: 
* I wish there was more actual "roleplaying" involved. I feel like my character's background was hardly mentioned and the dialogue options struck me as "super good", "stoic/neutral", or "super evil" only. Overall, MC shapes the world around them, but the world around them does not really shape the MC. 
* Sometimes background specific dialogue gets locked or not mentioned because of choices you made far earlier in the game, which is disappointing to see. (ex. I let the noble girl get possessed by the Skaenite slaves in Act 1, as RP wise my character had a slave background and just wanted to see nobles burn, but where Skaen is supposed to mention the MC's slave background to both MC and the party in Act 3, he doesn't and instead remarks how impressive the MC's actions during this event were.) I think it can still be assumed/headcannoned that your party knows about your character's background, but there's no reaction to it. This is the same case with POE2. It'd be cool if party members questioned my evil actions during this event, because most party members are good/neutral characters, and I could then explain my disdain for nobles due to my MC's slave background. Overall, the actual "roleplay" aspect of the series is kinda weak. 
* Why do major NPCs look like minor NPCs? More than once, I found it difficult to locate major NPCs because they looked so damn average. Meanwhile, some unimportant NPCs LOOK like they should be major NPCs which pisses me off. 
* There are still some bugs with gameplay. 
* I feel like the companions could've used longer questlines--especially the companions you encounter at the very beginning of the game. I was actually disappointed with how short Eder and Aloth's quests were. The good thing is that most companion quests follow the MC's main questline, so you can travel to wherever you need to go along the way. 
* AI gets confused pretty often. Especially in doorways. It's better to just turn it off and manually control characters for every move, but at the same time it gets hectic, so I avoided doing this unless the battle was a major battle. 
* It's difficult to find certain locations. Many times, I had to look up where to go. Sometimes graphical glitches actually obscured or outright didn't allow me to get to where I needed to go. (Ex. at the final Shadow dungeon (forgot its name) a shadow continued to obscure the stairway I needed to go down to get to Thaos. I had to look up where to go, and I realized this. The stairway only revealed itself after I reloaded the dungeon.)
* Holy F*** the amount of time I spent staring at loading screens probably made up at least 25% of my playthrough. I feel like one thing Obsidian gets wrong that Larian figured out is that each act should be set in one location with few loading required locations. Otherwise, there is far too much back and forth.
* At least 50% of the game is walking from location to location. I think pillars of eternity 2 actually fixes this by condensing the maps slightly. 
* Caed Nua restoration is neat, but I feel like it was underwhelming with the lack of content. I was hoping to see storylines/quests unlock as a result of fixing parts of Caed Nua. (Maybe I missed these? Idk) 
* You, unfortunately, can't change your stats/build/class mid-game. You can only change your skills. 

Pros: 
* Matt Mercer's voice. No, I totally did not just side with the evil Skaenite Wymgourd because he was also voiced by Matt Mercer. 
* Gameplay is fun once you figure it out. I honestly restarted my game 3 times to figure it out. 
* A lot of world building. Arguably, sometimes too much. I did forget major names/titles/events very often as I explored. 
* A lot of gameplay build options
* A lot of reading for reading lovers such as myself. 
* Replayability. There are a lot of builds to mess around with, and there are different choices you can make to impact the ending. 
* Although there is a limited number of choices, they do still impact the storyline. I'm just disappointed they're not as prominent once imported to POE2. 
* Most of the companions are interesting and likeable. My favorite was Eder not just because of his voice, his role in POE2 and his close relationship with the MC, but because he was a major meatshield for my glass cannon Cipher build lol. Eder is a total bro (sadly just a bro). I think you'll like him even more in POE2. 

Overall, the game is enjoyable, but I think I'll be focusing more on POE2 because I think it fixes a lot of issues of POE1. Again, I still feel like Obsidian doesn't understand the most optimal CRPG formula like Larian does because both POE1/2 can get really frustrating at times. Sometimes, I was so frustrated I considered quitting, but i'm glad I made it all the way through. I think POE1 is a one and done game for me though.

I am too lazy to write a long review for a computer game but to make it short: This game is amazing. It has the charme and the aesthetics of an old school CRPG but combined with lots of modern quality of life in terms of gameplay. But most importantly: The story this game tells is AMAZING if you are looking for something that brings up rather big philosophical questions and discourses. Enlightenment, mythology/religion vs. technology, racism, problems of progress, constructivism. And all that in a story that is embeedded in a rather classical fantasy world. This is important to me because I am not so much into the weird/absurd stories (e.g. Planescape Torment) where the whole world is so far away from yours that it's sometimes not as immersive. This is not the problem here – you will often think about what happens in the world of Pillars of Eternity, and you will almost always find analogies to your own world.

In short: I truly think that most of the games that are considered "incredibly well written" are not even close compared to mediocre literature (or films). In my opinion there is one example of a computer game that is as well written as good literature – and that game is Disco Elysisum. BUT the story of Pillars of Eternity is on the second place to me.

Play this – AND DO NOT READ THE DIALOGUE OF THE GOLDEN NAME PLATE NPCs. Those are texts written by Crowdfunding backers that are (sorry) mostly very boring, and will kill your joy of reading this game.

Description: A GEM among Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale series and kind alike...

[b]Pillars of Eternity[/b] is credited with revitalising the CRPG genre. I believe this praise is justified.

[b]PoE1[/b] is a solid CRPG built around the classical formula of [i]Infinity[/i] games from the past with some quality-of-life improvements that make it more accessible to the modern audience.

What I liked the most was the grim atmosphere, the tragic well-written stories, and that it's NOT using the DnD mechanics. Albeit the combat and classes are mostly the same as in DnD, all stats are relevant for each class, the min-maxing is not as crucial as in [i]Infinity[/i] games, and the action outcomes are not decided by random dice throws (there is some probability involved, but to a lesser extent than in DnD).

If you take the time for reading the stat and ability descriptions, the game's cyclopedia, and the combat log, you start to realise how everything comes together. For example, you can choose between high armour rating with slow execution time or low armour rating with fast execution time; strong, but slow weapons or fast, but weak weapons; high accuracy (one-handed weapons) at the expense of attack frequency (dual-wielding), strong defence (shields) at the expense of accuracy (one-handed) or high attack frequency (dual-wielding) at the expense of accuracy (one-handed). 

But the great thing is that all those choices work, if only you stay consistent and build upon them. The game is very flexible in this regard.

Different weapons and different spells provide different types of damage, different armours have different resistances and different enemies require a different approach. That's why you have to study the bestiary before each encounter, plan which weapons, spells, and items to use and how to position your party ahead of the combat. Since the combat is real-time with pause, the positioning is somewhat problematic, but it is still possible to use narrow passages, traps and flanking to your advantage. Everything can be bypassed and countered in this game, and that's what made the combat so enjoyable for me.

Although, I do have to admit that this level of micromanaging is not for everyone. Less patient people probably should just play on the normal difficulty. I grew tired of it by the end of the game myself. On the other hand, after progressing beyond level 8, most of the encounters become a cakewalk anyway. Only some of the high-level areas (in White March and Caed Nua) and bosses (like dragons) are somewhat challenging, unfortunately, mostly because of buffed-up damage resistances and health.

I also have to add, that in the typical [i]Obsidian[/i] fashion, wizards and area attacks get the preferential treatment, even to the point that some of the scripted text adventures (there is such a thing in the game) require a wizard for the best outcome.

I also was not happy with the following. You can't dual-wield pistols and blunderbusses (like in [b]PoE2[/b]). Weapon focuses don't increase the damage, but only the accuracy (by mediocre 6 points). Weapon focuses don't synergise with weapon styles well enough — each focus includes at least one two-handed, at least one one-handed and at least one ranged weapon, whereas the styles are: the one-handed style, the two-handed style, the two-weapon style, and the weapon-and-shield style; there also some passive talents for ranged weapons. With the two White March expansions the level cap is 16, which restricts the flexibility of your builds quite a bit. Consequently, some of the passive talents are not worth the cost. I guess this was done because the players get too powerful by the middle of the game. Likewise, the traps were nerfed and the talents that improve the traps and potions were dropped from the final game version.

Fortunately, all of these minor problems might be adjusted with the IE Mod to your heart's content.

As to the other major aspect of the game, the story, I can say that it's solid. It's nothing mind-blowing, but it's solid. It's a story that takes itself seriously. The game takes place in post-war Dyrwood, where children are being born without souls, wizards are experimenting on prisoners and lunatics, bandits are roaming the countryside, tyrants are oppressing the population, and various factions are competing for power. The quests are well written, intricate, and usually offer more than one way of solving them. If you pay attention to the details, you realise that more often than not they are also tragic. Sometimes, solving a quest requires choosing between a bad outcome and a worse outcome. But which is which — that is for you to decide — since morality in this game is rarely black and white. It's exactly this aspect that made me enjoy this game so much.

I only wish that the companions were more likeable. I didn't develop a sense of attachment to any of them. Only after completing the companion quests, did I learn to appreciate them more. I have used the word "tragic" a lot in this review, but their stories are precisely that — a tragedy. All of them have suffered some kind of injustice, personal loss, or a deeply traumatic event at some points in their lives. So, your job as a watcher (a soul-reader) is to help them to overcome the trauma in one way or another. 
Or not. You can also play solo (the game does not favour that, especially, on the hardest difficulties, but it’s doable) or hire custom-made companions (with potentially better stats). Or you can use the canon companions and modify their stats and even classes with the IE mod.

Before concluding my review, a few words about the economy, graphics, and the soundtrack.

The economy is somewhat problematic. Everything is expensive, and fully upgrading your keep and items takes considerable effort and time. Perhaps, this was done to make stealing more viable, I don't know. Either way, you won't be swimming in money until the final chapter or until you have completed the White March expansions, which not only offer you the best unique items in the game, but also the most amount of loot to sell. Doing White March is not recommended until about level 10, so it's kind of late game anyway.

As to the graphics, well, what's not to like about pre-rendered 2D backgrounds? They look good even in the [i]Infinity[/i] games, even more so in a modern game on a high resolution. It's hard to pick up the details on the 3D models, though, but you can adjust the zoom level with IE mod and a console command.

The soundtrack fits the atmosphere, although I'd say that it's somewhat generic most of the time — you know, your classic epic fantasy stuff you hear in Hollywood films and similar RPGs.

So, in total, I'd rate this game with [u][b]8/10[/b][/u]. It's a solid CRPG with a good combat system and a great story. It doesn't reach for the stars, but “solid” is good enough for me. [b]PoE[/b] tried to deliver the best of the old [i]Infinity[/i] games to the modern audience, and I think it has succeeded in this task. With its relatively low budget, it's a praiseworthy achievement.

First, I want to talk about who this game is for. If you love Baldur's Gate 3 and are looking for the next great RPG, this might be it. First ask yourself why you liked BG3. If the answer was the story, the character's, and/or the world, this game is for you. If you just thought it was pretty and liked the combat, POE may put you off but it's worth a shot.

POE1 does have some minor issues that are a necessary evil for any crowd funded game. Some of the writing for the memories you can listen to was done by random backers. That means the writing for these can have varying levels of quality and... edginess.

The important stuff:

There's a lot of discourse over POE1 or POE2 being better. I'm of the opinion that it is entirely based on opinion. Do you like a dark mysterious forest with a mysterious castle to restore? If so, you'll like POE1. Do you like a sunny archipelago full of piracy and imperialism, with a ship for you to restore.? If that's the case, you'll probably prefer POE2. If you like both, play the games in order and get an even better overall experience.

Both games are, very generally, about solving a problem surrounding the gods of the world. POE1 and 2 are fantastic, so if you have to choose it really is about which setting you prefer.

I don't know if I'll finish this game. It's disappointing - Pillars of Eternity has been on my list of games to play for years, and now... yeah. It's disappointing.

To keep it concise, here are my thoughts in big dot points:

- The combat is terrible. I usually adore terrible combat (Fallout: New Vegas, despite being known for terrible combat, has some of my favourite PvE content in any game) but here it is just soooo sloppy. Even in old Infinity Engine titles I enjoyed this kind of real time CRPG stuff just fine - here, I think there's just way too much of it.

- The story is okay. When I've heard people talk about this game, they've said it's really complicated. It's not, it's just verbose. You know how Fallout 1&2 have really succinct writing? Imagine the exact opposite of that, and the world building and story is also less inspired.

- The backer NPCs suck. The fact that you search "remove POE backer NPC mod" and all you can find is forums of people roasting the OP for asking them to be removed is just lame. Seriously, they are immersion breaking, Tumblrcore original character type bullshit in an otherwise very stoic, solemn game. I don't want someones cool gang of tricoloured vivisectors standing around under the tree hung with muddy, roped corpses (no hate to Tumblr. I love Tumblr, that was just my way of articulating my ANGER).

There are other negatives. The stronghold is underdeveloped. The world feels dead (but not in the way it should - it feels too static). I'm getting tired of writing about it though.

I think Obsidian just needed to make a more focused experience. Make the game a little less linear, replace some of the combat/lore dumping with characters/quests that make the world that feel more alive. Wish I'd chosen a better game to play while procrastinating my uni work
