An heir to the original Baldur's Gate games. If you're looking for an original, mature fantasy setting to dive into, you can't go wrong here. 

What I loved:
- Compelling main plot that isn't afraid to take its time building up to its conclusion. 
- The writers did a great job unpacking the central themes of the game (fate vs autonomy, how to find meaning in a chaotic world, the burdens of knowledge, the value of faith, and honestly so much more). One of the best things about the CRPG genre is that the good ones really make you think, and Pillars does that very well IMO.
- A suitably cunning but also morally grey antagonist. I never felt the writers were pushing me to come to one ethical conclusion.

What I liked:
- I enjoyed the visuals. Obviously they aren't cutting edge but the intentional throwback aesthetic does a lot to make everything still look decent in 2024.
- The gameplay is fun, I appreciate the existence of RTWP systems in a turn-based world. 
- Character building is good, although I think it becomes a little saturated by the time you reach max level in certain classes. I appreciate that Obsidian brought in some original classes for their universe.

What I didn't like:
- Sound mixing was a little bit whacky at times. It's clear they used a totally different set up in recording the White March dialogue, and the mixing is jarring when new companions from that DLC speak right after an NPC from the base game.
- I really liked some companions (Eder and Aloth are my dudes!). But it is very clear who the 'core companions' are - better sidequests, their storylines are baked into the main plot, etc. The others feel like they only exist for the sake of representing their class in the party roster.
- Obsidian really drop you in at the deep end in this brand new universe/system. On the one hand, that's awesome - things aren't spoon-fed to you in massive lore dumps right from the get-go. But it can make things extremely confusing at times, while you find your footing in the world and try to figure out the skills/abilities/etc. systems. Would recommend reading a guide on builds, though it's easy to re-spec if you need to.

Overall, awesome game. Looking forward to jumping into the sequel when I press 'post review'.

Bought this game forever ago, didn't enjoy it much until I played BG3. Since playing BG3, I have an appreciation for the game and love it. The game is great, with awesome story telling. Combat can be pretty hard imo, but you just gotta micro manage your party more. If you enjoy the BG3, I think you'll enjoy this game too. Doesn't have the polish like BG3 but its still a great game. Oh and be ready to read a novel with an insane amount of detail.  8/10

Pretty decent isometric party RPG with real time combat. It's not ideal and has enough flaws for them to be noticeable, but it's still quite good overall. 

The graphics are OK. As usual with the majority of the genre, nothing groundbreaking but good enough and some of the effects are very nice. 
I did not find the visual direction particularly interesting though. It was all drab, dull, grey, etc. Perhaps it was the intention but I did not enjoy it anyway. 

The sound design is OK as well. Again, nothing outstanding but gets the job done. One issue is that some of the dialogues are voiced and some aren't. So, you can go from a voiced sentence to a non-voiced one in one dialogue. It's a bit jarring since it kinda breaks the flow. It would've been better if at least the main dialogues were voiced in their entirety but it's not the case.  

The gameplay is enjoyable and quite interesting. I played on Hard and never felt as if things were too out of control or difficult, with the later stages of the game actually being the easiest. There is an option to make them artificially harder, though, which I intentionally did not take. 
I played as a Wizard and the class fantasy was pretty much fulfilled. I could deal damage with huge fireballs or ice balls, though not as much DPS as a fighter character, I could control the battlefield with CC, I could debuff and charm the enemies (which on Hard was totally OP since it's like a 5-10 second CC with a chance to make an enemy your ally). 

Roleplaying element was good. Not as good as, say, Disco Elysium, which had TONS of branching and flavour, but still good with various choices and consequences, both short term and long term. There were also some quite messed up and grim quests, which I suppose goes along with the whole aesthetic and tone of the game. Even though I did not enjoy grim visuals, I did enjoy those quests. 
The journal of the MC also contained a hell lot of details and was an interesting and helpful read. 

The overall story was passable. I felt it had a bit too much info and lore and was spread too thin as a result. I had a lot of info about different events in the past and present, but I did not feel very connected to them. I found a more personal story, such as GoW I recently played, more compelling and emotional. PoE's story did not impress me very much, it was simply not that terrible. 

Now, there are some flaws which were not crucial but still noticeable:
1. The entire rest system: for instance, wizards have X spells per rest. However, you can almost always (or even always) go out of the dungeon and rest for free, which means there is practically no limit and you can use all your spells every encounter if you want. What it means is that the limitation is purely artificial and there isn't really any resource management, it's just the question of "do I want to see 3 loading screens to replenish my spells or should I go further". 

2. No way to bulk sell items or filter them, which means tons of loot you get from low level mobs must be sold manually.

3. A bit too many meaningless easy fights. They do not pose any danger, they do not serve the narrative, they just exist and waste your time. In some of them I did not even press any skills and just mouse clicked the enemies to death. 

4. The entire stronghold management is very basic and primitive. Narratively, it was nice to have it to signify main character's influence, but from gameplay standpoint it was pretty lacklustre and felt like an afterthought. 

Overall, it's an OK game. I would say it's better than "mediocre" or "average", but it doesn't reach the heights of "great" for me. The story did not capture my interest and the lore was a bit too much. Nonetheless, there were enjoyable elements and at its worst the game was boring sometimes, but never truly bad, awful or anything like that. If you like CRPGs, chances are you might enjoy this one.

I got to Act II back in 2016 on GOG, then for some ungodly reason, stopped playing. Now that I'm back in Act II and actually paying attention, I can say this game is incredible. For a kickstarter game that was Obsidian's last-ditch effort to stay afloat, this game is a miracle. The sidequests are all full of depth and actual important choices, the characters feel real and nuanced. The world building and lore is genuinely interesting and rich, the metaphysics of the world are all carefully built, you feel like you are actually a part of a living breathing world, the gradual building of plot points constantly keeps you on your toes begging for more. 
Basically imagine a really good DnD campaign as a video game. It feels right at home with Infinity Engine classics, it has the personal quest that's as deep as BG1, the grand epic storytelling a la BG2, the dungeon diving and hack n' slash goodness of the Icewind Dale games, and the philosophical and moral quandaries reminiscent of Planescape: Torment. The thing is, it doesn't feel derivative of those games, it stands as much on its own while still paying homage and definitely owing a lot of its identity to them. It's a lot of game but most everything is actually good.
The biggest criticisms I can think of are the rules of the game, it's a brand new system that while it's definitely inspired by and plays similar to DnD, it is its own thing that is very complex and the game doesn't do a great job of explaining things to you besides in popups and menus. The world building as well is very tough to get into, characters will state things that make no sense to the players and it's up to us to infer what they mean by their statements. There are lore docs throughout the world but that amounts to large blocks of text that explain the histories of the various places you discover and the deities and powers at play in the grand stage of the narrative. Unless you read those massive text blocks, you are going to have to play catch up with your party members and NPCs you talk to to try and have a basic idea of what is going on in this game. Once the lore starts making sense, it's fantastic, but it takes a long time of confusion and reading between the lines to get to the point where it even makes a tiny bit of sense.
Score from partway through Act II: 8.5/10

I don't think its as gripping of a story as the original Baldur's Gate or its sequel, nor do I think it really compares to Mass Effect or BG3 in terms of how wonderful the characters were and how enjoyable it was getting to know them; but Pillars of Eternity far exceeds them in making one consider philosophy, theology, morality, and other such high-minded things.

It, much like Obsidian's Pentiment is a game that really makes you think about all of those topics, and while I don't know if I enjoyed it quite as much as Pentiment, it is still an excellent game.

This was my 3rd attempt to play through this game (tried twice on PS4), and again I quit. It's just not a very well executed game, despite it containing some great elements and ideas. I'll be honest, the game just bores me. . 

From a combat point of view you fight very similar trash mobs over and over, most of which are dispatched using the same routine every battle. There's an off balance to abilities as, rather than taking the Dragon Age: Origins approach of giving the player freedom to use everything at their disposal each fight, PoE gives you a mix of rest abilities and encounter abilities. In theory it should work, but in practice it just means you use your Encounter abilities first, and by that point the fight is usually over, thus resulting in very predictable fights. 

And the story is a bit of a mess. It's got a lot of the right ingredients, the hooks are certainly there, but unearthing them is a very arduous task. Pillars also suffers from being one of those games which thrusts you into another world as if you're already familiar with it. You will constantly get dialogue and text which speaks to you as if you are already familiar with the game's areas, factions, and such forth. Piecing all these things together as you go, rather than being drip fed them at a considered pace, makes things feel disjointed.

The exploration areas are a bit empty, timed events such as those plentiful in Baldurs Gate are far too rare, the quests are pretty bland, Cipher is pretty much the only way to play the game lol...oh and I've not even mentioned the completely immersion-breaking and filler-esq "Soul Watching" which you can undertake etc. Honestly, it's just a flat game, not to mention incredibly predictable with it's structure too, which contributes towards the game's general bad pacing. 

There are a lot of good ideas in there for sure though, so it has my respect, but I'm not gonna go into them because ultimately they count for little sadly. If you can stand ploddy, predictably games there is a story in here which is quite good if you can be bothered to piece it together and can endure all the bad stuff, but it wasn't enough to keep me hooked.
Baldur's Gate if it was boring/The problem with Obsidian is their team consists of only about half of the talent that produced the shit they are recycling in the first place

Pillar of Eternity is a highly acclaimed game but I have no idea why. I had many problems with the game and I had to force myself to finish the game or explore the world, since it was pretty boring for me. In addition to that, game feels like an old game more than an old-school game. Let me explain that a bit more:
Gameplay elements seems a bit obsolete and not implemented well enough. One of the most obvious ones would be the height attack, for some reason my men wasn’t able to do height attacks but enemy were able to attack from above without any problems. Other than that, there are lots of enemies clumped together and combat is pretty dull with the requirement of micromanagement. Since there are lots of encounters and some of the enemies are much stronger than the other ones, while having no indications, you have to do it by trial and error with a lot of backtracking. However, worst part is the enemies’ unlimited spells. I died a lot of time, because of AoE chain ccs. Sadly, even though there are a lot of spells and classes, spells do not feel very different or for some parts useful. Since there is a spell limit per rest for some reason, the combat feels much worse and more like a chore. Plus, the loot from combat is abysmal, experience is minimal. So, there is no real reason to fight. There are some boss fights with dragons for some reason. Even with their huge stats, they have mobs around for you to fight with the dragon and the mob at the same time. Guess what you get, after killing them… Just a couple useless items. Another problem would be the money. I had lots of money at my playthrough, since there was nothing worth buying other than the free DLC content. Weirdly, most of the binded weapons are mediocre. I think they were added to the game and you have to achieve some things to strengthen your weapon but a lot of them are not worth it. Therefore, realising this, after putting some time into it is annoying. Another weird decision is the enchanting system. There is no disenchantment option or getting back the rare ingredients. If this was a 20 years old game, it would not be problem but it is a problem for a modern game. Caed Nua would be another point for being obsolete. Although, Caed Nua management is an interesting system at his core, it feels like it is half-done, especially with the constant bandit raids. It is very tiny and almost have no real impact. Putting the unbalanced difficulty (with weird spikes) with a lot of RNG and no rewards to the mixture makes the gameplay even worse. Lastly, some quests are not explained after development or not updated properly and you get confused, especially if you are playing it time to time.
Second most important thing would be the bugs. If you pick two people from the party and try to move them, they cannot go to the place you have clicked for some reason and it seems like they did not care about it at all. Other problems I have encountered are broken interfaces, characters that go invisible (enemies can see them though), until the end of the combat; bugged books that vanishes (I was making a library and tracking the books that I read), bugged audio, weird book font which can change into another font at the same book. Unfortunately, I did encounter all of these bugs during my playthrough over and over again. 
The third and last thing that I did not like about the game was the writing-story. First of all, contributor stories are the one of the most idiotic elements I have ever seen. There are lots of them, they do not add anything to the story, break the atmosphere by pushing you afar and it is poorly written, while being too short to be interesting and too long to be curious. Apart from that, there are lots to read about the world and the lore; the main idea of reading souls is interesting. However, writing (like an amateur writer from Wattpad), pace, some of the events not being believable, while being contradicting to some other events (no one cares about the things that happened, characters do not care about anything around them other than stealing), weird and pretentious vocabulary decisions, bland and forced narrative style with boring, ever-talking characters that you do not care (also you start to not care about the story very quickly) with the choices that has no real impact on game are making this game a chore. Also, there are a lot of skills and choices at the beginning which overwhelms the player. DLCs make the game a bit better but definitely it is not enough.
Story-line for days

The writing just in the first hour of the game is so fucking atrocious and tone-deaf, I don't think I'm prepared to suffer any more of it. 

Beginning of the game:
1. you're sick enough to cause your caravan to stop, causing an accident that requires them to camp for the night
2. but go get your own remedy by adventuring out in the woods. Did I mention you're meant to be sick?
3. The guy who was meant to bring back water for your tea has gone missing
4. of course he was ambushed and killed, along with the rest of the camp
5. so you, being sick, scale a cliff, only to barely enter ruins at the top of the cliff, just in time for the entrance to said ruins to be destroyed by a sudden storm???
6. So your party members from the caravan die while you happen upon some sacrificial ritual???
7. You decide to go to the town your caravan was bound for
8. YOU SHOW UP TO A TOWN WITH DOZENS OF BODIES HUNG FROM A TREE IN THE SQUARE!?!?!?!?
9. Some guy threatens you, tells you to watch what you do or you'll end up in the tree
10. First moment of actual adventuring, some elf is picking a fight with 3 people from the town, 10 feet away from the guy who was threatening you just now, and despite trying to stay out of it, I wind up killing 3 guys??? And nobody cares??? When I was just threatened that I'd en up in the tree???

So then instead of escaping, or hiding, or any distress, the elf just casually says "I feel like introductions are in order after that scuffle." Like, dude, 3 guys are dead, and these people hate outsiders, let's, idfk, go hide or something? fml...

11. So then I find a TEMPLE RUINS UNDER THE TOWN SQUARE!??!?! Is this a settlement...??? This was supposed to be a town looking for settlers to homestead, and there's just a whole ass ruins under here!?!??!

So I go into the ruins, and there's this guy, bleeding out, sleeve drenched in blood it says, and he just starts lecturing me about the history of the realm. He's clearly got nothing but time while he's bleeding out. I have to tell him "cut to the chase" because clearly the setting and his condition calls for urgency, and he says "well, if you insist..."???? So this guy is dying, and he is telling me "can you go take care of this quest for me, there is gold in it for you." OH yeah? who's to say you don't die before I get back? 

In conclusion:
I don't know how much more fucking whiplash I can take, but this writing is ridiculous. It isn't as if that isn't telegraphed by THE VERY FIRST DIALOGUE IN THE GAME" when you've got some flat, accentless, city-slicking hillbilly contradaction, where the voice actor is meant to be slurring and drawling his speech, with missing words and hillbilly shorthand, but just falls flat and poorly delivered.

I'm strapped in dire circumstances, with a bloodthirsty town that hates outsiders just kills 3 of their own folk, and nobody cares or notices? 

Who wrote this. 

It's terrible. 

And this is just the first hour.

As a fan of the older Baldur's Gate games but also as someone who does have kind of a potato for a computer and as such, I'm not able to play Baldur's Gate 3 myself, I started doing research about similar kind of games that are old enough for my computer to be able to handle. I found many recommendations, but what really stood out to me was the Pillars of Eternity-series because of it's own different kind of lore and worldbuilding. I found it really interesting and different yet similar to the older CRPG-games that I used to play when younger. So I bought it and all the DLCs and got to playing... and soon I was 10 hours in and completely hooked. 

There is quite a lot of reading which might not be for everyone, yes, and there are things that could have been done better or differently, but the characters, the story, the combat style (I do enjoy real time with pause more than turn based, personally) and how much there is to see and explore, the many different ways you can go about handling the different quests... it all makes this game worth playing, and playing again - and even again.

I am now on my second playthrough and this time I'm noticing even more things, things that I never noticed during when I played the game for the first time, and I am already planning on my third playthrough to be honest, because this game just gives you so many options to properly roleplay in different ways and to try all the things. And especially at the price you can get this whole game with all the extra content nowadays, I would say this is a must play for all CRPG-lovers.

I had to read a lot of guides at first and restart the game two times then it clicked. Absolutely recommend it, there is something really unique and particular about this game, especially the theme and universe, with many grey morale choices.

It's not like Baldur's Gate 3, the mechanics and overall gameplay is probably more polished, as the cinematics, in this recent modern game. But (it's subjective) Pillars of Eternity is more engaging, if you like a good dark fantasy scenario and ambiance.

I also really like the RTWP gameplay, and I strongly recommend to stick with it, as the turn based mode is more of a hotfix if you really can't stand RTWP.

The sequel is better in all aspects, but don't skip the first if you really want to understand what Eora has to offer, it is still totally worth it and runs really well on modern hardware (and Linux, with proton for the cloud saves synced with Windows).

I bought this game shortly after ti came out, the first time it ever went on sale. It was the first CRPG I had ever played if you don't count Dragon Age, and still is. My first playthrough was terrible and I quit after five hours because I had no idea what I was doing and I was getting destroyed. Fast Forward and I got on the hype train for BG3 but couldn't afford a $60 game so I figured I would tried PoE again. I was in a weird situation irl and ended up theorycrafting for two weeks straight. Probably twenty hours. I was all over the wiki and made a big excel file. Haven't never played DnD before I had a blast just learning classes and skills and mechanics. 

As far as the game itself goes, it was great the second time around. With my immense theorycrafting the game was no where near as hard as it was previously. There were still certain times I got stopped, often against the dryad mage things, but I could usually get them in a few tries. Act 1 is decent though takes time unlocking new areas and you typicaly feel underpowered. Act 2 is the meat of the game. The story gets really good, you have access to most of the map, you've done a little city building lite, you've recruited most characters, and difficulty is perfect (maybe a tad easy since I theorycrafted so much). Third act is where things started falling apart a bit. I hit max level much earlier in the story than I expected and it trivialized the rest of the game. I had read once that most DnD GMs don't like campaigns get past level 12 and I can see why. If you have a team of lvl 15s you just 1-2 shot all enemies, you have so many free spells you never run out of magic, and because of those two things battles get repetitive. The game is also a bit long winded (coming from an JRPG enjoyer) so you're not going to get to the last town until 60+ hours in. And it is a hub town do they litter you with side quests and new NPCs which is all pointless because you are already max level with really good equipment. I haven't actually finished the game yet because I started the DLC before going to the final dungeon and then the holidays happened then other games have happened, so ~85 hours is roughly what you can expect if you do all side quests and NO DLC. Again, if you are max level at start of DLC it is super boring because you just blast through everything

Overall though, I love Pillars and am excited to play the second one which has even deeper systems (which yes, I have already theorycrafted). The story is better than I was expecting, especially Act 2. Bonus that I can play without a hitch on my crappy work laptop
This one is my favorite game of all times. If you are geek you gonna love it: deep mechanics, rich lore and full control over your party. The best CRPG out there.

After BG3 I returned to BG1 Enhanced Edition, which had unfortunately aged to a point where I could no longer enjoy its rudimentary combat and dated graphics.  

I turned to Pillars of Eternity, a game I had played on release, but didn't have the attention span for the introduction, which is an exposition dump.  The entire game is a bit text heavy, but the writing is really descriptive, so if you enjoy exposition you'll be at home.  The story is also more dark than your typical CRPG fair.  

The tactical, real time pause combat, really hits the spot on hard, as it's not even necessarily that hard, but it punishes you quickly for mistakes.  You can quick save and quick load, so dying a few times isn't that big of a deal, food buffs, consumables, optimizing builds, make the higher difficulties more rewarding.  There are 5 difficulty settings, with more detailed customization.  I don't like inventory management, so there is infinite chest for that on my party.  

I'm really enjoying my time with this game in 2024.  It's what you remember about classic BG1, but properly updated, with a new combat system to enjoy, better graphics, better story telling, and improved quality of life.  

My only gripe is that vanilla, you can't re-class your storied companions attributes, so they are inherently inferior to a silence mercenary, you can hire at Inns.
Still stands up in 2024. Play this (and Deadfire) while they fix BG3.

I've been playing the Kickstarter DRM-free version for years outside of Steam, lugging my save game backups to new computers. The Steam (and GOG) versions are nice because of cloud saves. I have a tendency to play a bunch one weekend, and not return for several weeks. 

The game is exactly what you'd expect from a PC RPG if you liked the old Baldurs Gate or Icewind Dale or Neverwinter Night games. The setting is much different from the old Faerun-based D&D setting of those games, which is novel in itself. And there are some rather interesting differences in character classes versus what you find in D&D that aren't immediately obvious to new players. With Chanter being a really unusual and powerful class, and a very interesting rewrite of the old Bard classes (there were many variants) from D&D. Of course all the classes in PoE have something to offer, with Cipher and Wizard being my favorites.

TLDR; Just play it. This is a masterpiece. 

I will be honest I was never so invested in a game before. I was playing PoE after Baldurs Gate 3 and I must say. This game... It hits harder. It makes you question every choice you make. It shows you that there is no happily ever after for all. Everything comes with a price. It has a really strong story that touched something in me that I though I long lost.  

Characters are top notch. Eder and Aloth are easily the best companions that games have ever seen. Even Durance. Oh, man, I hated him so much at the begging of the game. However, after spending all of the run with him in my party I was really fond of him and his story. All other character (companions and not) have strong writing behind them, especially [spoiler]Iovara. Her story made me shed a tear or two.[/spoiler] 

In general, I truly recommend you to play this game. Just expect it to take a lot of time. I mean. A. LOT. It requires you to pay attention to everything that characters are saying so you could understand the main plot. If you want to understand more regarding world and characters inside of it then expect to spend some time reading in-game books and then reading some wiki. However, personally I do not view it as a drawback. If you ask me was I overwhelmed with that time to time? Yes. Bored? Never. 

One major drawback of this game is that I get weak in the knees for Aloth and Eder but they are not real. Which is unacceptable on theirs part if you ask me.

I have just finished my first run of the game including the expansions.
It is a game that is hard to get into: lore is deep, many quests, sub-quests, classes and skills - so it can be overwhelming at the beginning but the more you play the more you are likely not to be able to stop (at least it was for me). It gets extremely fascinating and interesting during mid-game and what happens - the things you learn - during the final act are just mind-blowing. If you have patience and enjoy reading a lot and learning about the lore in-game I can recommend. The combat system can be tricky as it deviates from the D&D one developing its own, which is refreshing and fun to me but can be confusing at the beginning. The story-telling and lore, the feeling of the world and the history of the world you are inserted in, is extremely well executed, I loved it. Looking forward to play the sequel soon.

[i][h1]You have something you want to ask him, one question above all others, spinning madly in your mind...[/h1][/i]
There's something about tales of exploring one's own past life and/or unraveling secrets of ancient empires that reaches out to my soul on a primal level. There are very few stories that scratch that itch for me. Pillars of Eternity did.

It is a story both personal and down-to-earth... and grand beyond the scope of mortals,

[i][h1]You are here because you are lost. May you fare better in your next lives.[/h1][/i]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3142361272
As far as cRPGs go, I am neither that good at them, usually opting to play on story difficulty for, you guessed it, the story, nor have I played that many. But what I've seen of Pillars of Eternity, I enjoyed - including, and maybe most of all, the challenge of combat.

I played a priest because after finishing BG3, I realised that clerics are kinda OP in these magical worlds. As a priest, you unlock a TON of spells on level up that can provide great damage, great buffs, and healing. Like in D&D, you have a certain amount of spell slots per level per rest, and need to rest to replenish your spells. Some spells are per encounter - so if you want, you can save up and go longer without camping, since you can only carry a limited amount of supplies (6 on easy, 4 on normal, 2 on hard, unlimited on story mode). When you run out of supplies your options are to return to an inn or to your keep - to buy more supplies and to rest (resting in inns and in keep with upgrades gives certain bonuses that persist through camping). 

You will need to camp when your health drops low - which is also an interesting system in PoE I. You have 2 meters - Endurance and Health. When your endurance drops low, your character becomes knocked out, but they can still get up after combat or after a "res" ability is used. But if your health runs out, that character dies. Period. Endurance replenishes between encounters, but health does not, so to replenish it you must rest (that's the main way to replenish it).

My favorite memory from playing this game comes from the very start of it, when you first obtain your keep. I went to explore the dungeons under my keep and on one level, not too far in, I found a hole going deep underground. Of course, I did what any reasonable person in my place would do - and I jumped in it.

Only to come face to face with a [strike]DRAGON!!!![/strike] drake. There's only 5 in my party, all level 3 or 4 - and I don't have that much in the damage skills department. I don't know where I am and there's no way back - only through. Hours it took me to kill that drake and the adds that would stunlock my party. For the first time, I had to use every buff, every spell slot, every food item, craft potions, craft scrolls, and strategically position my party to outdps the enemy before they would outdps me. 

And what an experience it made.

And Pillars of Eternity is full of such memories.

Mainly because the difficulty modes are... strangely balanced. Personally, I can't find rhyme or reason to them, but I can't deny that it might also be a skill issue. Throughout my campaign, I was ping-ponging around between easy, normal, and hard difficulties, trying to adjust my experience when the game became too easy... or too hard.

Say, for example, you're starting on easy. In the first village, in the main square, where you meet one of your first companions, there is a stairway leading down underground. No one tells you to go there, but I mean, [i]it's right there.[/i] So you go down, accept a quest... and the mobs there aren't exactly what you'd expect from an easy difficulty - they will easily steamroll you if you aren't careful, and you need to rest after every pull.  

Not sure how you would tell that you aren't supposed to go there straight away if the difficulty spike relates to you being underlevelled (since it's the beginning of the game), but yeah. It adds its own level of challenge (that I, personally, didn't dislike).

One time the game kindly asked me if I wanted to increase the difficulty of encounters (outside of the normal difficulty options) since i'm overlevelled for the next zone - and playing on hard at this point, I agreed. How could I have known that the next moment it would spawn 10 spell-casting, club-bonking ogres on me and decimate my party? Moreover, that [i]every[/i] trash pull in that location will be similar? I couldn't have. And I didn't save. I had to put the game back on normal for future locations and sneak through the Elmshore with utmost caution.

Also an adventure.

[i][h1]What of your cohorts then? They have followed you to their deaths.[/h1][/i]
The real main story is the friends we made along the way. There are 8 companions in Pillars of Eternity (and 3 more in the DLC). 3 of them will go on to join the cast of the second game. Pillars of Eternity I, unlike its successor, doesn't feature romance - but in my opinion, it only serves it for the better here. (Although, a couple years ago, I would say it's a major negative point - I'd take Alistairs and roses all day any day, thank you.)

All of the companions have their own story that needs resolution. I have to be fair, I am not exactly certain what happens if you don't resolve them. I mostly travelled with Eder, Aloth, Durance, Kana and Hiravias/Pallegina, and I think i got a well-rounded and loyal adventuring party. That they don't have any reputation systems only makes it better because you don't have to worry about squabbles.

Some companions have a reputation for being somewhat annoying, but I personally can't see why. I didn't have any trouble with Durance, and the only character I didn't bother resolving the quest of was Grieving Mother (because she's a cipher, she appears kind of late in the game, and I already had a full party anyway).

[i][h1]Your memory shall be your penance.[/h1][/i]
I imported my save into Pillars of Eternity: Deadfire and so far, I... am not really liking it. For one aspect it improved over the original game, it took two steps back in another. The RTwP combat feels sluggish, the per rest mechanics are gone, you don't get your full array of spells as a priest, and what you do have you can only cast a few times per encounter because... priest charges???? what are those???

Pillars of Eternity is just something... One of a kind for me. On the one hand, it makes me sad that its sequel is different. On the other, it makes me appreciate it on its own even more.

There is simply too much text in this game. Similarly to Tyranny, the developers will describe what characters do, describe what is happening in the scene, and have characters talk and talk and talk. If I wanted to read a fantasy novel, I'd go read a fantasy novel. If I wanted to have a somewhat interactive experience, I'd play a visual novel. There is simply no good reason for a regular video game to have this much text in it. VFX, sound effects, character animations and cutscenes where developed to convey story in more interesting ways.

The most underrated game series from Obsidian. I have some gripes so let's get it out of the way. I do not like real-time with pause combat and this game does not change those feelings, I definitely got use to it as I went along but overall I cannot say I enjoy this game's combat. Feels like I need to select all the options to proceed in a dialogue tree which can be irritating specially if I am doing it over and over again because again said combat. 

Okay now the positives, I love this game's world, the character building options, the NPCs and party members. This is what kept me going. The world is delightfully bleak, but the characters feel real and there are so many great moments with them. The Stronghold is one of the best parts about the game and is so much fun to upgrade. Overall story is what kept me engage as I wanted to see where it would go and how I would approach certain things. And this makes me excited for Deadfire and Avowed later this year.

I really, really love Pillars of Eternity. I own it on console as well(100%), and I've got as close as 100% as I can here. You can't achieve 'Kickstarter Backer' without having been one as far as I know. Maybe the complete edition has something for that. Why do I bring that up besides to be a little cranky about that? Because I think you can see a lot of other games in Pillars of Eternity as a homage to older RPG games when it was announced as a Kickstarter title. As such you can see quite a few quirks that haven't aged well or feel a bit tossed in for the value of having it over it serving the story and being critical. It feels more like older RPGs for better or worse!

I also personally find the Attribute system to determine things about your character a bit off. A barbarian for example should have decent to high Intellect for AOE swings. Speaking of combat you should be prepared to micromanage and get hit with seemingly random difficult spikes on occasion.

Pillars of Eternity starts very dark, and very dour. Your character has an infliction that will drive them insane! But there is no consistent pressure after that, no driving force helping push the player. The pacing falls off and the dour tone for your character doesn't quite hold the strangle that the game implies. As long as I am on writing, Pillars of Eternity is _wordy_. I love hearing about peoples homebrew TTRPGs and have no problems with this, I consider it a positive. If anyone out there doesn't like endless information on a world be aware Pillars of Eternity is a beast.

I'm not blind to the game having some deeper flaws but I view it in a very warm light. I love hearing about the world, I love being in it. I think the companions are interesting and enjoy the variety of personalities since two I really dislike seem to be fan favorites. I love a lot of the weird, outdated quirks of old RPGs for some reason. I think the graphics hold up well and look beautiful, and that the White March is a phenomenal add-on to the game as DLC.  If you're new to TTRPG-style games I would gently recommend another title before going for Pillars of Eternity. Otherwise I'm happy to say I love it.

Generic pro-tips for the interested:

-I often used summons as bait. This is viable from magical spells to items to an ability Chanters have

First and foremost, I can say that I recommend this game. While it can't quite live up to the legacy of Bhaal, it makes a good stab at being a spiritual successor to the infinity engine games.

It feels like a modernised non-universe take on Baldur's Gate with some Icewind Dale elements that is somehow a little more obtuse yet clear in it's systems than BG/IWD. There is also no multi-classing in this game, but don't worry; all classes have abilities (no bored fighters here) and you class is not set in stone for any character you import into the sequel. I will also note the addition of a fast forward/slow down button, which really takes the time out of travelling around areas that you've already largely cleared. It does lack one key hallmark of the infinity engine games: being able to rest your way to victory; you now have to have supplies to rest anywhere that isn't an inn and you can only carry 4 of these at a time. I do particularly like the separation of health (longer term) and endurance (encounter) too. I like the fact you can lose, gain and have mixed reputations with factions, but I wish they had more impacts, say, on prices like in the sequel.

I really liked the endless paths and the white march content in particular. The battle of Yenwood field was also interesting, as was the relatively dark feeling you get from Raedric's lands. Additionally, white march content is most certainly worth doing and the main quest is also pretty good. I will note, though, that act 3 in particular did feel a little bit empty to me compared to the relative wealth of content available in act 2 or even act 1's offering.

In terms of companions, you can create your own, but they lack any personality and may as well be "hollowborn", so that brings us to the game's companions, all of which have their own quest attached to them and all of which range from fantastic to okay, with most companions weighted towards being fantastic and their quests being weighted towards good, in my opinion.

But whatever you do, always punch Gathbin.

After finishing two full runs through this game (one solo), it’s fair to say I warmly recommend it. Even though it uses its own RPG mechanics, it feels very faithful to the classic RTwP experience of Baldur’s Gate and Icewind Dale, except with modern graphics and UI.

I really can’t find much to fault in it except perhaps the frequency of loading screens in towns and indoor areas. The music is immersive, the art is consistently nice, the numerous side quests are impressively diverse and inspired to the point where I kind of want to borrow them for my own tabletop campaigns... and there is certainly no lack of content and lore to lose yourself in for hours upon hours and fun builds to try for a new run or three.

If you play them, you want to play them all, right? Pathfinder, Divinity, Solana -- if there's a party to be built and travelly dungeony adventure to be had, you have to play it. So you have to play Pillars of Eternity, too. Go get it.

What, you're still reading? OK, fine. I bought the second Pillars game and was having a great time. But I kept missing out on all this backstory stuff. It's not like you *need* it, but I wanted to learn more about the crazy events and highly (highly) detailed world from the first game. So I bought it. And now so must you.

(Bonus: a comforting callback to Baldur's Gate that Obsidian threw in.)

All of the elements for this to be a spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate are present, however the story is poorly paced with several beats out of place, and the custom core game system is confusing and lacking in polish.

Damage reduction, buff durations, and stat abstraction are key compounding issues, coupled with the over-reliance on charm and dominate in place of interesting encounters / creatures, most of which you have seen by the end of act 1.

Worth playing if you really like CRPGs, but not one that is worth going out of your way for.

From the studio that brought you STAR WARS: Knights of the Old Republic II - The Sith Lords and Fallout: New Vegas, Obsidian Entertainment delivers a beautifully crafted cRPG with Pillars of Eternity.  Paying homage to ‘Baldurs Gate’ and ‘Icewindale,’ Obsidian Entertainment helps breathe life back into isometric cRPGs. Gather your party and venture forward as you embark on an adventure filled with dungeon-infested monsters, war-torn politics, and magic that allows you to read others' souls. Prepare yourself to enter the world of Eora, where your choices and paths will forever shape your destiny.

Pillars of Eternity places a strong emphasis on character creation and development. Players can choose between eleven unique classes, six different races, and backgrounds that influence the players’ skills, abilities, and interactions within the Eastern Reach. Another standout feature is the beautifully crafted world that is Eora. Boasting hand-drawn artwork, you can see the attention to detail within the game. The bustling cities and ancient dungeons are nothing short of awe-inspiring. Each environment feels alive, teeming with history, lore, and a sense of mystery that beckons players to explore every nook and cranny.


The storyline in Pillars of Eternity is something we come to love and expect from Obsidian. Featuring a dark and bleak narrative that explores themes of souls, reincarnation, and the consequences of the player’s choices that impact the storyline and characters–leading to multiple branching paths and endings. 

Let’s not forget another thing Obisidian excels at, loveable and life-like companions. Edér Teylecg; the well-articulated veteran from the Saint's War with a blackly humorous outlook on life. Aloth Corfiser; the obsessive elven wizard blinded by his duty. Or Kana Rua;  an Aumaua chanter on a quest to discover the secrets below Caed Nua. With up to eight recruitable companions in the base game, with an additional three more in the expansions, you’ll find yourself lost for hours in conversation, or party configuration to suit your play style. 

Pillars of Eternity excels at providing a challenging yet rewarding experience. The isometric perspective and real-time pause combat system are executed with precision, offering a strategic depth that caters to both seasoned RPG veterans and newcomers alike. The variety of classes, skills, and abilities contribute to the gameplay experience that remains consistently engaging throughout the entire journey. I found myself captivated by the overall combat experience. Spending hours learning the system, reading about different buffs and debuffs, and meticulously crafting my party for the right fight. 

I was entranced by the wonderful score composed by Justin Bell. The music perfectly complements the game's atmosphere, evoking emotions from awe to tension and enhancing the overall immersive experience. I felt the same set of emotions the first time I heard the score from Howard Shore in the Lord of the Rings trilogy. Beautiful and elegant, I found myself listening to the score outside of the game. 
Pillars of Eternity stands as a shining example of what a classic RPG can achieve in the modern era. It successfully marries the nostalgia of the past with the innovation of the present, forging an unforgettable experience. Whether you're a seasoned RPG enthusiast or a newcomer eager to explore a rich fantasy world, Pillars of Eternity is an absolute must-play that will leave you eagerly anticipating what Obsidian Entertainment has in store for the future of the genre.

As many have already pointed out, the game tends to lean on the dull side, both in terms of combat and story. The combat is this odd mix of being overly complex and strangely simplistic, with the game not bothering to give much insight into its mechanisms. Some fights are a breeze, while others catch you off guard, with seemingly harmless mobs dealing one-shot blows to your team members. Plus, the dialogues can be a real snooze-fest, thanks to the overwhelming wall of text. Not to mention, not all dialogues are voiced—only a fraction of them are.

While I get that reading through walls of text is a hallmark of CRPG games, not every tradition is worth keeping. Even games like DAO, developed back in 2010, did a much better job of guiding players through their worlds and stories without drowning them in text.

In conclusion, the game has its merits, but it's not a universal hit. Don't let the glowing reviews blindside you. It's probably a good idea to check out some gameplay videos on YouTube before taking the plunge. And when I say some, I mean more than one.

[h2]Pillars Of Eternity Definitive Edition Review[/h2]

I never intended to spend much time on this game; probably 40-50 hrs at most, but before I knew it I had ended up spending 120+ hours in-game! Review is after completing the main game and all dlc and both expansions; including all main quests, companion quests, side quests and tasks on Normal difficulty. 

[h3]Pros:[/h3]
[list]
[*]I enjoyed all the reading, especially the named NPC backstories. All the expertly written exposition surprisingly helped with one of my English exams!

[*]The game allowed me to delay levelling up, which is a highly appreciated feature. I was able to level up based on the challenge the game offered at each progressive stage.

[*]The game had a relaxed inventory system that promoted hoovering up all loot. After all, in a world with magic why would they even need to worry about carry-weight?

[*]I particularly liked the Wizards summoning of [b]thick[/b] [i]slimy[/i] tentacles with which to pound enemies!

[*]The game soundtrack was entertaining and the option to download it and enjoy it at leisure was most welcome.

[*]Side quests supplied choices that had both large and small consequences in later Acts and in the ending.

[*]This game is called the spiritual successor to Baldur’s Gate; in my opinion this is appropriate.

[*]Companion quests had strong writing, excellent voice acting and were quite varied. I liked how some of them provided closure while others didn’t necessarily do so; as is often the case in reality.

[*]There are no romance options in the game. Perfect! It would have made zero sense for my wild Orlan to romance my odd brigade of companions. Obsidian didn’t shoehorn romance into this game and that is ideal.

[*]Figuring out the use of AI combat patterns and group formations felt smooth and organic.

[*]At the beginning of the DLC and Act3, the game inquired if I wanted to increase the challenge as I was overleveled. I declined, as the overleveled state was intentional. But the feature to ask the player’s choice was most welcome.

[*]The game provides named unique items, which can be upgraded or enchanted depending on the item type. The DLC also adds more unique weapons that can be bound to certain characters by fulfilling various conditions. I felt this was a very thematic and appropriate system considering the lore of the game.

[*]I was quite saturated at the point of playing the White March Part 2. Over 100 hours in this game I never intended to invest in. So I lowered the difficulty a notch to help speed through fights faster. As such, the ability to adjust difficulty at any time was much appreciated.

[*]Notable voice acting by the actors for Eder, Aloth and Durance. All other companions also have superb voice acting. Moreover, I felt the main villain’s voice actor played their part incredibly well. The majority of side characters also had decent voice acting.

[*]Speaking of world building: now that I have devoted over 100+ hours into this game I am fully invested in the world of Eora. All that’s left to say is: “More please!”

[*]The game dropped hints of the Deadfire Archipelago, setting up some lore for the next game.
[/list]
[h3]Cons:[/h3]
[list]
[*]While it appeared enticing to obtain all the achievements of this game, some of them required a level of dedication I simply couldn’t spare.

[*]At the 90% mark of Act 2, I felt overloaded. After exploring the entire world map thus far, the game dumped a new capital city with its own culture and lore on me. I was weighed down by this, especially because I felt their culture was uncivilised and barbaric and it tested my patience. Perhaps because, at this point I just wanted to be done with Act 2.

[*]Loading times were bad right from the beginning of the game and progressively got worse. Quicksaving felt like the easier option. Manual saving or loading felt like a painful option.

[*]When playing the White March Part 2 I experienced occasional freezing of the game. Waiting for about 1 to 2 minutes resolved these issues.

[*]When loading the save file list doing a mouse click would freeze the game. Windows asked whether to close POE but being patient resolved the issue.
[/list]
[h3]Advice:[/h3]
[list]
[*]I played while occasionally referring to a walkthrough from Gamefaqs. I learned that lesson from playing Divinity Original Sin. My advice is explore and play a new map area/dungeon as you please while manual saving often. Then refer to the walkthrough to check if you missed any hidden area/item/quest/approach/dialogue. As this is a large game, investing in a second playthrough can be extremely time consuming. Therefore, it’s best to experience the complete buffet of game content in the very first playthrough.

[*]Another benefit of referring to a walkthrough was discovering the optimal playthrough order. That would be: PoE Act 1, PoE Act 2, White March P1, PoE Act 3, White March P2, PoE Epilogue. That approach covered all of the Definitive Edition content in a chronological manner.

[*]The dragon battles were the toughest in my opinion; the other encounters could be managed using kiting, drawing enemies to narrow corridors or springing traps or ambushes. 

[*]The game dumps a large amount of lore and history from character creation itself. Much of it didn’t make sense until Act 2 and onwards; therefore, a healthy amount of patience is required. Perhaps this was intentional as the developers had to create all this new lore and world history from scratch; certainly no easy task.

[*]Wizards are the most fun class and next would be priests. Their wide range of spells, buffs and debuffs offered the greatest opportunity for creative problem solving gameplay.

[*]Refer to an online build guide. I played as a Wild Orlan (furry), paladin, sword and shield tank built to specifications. Therefore, I had a much smoother combat experience having an incredibly durable tank character.
[/list]

So what exactly are these so-called Pillars of Eternity? For me they represent the entire world of Eora and its various mechanisms; its cycles combined with the various race’s attempts to understand those mechanisms while living their daily lives.

Sorry, but in 2023 I'm not playing a game where you have to trek all the way back to town, sit through 10 loading screens, and buy more camping supplies just to be able to heal your party. That doesn't make the game more difficult or immersive, just annoying. 

There is not much added challenge to fighting a battle with a low health party, it just makes victory pretty much impossible. 

On top of that, it really breaks the immersion of the game. I'm in the middle of the woods with flint and tinder in my bag, but I can't rest because I'm out of "camping supplies"? Likewise, I'm inside of a building with a fireplace and some comfortable chairs and bedrolls, but I can't rest without "camping supplies"? 

Adding pointless tedium is just poor game design. Not sure who thought this mechanic was a good idea. Go play Divinity, Baldur's Gate, Pathfinder, Planescape, or plenty of other better options in this genre.

Pillars of Etenrity is a retro cRPG in style of first two Baldur's Gate games or Planescape Torment. Indeed, it takes a lot of inspiration from those titles. Although the classic fantasy elements are present, the game is far from unoriginal. It's technological level is closest to XVII Century than medieval times, allowing you to use guns alongside meele weapons, bows, crossbows and magic. The story takes on themes of gnosticism and Nietschean philosophy, while dealing with often truly morally grey situations. Meaning not the cowardly mainstream "both sides are wrong and only Enlightened Centrism is right" or "these people have a point, but their methods are wrong so they're evil", but carefully crafted situations where you can see how even worst acts can, to some extent, be justified. You will be often forced to take decisions that are not purely good or evil, even the possible third option, if any such exists. The lore also is interesting, full of stories of cycles of violence rooted in colonialism this region suffered, tragedies of ancient times coming to haunt the world once again and games played by the gods.

The game uses an isometric view, with a "real time with a pause" , during which you control a party of six characters, where positioning and use of specific abilities of various classes is important. While you can make separate characters as mercernaries, you also get to recruit a colorful cast of characters, from fan-favorite laid back farmboy war veteran Eder, to enigmatic Grieving Mother.  Each one of them is haunted by their own goals and demons, be it Kana Nua's  quest to find ancient writing of his people's ancetors, Pagelina's dilemma between loyalty and pragmatism, Hiravia's crisis of faith or fascinating deep hidden secrets of Durance, Grieving Mother and Aloth. The characters are unique and feel like natural progression of archetype deconstructions that we have seen in classic Baldur's Gate I and II. 

One of the interestign aspects that even more advanced games in the genre do not always posses (looking at you, Baldur's Gate 3, whose protagonist doesn't get his own tent for some reason) is the stronghold that the player will acquire at the end of the first act. You can build and expand it, which helps for a long time offset the issue of huge amounts of money at your disposal. You also get to take guests, make decisions regarding various visitor's goals, often being able to play them for your advantage or allow your party members to handle them, take up bounties for challengign enemies or send idle party members on quests you later get nice short narratives. Unlike Dragon Age Inquisition, you never feel like you're doing busywork, while the NPCs handle cool quests, however - even if the adventures your companions had off-screen foten are interesting, so are your own quests. Also, there is an absolutely amazing megadungeon beneath the  stronghold as well, not to mention quest in which you have to defend your claim to it, cullminating in an amazing battle.

Many segments are handled through hsorter narratives, where you can get different outcomes if you usecharacters with high enough attributes, which cut down on some busywork aspects of a game like this. Attributes also unlock new dialogue options, a system that Disco Elysium would perfect years later. Unlike many games, the mechanics are designed so that there is no one stat to rule them all and every attribute is as useful for meele or caster characters.

Worth mentioning is als othe music, which you probably have heard if you are a fan of Critical Role, as Obsidian was kind enough to let them use it on their streams for years.

Pillars of Eternity has aged gracefully and, even if the cRPG genre may have progressed with the likes of Pathfinder, Diso Elysium or Baldur's Gate 3, this game is still a source of many enjoyable hours of interesting story in old school style. I will also rip off the hell out of it for my d&d games ;)

(This is the most recent "update" to the review: I'm 100 hours in now and I still consider this as a somewhat of an underrated crpg. It's beautiful, stylish, and has the same vibe as Baldur's Gate 2. The more I've played this the more I've grown to appreciate this. It really is like the actual sequel to Baldur's Gate 2 and I think many might have missed this due to the naming).

The actual review:

I've played PoE on another computer via another platform so the Steam hours don't reflect the actual hours played.

The game feels more like Baldur's Gate II than BG3 does. In general I like the style and the overall feeling of this game over BG3. The visual style is gorgeous, even though textures are not sharp when zoomed in. The battle mechanics and stats etc. take learning and a lot of things are not explained clearly enough. I had to watch a guide on youtube to learn about stuff that I hadn't known about during dozens and dozens of hours of play prior to watching the guide. I assume there's still more to learn. This is not a minus though, if you're aware that you need to use some outside resources to understand the systems well.

The game is not easy by any means and requires a lot of reading into what different spells and abilities etc. do. Knowing what spell and ability does is what makes the gameplay easier and more fun. It's still challenging though (based on my experience on hard difficulty). One gets most out of the game when really taking things slow and reading the lore that the game presents, reading info (stats, abilities and lore) on beasts etc. Really taking in the whole setting helps to see and appreciate what the devs have done with this project. Btw. Pausing the game prior to the combat action is already combat gameplay. Impatience kills the fun, I've noticed. So again, understand that taking things slow and appreciating all the minute details is how one gets most out of the experience.

To me, this is one of the best crpg's, at least when it comes to the overall style, lore (BG2 might be better though), and the overall vibe and immersion. It's like some of the classics (BG1, BG2, Icewind Dale 1&2, Fallout 1&2, Arcanum etc.) but with better graphics while staying true to the classic 2D-graphics style and not killing the immersive old school feeling with some more modern looking execution.

Definitely recommended, if you're into this kind of a setting and have patience. The game is just lovely. (Edit: I made this last comment prior to having been presented with some f*cked up sh*t by the game. I'll withdraw the "lovely" and replace it with "great" with some surprisingly twisted and dark themes. Although I guess it's nothing that hasn't been dealt with in Game of Thrones as well, for example... Anyway, I could have gone without it).

Edit #2:

And one little extra tip for making the adventuring even more immersive. Instead of using the hotkey on a whim, to see whether or not there are interactables and info spots in an area that your party is at, use a D20 and throw that to see whether or not you can press the hotkey. A little rule that I use is that manual searching with the mouse cursor is still permitted, even if the throw fails, but with using only the mouse there are some things that are bound to be missed that otherwise would be easy to notice with the hotkey. This approach is more immersive and fun in my opinion though.

And one can use a perception check from the D&D rules, for example. Or whatever works or feels best. So far I've just simply rolled a D20 to see what number I have to exceed to succeed with the check and then add +2 to the perception roll (per my character's stats and active effects). If the initial "difficulty check" is 3 or less I just don't use that bonus and roll anyway instead of having it to be an instant success. Oh yeah, and a strict rule that makes this kind of a "perception check" meaningful is that one can use it only once in any given area that is visible on the screen at a given time, and not use it anymore over that location, after having made a failed check.

I loved this game, but made some mistakes going in. The first mistake was not assuming it would be like other TTRPG style games, and choosing to play a class which had too many spells to pick from, right at the beginning. 

If you're new to this game, I would suggest a 'simple' fighter-style class to start with, so that you get used to the mechanics, and then on subsequent playthroughs, you choose one of the more 'complex' classes. 

The story is pretty good, it's engaging enough whilst having some of that D&D charm (note, not a D&D game, but that's the bar against which everything is compared in the VTT world). The overall world building is excellent, and possibly my favourite part of the game.

I read somewhere that they were planning a tabletop ruleset for the game, but I haven't heard anything about that for a few months, so maybe there were some problems in playtesting.

Either way, this is a good game, if you like the genre of old school CRPG, and I highly recommend playing it.

Even when playing Pillars of Eternity for the first time my heart started to feel a strange tingling around it.  A tingling that slowly turned into a warm embrace the more I traversed through the world of Eora. I was certain then - this was going to be one of the special ones for me. 

It only takes the first notes of the main theme to hit your ears and dreams of dragons, mighty battles and potent fantasy will fill your mind. The gentleness of the song only hints at the iconic soundtrack that will accompany you and your party throughout the whole story.

You’ll feast your eyes on isometric goodness of caves, mountains, keeps, battlefields, forests and everything in between. A charming art style which, while being an homage to its predecessors, still manages to stand on its own. Amazing sights are spread throughout the whole world. Sights that will make you want to relax by the lake, browse the city market or whichever vista grabs your eye and imagination.

A mysterious plot involving gods and the cycle of rebirth will be unfolding the more you progress. While many pieces to the puzzle might be missing in the beginning, once all is done you will be able to see where they were hiding. In the process of doing so you will also uncover and experience the grandeur of Eora, its gods and the people that inhabit it.

Chaotic battlefields and, at times, unfair battles will challenge you throughout your entire adventure. It does get easier with time. But, the difficulty is there. You will feel overwhelmed and put against impossible odds. However, despair not. This only makes the joys of victory that more bountiful. That is, if you succeed in persevering throughout the challenging times that await you.

Some of my most epic fights I’ve had are here. And they took a lot of planning, preparation, adjustment and exploiting weaknesses as best as I could. Walking the Path of the Damned made the combat no joke for me. Especially the dragons that I faced. Each presenting a new challenge. And a new weakness to find and take advantage of. 

Pillars manages to pull off what great art is capable of. Create and match vastly different elements together. Elements that succeed in complimenting each other in effortless and perfect harmony. And while I can see its faults and how some people might not be able to get into it I’d say this - if you are a fan of CRPG’s, or video game art, this one is a must try. Pillars of Eternity might not be perfect, but for me it’s close enough.

Pillars of Eternity is an old-school RPG in the spirit of Balder's Gate I and II.  The game's setting is sufficiently original to feel fresh and different, but with enough familiar elements to hook traditional fantasy lovers.  The story is intricate and the characters are definitely fun and memorable.  The downside for some will be the lack of a turn-based mode (don't let this turn you away because it's easy to adapt to the pause and play mechanic) and the deep lore of the game which does require a healthy bit of reading (the lore is well written and engaging so I would also encourage giving it a shot, even if this makes you cautious).  I definitely recommend it for anyone looking to play old-school open world RPG that takes place in an original and engaging game world with tons of flavor.

Pillars of Eternity is what I would consider a baseline for good RPGs. It's engaging and feels good to play, but never quite made me fall in love with it like the best RPGs can do. If I wasn't also playing its sequel, I doubt I would think about this game a month from now. With that said, it does have a lot of qualities that makes it stand out enough to be well worth playing.

Gameplay-wise, PoE is both terrible and great. Terrible because of the stealth option being tied to searching, which means that you have to move at half speed if you want to find any traps or secrets, something that bogs the game down a lot. Great because of the combat, which often involves varied enemies and scenarios, with competent AI and some fun abilities. I specifically enjoyed how AoE abilities work, where if the outer rim hits your party it won't harm them, allowing for some ease of use while still requiring some aiming. It's clear that a lot of care went into combat feel in the game, and it's unfortunate that other areas were left a bit undercooked in comparison. I never really liked moving around the world, which is a shame.

Even more so because the world building is so effective. Many parts goes into this, including the excellent story-book skill checks and dialogue descriptions, but I think the main thing deserving praise compared to many other RPGs is how PoE melds its world building into the story. Reading book excerpts and asking locals about their history and politics aren't just flavour or momentarily relevant, it plays a part in what is happening in the bigger plot and, more importantly, [b]why[/b]. It doesn't hurt that the main plot of the game is really good, a mystery where new revelations seamlessly expand your understanding of events. When it gets going, it's very easy to get swept up in it all, and the world building only adds to that.

With that said, the story has a couple of flaws. One is set up and pay off. In the first hour or two, you are introduced to the game as a kind of settler-native conflict. There are ruins that the natives don't want desecrated, which is presented as a big deal. Now, that conflict does exist in the game, but it's far from the main focus, or even the emotional core of the story. This kind of set up without a satisfying pay off happens several times and, while it could be seen as red herrings, hurts your ability to care about the story. This is further impacted by the second problem, the characters. While their interactions throughout the game are well executed and much better than some older Obsidian games, they still lack the edge that makes a character memorable. I got the sense that if each character got dropped into another RPG, they would be the dullest character in that game, with maybe one or two exceptions. Again, it hurts your ability to resonate with the game emotionally, which is a shame.

I want to end on a positive, so let's talk about the morality system. It's clearly a focus for Obsidian to make morality non-binary in their games and instead make it more fluid, like the real world often is. And I think they did a good job here; choices can still be good or evil, but the emphasis is put on other values like honesty or aggressiveness. Because of that, each choice is more free and thus requires more thought. Isn't it right to be aggressive towards an enemy that seems like they would give up if given a reason? Can you really be merciful towards a serial killer and still be in the right? It's something that few RPGs do successfully, and this game is probably the best one that I've played in that respect. More games should take after this way of handling morality.

Overall, I really liked Pillars of Eternity. More than I expected beforehand, to be honest. A lot of problems that exist in other games are solved here and that's a clear strength of the game. At the same time, problems are also created here that I haven't seen in any other game. Basically, it's very different from your standard RPG. If that is a draw or a deterrent is up to you, but I do think it's well worth trying out.

Like many other reviewers, I wanted to like this game but just couldn't. It's got some interesting elements and you can tell the devs put a lot of effort into creating and interesting world. That said, for the most part I found it boring, there's multiple systems that do not quick click which makes it boring in the end. The fighting is repetitive and requires too much micromanagement. The world building is interesting but the way it's presented it's way too much information too quickly which makes it hard to follow, and that led me to just skip the flavour parts which I never do in these kinds of games. The trap searching mechanics are terrible, basically you have to stealth to find traps which makes exploration tedious as you have to go everywhere using stealth (which is slow) or risk running triggering them. Inventory management is a chore and the usable items seem so weak that I never bothered using them. Finally, almost every time I felt like quest resolution and dialogue options were not the best, they either lead to boring outcomes or the outcome that you'd want is not available to chose from.

Background: I discovered Pillars of Eternity in the context of finding games with similar, if not the same, "real-time party-based RPG" feel as Fallout Tactics: Brotherhood of Steel (a childhood favorite of mine). I played the game on normal difficulty and completed all main quests, side quests & tasks. As I usually play games largely for the story while setting reasonable difficulty, I don't intend to have further playthroughs with the game.

I enjoyed playing this game for almost 200 hours. The plot/story is engaging and I was pleasantly surprised when its puzzle pieces started to come together in the Final Act. The wide conversation options and the consequences stemming from them are impressive. The companions you encounter in the game enrich the experience with their takes on your journeys together. The graphics were decent, at least for its age. 

As this is only my second time playing with such a game (after Fallout Tactics), I was shocked but had fun dealing with the complex game mechanics: many classes & races, 8 damage types, 4 categories of defenses, 6 attributes with impacts that do not seem intuitive at first (e.g., a barbarian frontline crowd-control character needing high Intellect attribute for its abilities and talents to be more useful), and a lot more. To keep up with the complexities of the game, I actually had to make tables of abilities/talents/spells/chants/invocations and statistics of enemy types detailing their strengths and weaknesses. There is also a nice figure available online by user Gairnulf that details the effects of the attributes: https://pillarsofeternity.fandom.com/wiki/Attributes?file=Attribute_effects.png. All of these somehow made the game less overwhelming for me.

Perhaps the two issues (albeit minor and forgivable) I have with the game that I can think of is that (1) some of the written dialog have no voice counterpart or have a slightly different voice counterpart and (2) there are several instances when I had to read blocks and blocks of text in the game to make sense of something.

Overall, this game is a great exercise on exploring nuanced consequences of choices - from gameplay when creating your characters and allotting points to their attributes, skills, abilities, talents and spells/chants/invocations to story progression. I look forward to play Pillars of Eternity II in the future.

[h1] Don't let the dull first couple of hours dissuade you... this deep RPG is one of the greats[/h1]

[i]Pillars of Eternity[/i] is "classic" style RPG heavily influenced by [i]Baldur's Gate[/i], complete with a massive world to explore, plenty of side content, gorgeous isometric backgrounds, and highly tactical realtime-with-pause combat.  Although it never reaches the heights of [i]Baldur's Gate[/i], it's overall a more consistently enjoyable experience start to finish, and is also a much fairer game.  Regardless of its issues, it ends up being a fine spiritual successor to [i]Baldur’s Gate[/i] and a fantastic RPG on its own.
[hr][/hr]
The game ends up having a very interesting story, but takes a bit too long to get there, with the first couple of hours being particularly dull since you basically have no idea what’s going on with the story.  Instead of seeming mysterious, it comes off as meaningless… and then you spend the vast majority of the game doing stuff that basically has very little to do with the plot.  The game also suffers from being wordy and overwritten, with the actual good writing being buried under flowery descriptions and excessive exposition.
[hr][/hr]
Fortunately, playing the game is a wonderful experience.  There’s a massive world to explore, intriguing mysteries to solve, and a fascinating combat system to learn.

Questing is a highlight of the game.  Many quests have multiple solutions, with some options available only for certain types of characters; sometimes, you may just not be persuasive or wise enough to resolve things peacefully, and the only choice will be to fight it out.

And it’s a great combat system.  Although it seems completely overwhelming at first, with several damage types and resistances to track, the game actually gives you all the information you need to understand its nuances, right there in the combat log.  Even better, encountering the same enemy multiple times slowly adds more and more information to its bestiary log, and simply hovering the mouse cursor over an enemy will give you the full rundown on its strengths and weaknesses.  Difficult combat encounters then become extremely tactical, with you slowly stripping away enemy defenses while building up your own.

Similarly deep is how you build your characters and party.  The system provides you with a ton of flexibility in how you want to play the game; unlike many other RPGs, there are no attributes that are completely useless for certain classes.  A high Might Wizard will play very differently from a high Intellect Wizard, and both characters would actually be very viable to play.
[hr][/hr]
All in all, an excellent RPG that’s a must play for any fan of the genre, particularly fans of [i]Baldur’s Gate[/i] or [i]Icewind Dale[/i].  Highly, highly recommended!

A cross between the old Baldur's Gate saga and Planescape: Torment. It has that old-timey feel of the older RPG games and (for those of us who get easily motion sick) a stable, third person, top-down view (Yay!). Although Pillars of Eternity exists in their own fantasy world (FYI, think Dragon Age in terms of available in-game lore: MASSIVE), players of any D&D game will recognize a lot of the battle tactics (real-time combat), wizard spells, and priest abilities. PoE does bring a few new things to the table, like new classes (e.g., ciphers, chanters) that are a lot of fun to play with, new weapons (gunpowder!), and a Divinity-esque approach to class skills and crafting (but with less confusion). The main plot is unique (think Wheel of Time, but vastly improved upon) and very grimdark. Side plots vary between dungeon crawls or dialogue-heavy tasks that cultivate MPC's personal reputation. And the companions vary between adorable-let-me-take-you-everywhere to why-isn't-there-an-option-to-murder-you. Soundtrack is beautiful. Artwork is good. My only true complaint... and that's said more wryly than anything else... is the excessive wordiness in everything. Think of a promising fanfiction writer who is trying to employ as many adjectives as possible. It's not bad, per se, but... wordy, lol. In short, PoE deserves a place next to the old classics and is solid enough to stand on its own. The White March DLC adds even more flavor and interesting companions.
