If you're already a fan of CRPGs, give Pillars of Eternity a try. If you're new to CRPGs, I wouldn't recommend starting here. 

The reason I wouldn't recommend PoE to someone who isn't already invested in CRPGs is because, when compared to contemporaries such as Divinity: Original Sin 1 and 2, Baldur's Gate 3, and Disco Elysium, it is not as, well, "fun." Don't get me wrong, I do think it's good, but it's nowhere near as engaging as the best modern CRPGs. It took *me* three attempts before I finally finished a playthrough, and I think that's because the game is a little... drab. Especially in the beginning. The story takes a while to build and, in my opinion, it isn't until Act II that things really get interesting. (From Act II on, the story does become rather captivating, with seriously thought-provoking themes.) But the environments are same-y and mostly generic meadows, the tone is very dry, the combat is micromanage-y real-time-with-pause (with A.I. options), and playing involves a lot of reading of rather plain prose.

Now for the reasons why I think Pillars of Eternity might still be enjoyed by someone who *is* invested in CRPGs. While I think PoE's world may be mostly visually uninteresting, Obsidian took great care to develop a realized setting. I think their world-building is strong, and the lore they've written is interesting. A lot of the finer details of the world's religion, government, history, etc. is there if you choose to dig a little, but the main story revolves around the lore in a very satisfying way, so the more you give the more you get. And, as I said above, by Act II you will be more invested in the world and its mysteries. Role-playing options are given this same attention, with your character being defined by and remembered for their actions and the context behind those actions beyond "good" and "evil" (i.e., were you benevolent, diplomatic, indifferent, aggressive, cruel, etc.). You are given a plethora of (oft difficult) choices, big and small, that affect not only the fate of the world, but the fate of small villages you encountered, and the paths your companions take after the events of the story. These choices are not always obvious, often coming through seemingly insignificant dialogue options, encouraging you to carefully consider your character and exactly how they would react in a given situation. Play a consistent character [note: "consistent" =/= one-dimensional] and your ending will feel earned. If you enjoy CRPGs, you will find Pillars of Eternity to be a fulfilling RPG experience.

(P.S. As a bonus, the White March DLCs are even better than the base game! Definitely pick them up.)

Pillars of Eternity is one of those games I really wanted to like, but I couldn’t.

I first played this game when it released 8 years ago. I quit after 20 hours, but the thought of finishing it has been lurking at the back of my mind ever since. So, after 8 years, I finally decided to give it another go.

I’m the type of gamer who loves RPGs, and I especially love Obsidian Entertainment’s earlier games: KOTOR 2, Neverwinter Nights 2, Fallout: New Vegas. They are classics. Unfortunately, Pillars of Eternity is not one of them.

If I had to describe this game in one word, I would describe it as “tasteful”. The story, the art, the writing are all consistent and well executed.
The soundtrack is outstanding. One of the best soundtracks I’ve ever heard in a video game, Justin Bell did an excellent job for sure.
I have to give credit where credit is due, Pillars of Eternity is a tasteful game.

Yet, during my 60 hour playthrough, it never really hooked me.

The game is set in a medieval fantasy world, which feels unique in its own right.
I'm happy Obsidian Entertainment finally has their own IP! I admire the rich lore of Eora, and I‘m excited for future games set in the same universe (i.e. Avowed).

The issue is, lore building is not enough in itself. It's not engaging content, at least not for me.
I’ve played a lot of RPGs and I would say I enjoy reading more than most people, but there’s a limit.
The endless exposition in this game is just excessive. The characters are constantly talking about past events that, when you think about it, have little to no relevance to the story.

The story, in a nutshell, is about the reincarnation of souls and about the gods.
It’s not my cup of tea, I prefer stories that are more personal. I found it hard to relate to any of the characters and to actually get invested in the plot.

A couple other pain points I had:

- The combat was fun for a while, but it became a chore mid-game. The only character I enjoyed controlling throughout was Aloth.
- The leveling was quite disappointing for me. You can’t increase your attributes and skills are useless. You need to rely on “talents” instead. It was difficult to wrap my head around this, I had no idea how to build a character well, what talents to pick, what items to use.
- The Kickstarter characters and tombstones are immersion-breaking.
- The long loading screens are off-putting.
- The game is too dark sometimes. I noticed this on multiple occasions and there’s no in-game setting to make it lighter.

As I said, it's a well-made game, but it hasn't captured my attention. I found it mildly interesting, but I can't recommend it.
Takes a little getting used to, but a very interesting RPG once you get the hang of it.

Complex and finely woven, it has the enduring quality of a classic

Among the all-time greats in terms of writing and narrative cohesion, with a depth of storytelling that few in the genre could ever match. This isn't the sort of RPG where you need to collect four crystals to unlock the boss. There's no morality system. No 'right way' to play it. Instead it asks the player to imagine themselves in a bewildering and broken land, and challenges them to form their own conclusions

A masterclass in worldbuilding. Voice acting is stellar. Visuals are polished and lovingly crafted. Combat mechanics are quite deep, but even on the hardest difficulty level there weren't many encounters that took more than two tries

The game's story is good but I think that the problem with the game is that it is all story (or rather all writing, expect A LOT of reading). Most of the actual gameplay is just... Confusing. You control 6 characters in real time with pause where there are 4 different damage resistance types that you need to memorize and each weapon has a different think it affects and classes have tons of weird names for spells and abilities that aren't very clear as to what they do and out of nowhere a character loses 60% health and you have no idea what the hell just happened.

Stick to 4 dialogue personality types (they pop in dialogue like "[Stoic] I got balls of steel") and expect the game to screw you over in storylines. The game's tone and atmosphere and writing is very... I dunno if I should say nihilistic or realistic. You can't save the day all the time. That's not the kinda game this is. And there are a lot of times where the game outright just screws you over because you lack something. Like you don't have the right race, or religion, or sub-race, or upbringing, or class, or personality type or rep. 

But I mean, yeah, it's a decent story. Play it on Normal until you get fed up with the bullshit then turn it down to story mode and just enjoy the story.

Pillars of Eternity is honestly rather dull. The setting is 90% bog-standard, even if the developers put some effort into creating a new universe and lore, it feels too similar to DnD. The game was based on a good idea: In a samsaric world where souls pass from one life to another, the wheel of death, rebirth and redeath has been broken and it's our job as the Dovahkiin™ to fix the cycle. Souls retain the memories of all the persons they once were for some reason, which can create psychos if a living individual start to "remember" its past(s). Our main character can see and interact with the souls of the living and the dead, travel through their memories, but at the cost of his sanity. Despite this good idea, somehow the developers managed to make a generic experience out of it. A shame, really. The story does a lot of basic mistakes, lot of set ups without pay offs or with shitty pay offs, it feels like the story's ambitions exceeded their level of competence. Three quarters of the dialogue choices are "Please tell me more about X" in different ways and a lot of the descriptions are straight walls of exposition. Roleplaying is surprisingly satisfying though, nothing revolutionary but there are options for playing very specific types of characters that would make sense in their world. Chargen and tactics have some decent depth to them, but most fights end up boiling down to "lock down a chokepoint with your tanks and grind down the enemies with whatever combination of abilities your party have".
The White March, however, is fantastic. It leans harder into the setting's less generic elements, the plot is punchier, and everything as a whole is just much more exciting and enjoyable, including the fights. Overall I'd say the game (Definitive Edition) is worth playing, but I dunno if I'll bother getting the sequel, probably not.

I am only 10 hours in and this is the first game to hold me in the manner that Baldur's Gate did. The game is absolute quality and if you enjoyed some of the old BioWare RPGs from days past I highly recommend you give this game a shot.

A Masterclass in CRPG Design: Pillars of Eternity Exceeds Expectations

I'm thrilled to say that Pillars of Eternity is an exceptional CRPG that has exceeded my expectations in every way. As a fan of the genre, I was blown away by the game's attention to detail, depth, and complexity. From the moment I started playing, I was hooked.

One of the standout features of Pillars of Eternity is its racial passives and stats system. The ability to customize my characters with unique abilities and traits based on their race and background is incredibly engaging. The stats system is also incredibly detailed, with a wide range of attributes and skills that can be combined in countless ways to create a truly unique party.

The game's skills system is also noteworthy, with a wide range of abilities that can be combined in creative ways to solve puzzles and defeat enemies. The ability to craft my own recruits and shape them into a powerful team that synergizes together is incredibly satisfying. The tactical gameplay is also top-notch, with a focus on positioning, timing, and strategy that requires careful planning and execution.

But what really sets Pillars of Eternity apart is its story. The game's narrative is engaging and captivating, with complex characters, moral dilemmas, and a richly detailed world that draws you in. The writing is superb, with clever dialogue and a sense of humor that adds to the game's charm.

The game's visuals and sound design are also noteworthy. The graphics are stunning, with detailed environments and characters that look like they've been ripped straight from the pages of a fantasy novel. The sound effects and music are equally impressive, with a haunting soundtrack that perfectly captures the game's dark and atmospheric tone.

Overall, I would highly recommend Pillars of Eternity to fans of CRPGs and fantasy games in general. It's a masterclass in game design, with a focus on depth, complexity, and storytelling that sets it apart from other games in the genre. If you're looking for a game that will challenge you, engage you, and leave you wanting more, look no further than Pillars of Eternity.

Amazing! Such a great game for those whom like Dungeons & Dragons but dont have the beefy PC to run it. Fantastic characters, atmosphere and story. If i had to have any gripes with the game, it would be the sorta out dated graphics, but its park of the appeal which is fine. But my main gripe is that the start is just so depressing...not a shades of grey kind either. Honestly definitely recommend this game with the sequel as it is all one fantastic story and games series.

Overall, though the game is not a masterpiece, it is worth playing. It is an enjoyable tribute to the original Baldur's Gate & Icewind Dale games. The world and the characters are very well done. The combat (and there is a lot of it) is kind of hit and miss. I like the combat mechanics in theory, but the difficulty scaling turns it into a bit of a slog. There are a vast number of intriguing spells and skills and items, but unfortunately, you don't get to properly appreciate them all, because for so much of the game, your enemies are either so easy you hardly need them, or else they're so hard, you get pounded into a paste before you get a chance to use them. Skillful play and judicious use of items allows you to take on harder enemies than you could fighting on autopilot, but no amount of skill is going to let you slay dragons with level 1 players clad in loincloths and armed with pointy sticks. If the enemies are much lower level than your characters, they're so easy it's annoying to have to fight them. If they're much higher than your characters, you're going to have to reload and go to some other area to level up a bit first. My advice is to take full advantage of the difficulty settings that can be adjusted in game, but keep in mind, it only affects enemies in areas you haven't yet loaded. I thoroughly enjoyed about 75% of my play through, but by the end, I just wanted to get it over with. I finished the game in story mode, which didn't make the combat fun, but at least it kept it short.
Good CRPG

A decently enjoyable DnD style rpg with ALOT of story/lore/stuff to read in it. Like the Divinity series, it has multiple difficulty settings for players of all strategic skill levels. Combat is done in "real time" and can be paused when ever you want to have characters be repositioned or cast certain spells. Just a heads up though, there is ALOT to read/investigate, so if you dont got much patience for doing such things, then chances are this game is not for you.

Also as a heads up, there is NO health healing spells or health potions in this game (you will find many and i do mean MANY, threads talking about healing this and healing that, but they are all referring to restoring endurance, NOT restoring hp/health). There is 1 health restoring talent that you can burn one of your precious talent points you get via lvling that restores 20% of a friendly characters health over 9 seconds once per fight but thats it.

There also doesint seem to be any life leech in the traditional rpg sense aka life/health/hp/what ever you wanna call it steal (again, tryed to google it, and it turns out everyone is just talking about endurance which has so many ways to be restored in this game that its not even funny).

You mainly restore health via camping/resting at an inn. Wish alot more game reviews had stated this (by this, i mean the almost complete absence of skills/items/ways to heal health other then camping/resting at an inn) for had i known before hand, i most likely wouldint have bought this and pillars 2, but it was on sale when i got it and just assumed it would have healing spells in the traditional sense and health pots, for in truth, i didint know they made ANY kind of rpg almost fully void of such things until i played Pillars and ive played MANY rpgs/types of rpgs since the days when they started to come out on the NES console and PC.

Still, after having clocked in 10 hours as of this review, my whole gripe about the lack of health healing stuff aside, it is a decent game, but i do implore anyone reading this review, READ OTHER REVIEWS AS WELL! For although i havent touched on combat encounters in this review and lack the experience to talk about it at length with my limited time clocked into pillars, other reviews, both positive and negative, have stated that they can be random in difficulty, with some being ease, others being "Omg most of my party just got pwned nearly instantly" and some just flat out popping cc spells on your party off the bat/often.

Overall, if the game is on sale, and your ok with no health restoring spells/health potions being in the game, with your real, main source of healing being resting at an inn/camping, and enjoy a game with alot of story/stuff to read, then i def recommend buying this. 

Honestly though, even though i am giving this game a "Recommend" checkmark, its really more of a "Neutral" check mark from me. Because, as someone that mained a healer in WoW for many years back in the mid 2000's and other other mmo's that came after, finding out 9h into the game that there is no "healer" in the traditional sense of the word (after the hours of reading i did in addition to my play time in this constantly thinking id get my heal spells in another lvl or so but turns out they just did'int exist) really killed a VERY large portion of my desire to play through it. Like come on, there's healing in table top DnD and in R.A salvatore's drizzt series but not in this? BAH! MEDIOCRE! (says zols in his best mad max fat, ugly, evil main dude voice)

Positive: Gameplay

Gameplay-wise this is a very faithful modern adaptation of the classic Baldur's Gate isometric formula, although it's not exactly the same. While I do feel the nostalgia as someone who invested hundreds of hours in BG 1 and 2 for the last 20 years, I can also appreciate the tweaks made from a QoL perspective. That being said, I still prefer turn-based games such as Divinity: Original Sin when it comes to combat mechanic. Other than the nostalgia factor, the only positive side I see with realtime with pause is that it allows you to go through easier combats faster and/or to focus more on your favorite characters. But then a game would need a) a good story and b) good characters, which leads me to the next section.


Negative: Storytelling and Worldbuilding

I can't recommend this game because of how awful these points are. The world is the most generic high fantasy medieval setting you can imagine, the storytelling is focused on quantity over quality in regards to the text (both in dialogues and worldbuilding), there's a constant flux of SJW cringe/hot-takes and obvious references to real-world history, namely the Cold War era. I can't get immersed in any aspect of this game's world, story or characters. The characters... Don't get me started. They're as forgettable as it gets, token shells with a clear SJW filter looming over everything. It's awful. I really can't recommend this, as I can't tolerate it any longer myself. Maybe if you're just looking for this style of gameplay and doesn't care about a good story or memorable characters.... But still. Meh. You've been warned.

[b]Pillars of Eternity[/b] is like a good 900-page book that you consume and savor [i]slowly[/i]. A dense and complex block of narrative and details that, through prolonged engagement, builds an intimate and enduring relationship between the reader and the universe, offering a gratifying and immersive experience that will leave you satiated and orphaned at the end, as only a good story can.

For those who hold a special appreciation for fantasy stories that don't reduce their setting to mere juvenile escapism, but rather, employ the freedom of the fantastical in a sophisticated and elegant way to explore themes unconstrained by the mundane and concrete nature of the real world, and to play with questions that inhabit the realm of human imagination and give shape and meaning to many of our beliefs and habits, this is a feast ready to be devoured.

In a standard fantasy attire, with touches of dark humor and philosophical remarks, delivered in a finely balanced manner through beautiful ornate prose and complex characters, often brimming with humanity and laden with traumatic baggage intertwined with the original lore of the world, Pillars works with the unique idea that souls, the primordial essence of all living beings, exist as a concrete fact and not merely as a philosophical abstraction.

And thus, all the ramifications related to this subject become part of the tangible reality of the inhabitants of Eora – Reincarnations, ghosts, supernatural traces in objects and locations, and of course, gods and rituals. Many of them.

The entire story emanates from these concepts. And in the end, it will confront you with slightly unsettling questions about the ultimate purpose of faith and religion, and how it might be to live in a world with or without gods. Imaginary or not. 

Pillars uses it's fantasy to discuss the fantastic. This is a story that demands your attention and patience, and it rewards the player who is curious (and a bit dedicated). And it will present you with interesting questions and doubts around its themes, encouraging, perhaps, one reflection or another about your own worldview.

As if that weren't enough, like any worthy narrative RPG, you're invited to actively and decisively become part of that world, to decide the course and outcomes of its dramas and conflicts. You have the opportunity to bring a part of yourself into the story and transcend your experience of playing in something more personal and meaningful.

Evoking classic CRPGs of the 90s, the masters at Obsidian Software set out to make Pillars an experience familiar to fans of the genre, while also carving out its own place, as if these games had never ceased to be made and this was simply another franchise from those times, retaining and enhancing that same mechanical and narrative complexity (and making everything a bit more refined).

Undoubtedly, they succeeded in this endeavor. I've never met a fan of those games who didn't feel at home here and don't admire these extremely detailed and diverse pre-rendered backgrounds, or wasn't satisfied with the whirlwind of combat micro-management, enriched by deep customization and the possibility of making explosive combos, or by the immense replayability factor that easily covers two or three full playthroughs of the game (which is already quite sizable). The irony of it all is that in this effort to resemble something older, several issues were inherited along with all the good that came with it.

The first, and most serious of the problems, are the endless loading screens, taking 5~10 seconds (perhaps more), even on a standard SSD, to load the environments. Small or large, it doesn't matter. All require loading screens.

The decision to make each house, each floor of a building, each transition within the same city, require one of these screens, always generates that wonderfully inconvenient sensation of dead time. Imagine, as I approached the end of the second act of the story, I encountered a total of 17 loading screens in less than five minutes due to back and forth travel. 

Yes, 17. I'm not exaggerating. And i played the PS4 port first. The loads were even longer.

To be fair, it's not always so aggravated. For the majority of the game, the back and forth is sparse enough not to be too bothersome, but consider this: If a house has two floors and you need to go to the second floor to speak with someone, you have to go through 4 loading screens just to exit the house again.

Some fans of this game dubbed it "Loads of Eternity," alluding to this peculiar feature of the game.

The second point concerns the absurd excess of combat in the game. For those seeking an opportunity to experiment with new builds, it might work, but it's clear that the game prioritizes quantity over quality. The only reason there's so much combat in the game is because there was the same amount of combat in games like Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale. In the end, waves and waves of enemies force you into an exhaustive and repetitive process that makes you no longer want to experiment with your likely fifty spells available. You go into automatic mode and become frustrated because the game doesn't respect the atmosphere of the locations you're exploring.

It's a complex combat. Fast and intense in micro-management. It can be tactically delightful to devise a plan and overcome a challenge that had been troubling you, but most of the time, unless you're playing on very high difficulties, the process becomes repetitive and eventually exhausting.

Lastly, and perhaps less important, because Pillars was a pioneer of this CRPG renaissance, it still lacks various convenient features that you find nowadays, like multiple quicksave slots or skill anticipation for build planning (fortunately, the game allows you to redistribute your points), or clearer explanations about some of the game's systems, among many other small things. If you've played games like Pathfinder: Kingmaker or Divinity: Original Sin 2, you might feel their absence.

Furthermore, I emphasize that these issues are minor and don't significantly detract from the enjoyment I had with the game.  

Doing a methodical exploration of map is immensely satisfying and intuitive. 

The game is drenched in excellent little narratives, exploring various conflicts with dubious morality. 

And even those lore books, which serve to supplement your understanding of the world, become a direct part of the main narrative. When was the last time you saw a game ask you to learn a bit about the world in order to advance a quest?

And you can be genuinely evil in this one. Without that crude, weak, false dichotomy presented by so many rpgs, between the genocide-man and the fantasy Jesus.

It's a very complete package and an extremely competent and well-crafted game, with a good amount of both main and optional content that's highly replayable due to customization options and a variety of outcomes. It offers a good dose of tactical combat open to experimentation, stunning art direction, writing, and music, and a series of delightful extras, like a lore book, a tactical guide, and a short story written by Chris Avellone.

Seriously, even the game's name is great.

It's that kind of story that you know that every time you revisit it, you'll extract something new.

It's worth every penny. And you'll feel like you should have paid more.

Take it with a grain of salt as I've never finished the game and it has been a little while since I last played it.
The game feels like a typical Obsidian game, where they try to do a lot but only accomplish some of that. 
I don't mind reading, normally, but this game sure contains a lot of text. A play of lot of different games and few have ever made me stop as early because of eye strain as this one. 
I prefer Divinity Original Sin in general, as it is a similar game but somehow better executed. DOS also has a narrator say anything that isn't said by any character and uses less text to bring the point accross. 

I'll probably give the game another shot at some point, but I would have to be pretty bored at that time.

Pillars of Eternity is probably the best entry point for anyone who wants to play a Real Time with Pause CRPG, or an Infinity Engine inspired game. The game features fairly modern quest design and QoL concessions, but also maintains the classic feel of games like Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale. There are plenty of options to tailor the difficulty and the UI helpers to your preference.

I will say that the game has a learning curve when it comes to character development and skill usage. If you are unfamiliar with CRPG design from the late 90s and early 2000s, I would recommend you look at a guide to understand the game mechanics and class system. The tutorials and tooltips do a fairly good job of explaining what each stat or ability does, but there are some game mechanics that will need some thought or explanation to fully understand.

Story wise, the game is very engaging and there are a variety of companions to recruit. The quality of the writing may be a bit inconsistent, but overall the narrative accomplishes what it sets out to do. Party members also have memorable stories and most characters are interesting to get to know.

Overall, I'd recommend this game to anyone who enjoys classic CRPGs or would like to get a taste of those style of games.
excellent game. Reheat our love for cRPG of old

Really solid RPG. Good, engaging storyline, varied characters, well voice acted and pretty fair difficulty throughout - challenging, but not impossible. Picked it up in a Steam sale for very little and dumped over 60 hours into it, so I guess that says enough.

Pretty good.

Ok so it took me a bit to decide whether I like this game or not. The reason I bought this game is I heard from a few divinity original sin players that it is a game that offers more "interesting" build/battle dynamics. I noted that and forgot about it lol.

I recently purchased Pathfinder WOTR , prior to getting this game. Pathfinder to me was extremely overwhelming as someone completely blind to the "rulesets of DnD" or whatever. 

I got there eventually, but I found that game to be off putting from a battle mechanic perspective (to me the most important quality in a video game). The story was good and easy to engage with...but the battles felt like they are in the way, I don't actually enjoy coming across or "overcoming" any battles..was rushing to just finish the story. 

Now, I would say this game has kind of the "opposite" problem to me at least in the beginning. I immediately found the battle a lot more exciting. I really feel this game put effort into making that whole "DnD ruleset" enjoyable/palatable on a PC game, and not just copy pasta'd with no thought what would happen. 

They made the classes have iconic obvious flavors from the get go, so you immediately feel you are playing the class you picked. Even though the choices are a lot "less" than Pathfinder. Pathfinder has -for my taste- too much jargon that mechanically is so unsatisfying and inhibiting for an RPG, and it takes you way too long to feel anything special is going on with your run or characters. Not the case here imo.

The classes in this game genuinely feel like they are different. And you feel that a lot of the talents and level up choices are meaningful, easy to understand and you can take multiple build approaches to what would you like your party to be, or what flavor twist would you like the class to have. 

Are all talents/spells good or well balanced...no. There is definitely some "useless traps", but nothing is SUPER misleading, and you don't feel like you really really should be focusing on a specific approach to a build otherwise the game is just completely not fun and a disaster, and retraining is accessible. This is in contrast what turned me off immensely of Pathfinder WOTR personally, the massive amount of misleading do nothing spells and talents.

Now if you are an RPG general fan, I will warn you that this game is real time battle, not turn based at all, in Pathfinder you can pick between the two, here it is only real time. 

The best way that I can think to explain it. Think if you've ever played Age of Empires, Warcraft, Starcraft, or Red Alert. You know games where you manage armies, invade, attack etc.
 
Did you find these games enjoyable??. I personally only enjoyed Warcraft since it had a "magic/fantasy" element to it (not a fan of scifi/or real life games), and you had campaigns with amazing stories and characters, not just army management. 

This game feels very much like that but less "micromanage-y" battle wise (well you are managing 6 fully abled characters though not 100s of mindless roaches) and you have an easy way to slow down/speed up/pause battles, which originally when I would watch that on stream I would feel that looks so weird and not fun as a viewer, but playing it, I love it! The game's graphics are, you know not the best, but very smooth and doesn't feel like it's consuming too much while giving questionable visual experience (Pathfinder lol).

The playstyle/mechanics/abilities I found to be very intuitive, and easy to understand, and accessing information is easy in game, menu layout and item management is easy to utilise...(I can't say the same for pathfinder tbh). To me the battles and character building is 10/10!! Love it, big fan!

Now where I have "shit to say", is the story. Look the story is actually very interesting and "complex", and the characters you play with are really cool and lovable. But...in my experience I just found my self having a hard time getting sucked in into the lore, and gauging or even wanting to know "where is this going". This where Pathfinder definitely wins lol. In Pathfinder I was like ok and then what's gonna happen!!...this game...I struggle with that. To me it's one of those "Thanks, I'll just watch a youtube summary about the whole thing".

Now I admit I am one of them "I hate books" people, and I definitely think this game is very much "read to understand". The voice acting is great but for whatever reason is not consistent. You get random pieces of conversation voice acted and the others not (is that a bug no idea). 

But even when it is working, it's just you get a lot of "talking talking talking but what did you say?" situations I don't know how else to put it, I am not really an aficionado on story telling techniques. All I know is....if it wasn't for the battles I would've been gone, so the opposite of Pathfinder lol just tell me where the are things to kill please, give me the juicy hard battles!

There is a lot of lore terms and figures that get bombarded in your face...eventually I just felt like...ok...I guess I dunno. It's hard to gauge who are the "side pieces" of the story, who are the "main events", I just felt lost tbh. 

I am probably very spoiled with perhaps modern games, or other types of games. And frankly I never ever contemplate reading "novels" for entertainment, If you gift me a book it better be mainly pictures, or has a nice cover to pretend I am sophisticated when I put it somewhere people can see. It's just not my thing...and that's where I wish the game was different. But I realise that is a taste thing...just giving you my take. Plenty of people enjoy the reading aspect of games.

I do think the more I replay the game the better the whole game will drill a place in my heart, including the story. Which I definitely feel this is a game I will enjoy replaying, something I can not say at all about Pathfinder personally, because lore/stories is not why I play a video game. (I keep mentioning that game cause it's the closest to this one).

Anyways glad with my purchase on, got it on sale hehe.

You'll need a guide. This game is not accessible for casual play.

For example, there is a fighter that is willing to join you next to the hanging tree. I missed him the first two times I tried this game, which got me rolled in the next area.

Pillars of Eternity is a game I’ve always wanted to jump into, enjoy an immersive story, and have fun with a classic CRPG. I grew up playing CRPGs over 20 years ago with Baldur’s Gate and Icewind Dale being the two I remember the most. Those games are legendary and I saw a lot of similarities between those games and Pillars of Eternity but unfortunately, this game just didn’t come close to how great those games were.

This game isn’t terrible but it isn’t extraordinary. The soundtrack is solid, the graphics are good, and the customization options for creating your main character are great. The overall art in the game, especially with the loading screens, I also thought was good. The voice acting is decent but at its core, Pillars of Eternity is simply not a fun video game.

The story at first grabbed me and I was genuinely curious to see where it would go. The problem is, after the first 5 hours or so, it got so boring that I started to dread playing this game. I originally played this back in 2020 and stopped because it got too hard and too dull for me. Fast forward almost three full years later and I remember why I stopped playing this because it’s a slogfest to get through the story, areas, dungeons, and everything else in between.

Ultimately, things get beyond frustrating due to the random difficulty of enemies you encounter. One moment, you are one-shotting everything and then the next, mind you, against the exact same kinds of enemies, you get destroyed and have to play again from a loaded save. It’s not balanced at all and there are no explanations as to why it’s like that because it’s all random and super annoying.

Besides the difficulty, characters in my party got stuck everywhere, either against invisible walls or doorframes all the time. The combat is not fun at all since you have to pause and micromanage every single encounter and let me tell you, the “Party AI” is useless. I can’t tell you how many times I’m fighting a group of enemies and besides my main character, the rest of the part is pretty much AFK doing absolutely nothing. Again, you have to pause, click on them all, and specifically attack the enemies you want. Either this is broken or useless but it’s so frustrating to have any genuine fun or a natural flow to the game.

When it comes to items, spells, weapons, etc., 95% of everything you loot is mostly garbage to sell. You’ll find maybe 4-8 things that are worth using and everything else is nonstop duplicates with the exact same properties. It’s terrible and when a game like this has mostly fluff you get from looting, it’s another bad sign that even this part wasn’t well thought out. When you kill a group of enemies, why have they dropped 8 one-handed axes with the exact same properties? Common now.

I couldn’t finish this game fast enough because I just wanted it to be over with already. I have zero desire to do any of the White March expansions because this game is simply not fun at all. It’s an underwhelming CRPG with a hot mess for a main story.

Speaking of which, this is one of the most mundane stories I’ve ever played in a video game and I’ve been gaming for over 35 years now. It’s so bad that it’s forgettable. As I sludged through the final parts of this game just to get my Steam Achievements for at least completing it, I’m excited to move on to something better. I own and will eventually play Pillars of Eternity II: Deadfire but after this experience with the original, it’ll probably be a while before I want to jump into this game’s sequel anytime soon.

I give Pillars of Eternity a 2/5 and would not recommend it to those that love playing CRPGs. You’re better off playing the classics and especially the remastered or enhanced editions of them. Pillars of Eternity is flat-out boring, has combat and audio bugs (voices cutting out, delayed sounds, and it muting entirely), and the characters you meet along the way lack any personality or sense of humor. This game felt like a chore to get through and gaming is supposed to be fun, engaging, and awesome. This game is boring, tedious, and frustrating. It’s a shame, I really wanted to enjoy this but I honestly feel it’s one of those overhyped games that once you get into it and after the first few hours, you’ll see how truly bad it is.
Excellent

After playing this for a few hundred hours, I can say for certain this is a masterpiece. Everything about this game is fantastic; the story, voice acting, gameplay, environments, etc. There is a reason this game resurrected the CRPG genre.

Great CRPG, its nice to see these coming back.  I think the rise of them is probably thanks to this game, but I didn't do any research on that.  Anyway, I recommend Pillars.  Good writing, fun system.
This game is amazing!
If you like Baulders Gate you will like this game. The art is fantastic and voice acting draws you in.  The choices in races and classes are interesting, especially the background portion.
Great game,  following the tradition of giants like Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale.

Pillars of eternity is a slick looking retro styled rpg, it’s appealing on the surface but for me there wasn’t enough going on under the hood.
I personally am not a fan of isometric rpg combat that happens in real time, I would do much prefer turn based combat bc the combat in this game is a bewildering clusterfuck where you are pausing and issuing orders that characters often don’t follow. Also bc of the zoomed out perspective and how close characters stand to each other, it’s very difficult to tell what’s going on. Many times, I would have no idea what was going on and could only tell by looking at the health bars of my characters.
The other big issue is the story, I really found it confusing and uninteresting with a lot of very wordy passages that were well-written but lack personality. By contrast, I’m playing Avernum right now which has a lot of words but the story is so much more engaging. And despite having a lot of freedom in many of the side quests it didn’t feel in the overall quest I was allowed to decide anything.
A better CRPG than Baldur's Gate 3.... And this thing came out 8 years ago!
My favorite isometric RPG ever, on par with Baldur's Gate. I love it: the atmosphere, characters, battles. Everything is just perfect.

Pillars is a great homage to CRPG's of old, with the main inspiration obviously being Baldur's Gate.
I'm not a big fan of RTWP combat, but Pillars kept me entertained throughout. Where Baldur's Gate is now very old and showing it's age, Pillars has many quality of life improvements to make it feel far more modern and accessible to players. I will warn you this game is text HEAVY and will require a lot of reading if you want to enjoy the story. There are a lot of moral gray areas and choices to make. Although I don't think this is one of the best rpg's ever made, I do think it's a really good one. It's just the right length and just the right amount of content to not overstay its welcome - though I found the story not nearly as interesting as many other RPG's out there. This game did send my pc into a BSOD one time.. that was weird.. Overall I would highly recommend this to any fan of the first 2 Baldur's Gate games or any CRPG fan. This is a love letter to rpg's of old and if you haven't played something like it before - give it a try.

I have not played many CRPGs, and if you are like me, I would recommend easing into the mechanics by playing on a lower difficulty and use the story characters your first time through.

Obsidian has done it again. Fantastic story-writing, gameplay that's difficult but alluring enough that you actually want to progress just to be able to go back and fight these harder battles, and an actually enjoyable camp-based (i.e. "stronghold" in this game) management minigame. 

The only downside: this game isn't the most optimized. I'm rocking a Raedon RX 7900 XTX and i7-3700K yet I get on average 110-130 FPS with settings not even completely maxed out on a game that looks like it's from the last 2000s. Take this info with a grain of salt.

Highly recommend if on sale, though. Get the Definitive Edition.

Played it for an hour, and frankly it's boring. Tiny characters fighting, so small that you cannot see what they are doing or who they are doing it to. Awkward movement controls, you have to manually recenter when the characters move near the edge of the screen. Not fun.

... That was my initial reaction. I came back to the game and completed it. A good story, some very interesting spells, and many compelling quests.

I deleted that bloody Divinity - Original Sin 3 crap from my account today.
Then I came back to give POE a recommendation and I'll definitely buy Avowed.

I think I'm about 2/3 of the way through the game.  Some of the classes feel fantastic, others feel like they need more buttons to press.  Combat is fun as long as you don't get aoe CC'd or walk into a fight you're not prepared for (sometimes you can't tell).  There's some issues with the pathfinding which sometimes make the combat janky.

Pillars of Eternity is a RPG is eager to show off its writing and its world, while showing little regard for the impatient and for the folks who don't have a passion for reading.
And the writing of PoE is brutal, by using 20 words when 8 would suffice. At its best, it is very well to convey messages and ideas, bringing characters and their philosophies to life. But at its worst, it actually undermines its own story. Sometimes when it wants to reveal essential plot points, these can easily be drowned under its own flood of dialogues and descriptions. Saying so much at once, the supposed twist is unrecognizable. Admittedly, these moments are rather rare in the entirety of the game, but they do exist, so one has to accept to be frustrated and stay faithful. Or not(later on that).

The music of the game is also quite atmospheric in the right moments, though, I wouldn't say it is somewhat recognizable outside of the game. It does its job, and delivers a pleasant experience without to disappoint, but also without leaving any impact on you for the long run.

The biggest warning I can share on this game are its technical issues-
I am not talking about bugs(not denying there are any, but I havent really encountered any which harmed the gaming experience), no, it is the actual loading screens in the second half of the game. At a certain point, the loading screens start reaching the 20 till 30 seconds mark, and only get longer at this point(until a whole minute). Which includes the loading screens when entering a house, or just entering a closed room or another floor. It harms the experience immensely, because games like PoE live of traveling around and visiting settlements, yet when hitting the endgame, just looking around into buildings can lead to frustration because you've wasted minutes entering a room, which only houses a single nameless NPC. When I've beat the game, I learned that I missed content which I wished I've seen it for myself, but at that point, I've lost all desire to look around in the new town and just moved on, minimizing my explorations on what was necessary. 
I recommend to look for mods which might deal with that issue. I learned about those in hindsight, and wish I've added them early on in my playthrough.

For these technical issue, I'll take a whole point from the score, because even if the writing and pacing of the story has flaws(there are sections of the game, which make it unclear what exactly the main story is supposed to be), it is nonetheless a fun adventure. The gameplay works and grants many ways to overcome encounters, both on the field and in dialogues.
It is a very solid RPG, and I am sure, many people had fun with it, and many more will end up having fun with it. But anyone who gave up on it, because waiting for minutes to just enter a house was just too much of a slog, is justified in their ire.

A very solid RPG with an equally solid fantasy world, presenting a story which utilized the setting to its fullest, even if it is overwritten at times.
Harmed by its own tech, sadly.
I give it a 7/10.
(important note: When buying the game, the White March DLC is a must. In its entirety, it is a focussed miniature of the whole game, with a tighter story and improved pacing, with many great moments of mystery and adventure. Giving the vanilla game another point to the score[ie, without the DLC PoE would have ended with just 6/10 instead].)
Good lore, nice RtwP battle mechanics, cool classes abilities and spells, interesting companions. But gets easier with progress even on highest difficulty which is not optimal.

Fun classic crpg, the combat takes a while getting used to since it's a different take than classic d&d rules but once you get a grasp on it it's pretty intuitive.  Story and world-building is well written.

This is one of these games I WANT to like, praise and recommend. But just can't.
Overall, this game is masterfully written, well voiced and more than competently designed. It feels like a true successor of the Classical RPG Genre, and it deserves credit for how it stays true to its roots.

But...
There's a few things that hamper it along the way, which take away from so much of the good things that the game does. And most of it, comes in the form of the combat system, and how it is either too fast, or too slow. Too difficult, or too easy. Too simple, or too obscure.

My main gripe would be with the difficulty, which seems erratic. One moment you are one-hitting enemies that explode in gore with basic attacks. The next moment there's this strange floating nondescript blob that zaps your entire party to an inch from death, and almost can't be scratched. I understand there are mechanics, and some enemies have resistances and weaknesses etc... but the game is tremendously bad in giving you this feedback.

Some other encounters are then horribly annoying with enemies just ignoring your tanks' taunts, and taking a long route, just to swarm your casters. I get that the "Monsters know what they're doing"-argument is sound and fair, but if the game doesn't give you the tools to crowd-control effectively, it seems kind of unfair.

Other encounters just stun-lock, charm and knock-down multiple party members, making the fight ridiculously long, difficult and drawn out. When it's basically built in as a speedbump-encounter on the way to a bossfight. Ironically, said bossfight, a blind badger with a wet herring for a main weapon, could beat.

At one point, the game seems to actively prod you into the direction of fighting a pitched battle with your underlings and allies against a pretender. I gained a few more levels between then and the actual battle, using my own character and some of the NPC's that the game offers. When I fought the battle, I won by the skin of my teeth. If I had taken the battle when the game seemed to "want" me to fight it, I'd have had no chance of winning.

The game also does this weird thing with a lot of weapons being fairly indistinct from each other, and frankly, I find it hard to distinguish between multiple of the unique, named weapons. Which is a shame, because the game seems set to shower you in gear drops and unique, named gear.

All in all, I can't really recommend this game over some of the more modern competitors at full price. Maybe for €10?...
And even then, i'd play it on the "story mode" or "scenic" difficulty, just to enjoy the story, the well-written characters and the thought-out lore-rich world.

If what I have just described is 100% your thing, then by all means, take that as an endorsement.

It's ok. I'd give it a neutral rating if I could. The story is mind-blowingly confusing as they throw so much at you so fast and it's all text-based so if you accidentally press spacebar on accident huge portions of the story just vanish, the stronghold seemed so interesting at first until you actually try to use it, then it's kinda like 'Why did they even add this to the game, I'm never close enough to it to actually use it' No matter your security score you can lose all of your taxes to bandits so there's barely any point to even mess with the stronghold. I was just having a blast exploring things and killing everyone that even looked at me funny.

If you can get it on sale go for it, get some mods to make the classes/weapons more balanced or go with 1 pally 5 wizards and just nuke everything that moves to ash.

Great game! I'm a big fan of the balance and interesting stats that provide a utility rare in other Western CRPGs that follow these same formulas. If you've heard about this game having a bland story you've been sorely mistaken, the writing is fun (and very dark) albeit a bit verbose.

I enjoyed my time with this game much better than the first two Baldur's Gate games, I wish I had played this sooner. Something to note is that this game was held back by Baldur's Gate fans who wanted it and its RTWP mess yet again. To quote the director:
[quote]Honestly, I have to say it felt like the most compromised games I worked on were Pillars of Eternity 1 and 2[...] I (had) a bunch of new ideas for how differently I would do it if I were doing it on my own[...] But they were crowdfunded games and the audience was like, 'No, we want D&D, we want exactly the same experience as the Infinity Engine games.'[/quote]

good game
good game, amazing writing, replayed so I'm refreshed for Deadfire, got into the game again, played like 40 hours

this was a frustrating game to play because it had enough potential to keep me playing until the end, but it just hit me with disappointment after disappointment.

good:
1. interesting setting and concepts
2. if you like heady, philosophical writing there's a lot of neat stuff here

bad:
1. the nihilism gets old really fast
this game is overwhelmingly cynical and nihilistic. it's suffocating.

everyone is either distant and cryptic, or glib and cynical, or just cruel. there is no tenderness anywhere despite the core conflict revolving around people losing their children. this doesn't make the writing more thoughtful, more objective, or more mature. I think the overwhelming pessimism makes it melodramatic and cheap.

the grieving mother is a fantastic exception to this, and i think she's an incredible party member with a criminally small part to play in the overall game. her cryptic and detached attitude actually works for the character because of the tenderness in her story. it's a breath of fresh air because it's the game FINALLY giving you a window into the tragedy of the hollowborn. you get to see how sacred a happy and healthy childbirth is in Eora and how horrible the new reality is in comparison.

2. underwhelming character writing in a setting that has such interesting potential for it

you have incredible, nearly perfect empathy but 99% of the time you're using it to be the world's most mediocre detective. "who killed this guy? which one of you is lying?" who gives a shit!! i want to know what makes the big bad head of the crime family feel warm inside, or what small vices the strict monk secretly allows himself, or to tell the innkeep that the troublesome customer is secretly in love with him.

everything is basically just convincing someone to let you help them, you go do their stupid objective, you meet someone, and you choose to spare or kill someone, and someone thanks you and apologizes and says they were wrong about you and you're actually the second coming of jesus. it gets old.

3. the ai is an eldritch horror designed to give you nightmares. it cannot be trusted
- unless you micromanage your guys they will fail to path to an enemy and just afk because they don't understand how to take a slightly longer but more open path to a destination
- charms are stupidly strong. why does sagani instantly shoot itumaak in the head when someone casts a charm on him? why does raedric's entire court instantly cave his skull in when i cast whispers of treason on him? why does everyone swap their active weapon set and then forget what kind of weapon they're supposed to be using when the charm ends?
- the ai changes targets too much on Aggressive, and not enough on any other setting. focusing down a caster requires babysitting all of your damage dealers no matter what because they can't be trusted with just an A-click on the enemy

4. everything costs too much until you suddenly have infinite money
you cant afford a decent sword at the beginning, and by the end you have way more money than you could ever know what to do with because nothing you can buy is good enough to use. the only things I bought were prybars, grappling hooks, chisels, lockpicks, and camping supplies.

5. the game has a "fast mode", but you have to walk around in slow mode (scouting) everywhere to see traps and secrets, so they cancel each other out

6. party members having desynced xp is annoying

7. the ui is clunky as all hell

8. the audio is bugged and random sounds are cut off or way too loud

9. way too many combat encounters. on normal difficulty, my party was strong enough to brute force combat without too much micromanagement in the last 10ish hours, but it was still tedious.
Lots of play-ability. Came back to play through a 2nd time after finishing Pillars II.

Pillars Of Eternity is an isometric RPG developed by Obsidian that takes heavy inspiration from classic RPGs, most notably the games made on the infinity engine (Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, and Planescape Torment). Despite its heavy influence, Pillars is quite a different kind of game with its own identity. It doesn't use the D&D licence and thus has its own set of rules, spells, and an entirely original yet somewhat traditional feeling fantasy world. 

One of this games biggest strengths but also one of its biggest weaknesses in my opinion is this game's massive amount of lore and world building. Obsidian created such a rich and huge world with this game and it does its best to try to show and explain all the elements and facets of it throughout the experience. Characters that you talk to will be constantly referencing things about the world or discussing certain things, many of which you probably don't know about or have forgotten about because it was mentioned hours ago from another dialogue with some other npc or was written in a book that you probably didn't read or just skimmed through. Due to this game's shear amount of world building it throws at you from the very beginning it is really easy to feel lost and at a certain point in the game I just didn't care any more. 

The main plot itself is very interesting and the game ties the main protagonist (the player) and the main antagonist together very well. Without spoiling anything I will just say the plot is good but like the rest of this game's world building, it can get confusing and if your not paying very close attention you can lose the plot pretty easily. One main criticism of the plot I have is that the main antagonist does not appear or is even mentioned that much through the whole story. As a result, the game just feels like I am going from one location to the next with no real purpose or goal other than for the sake of exploring and meeting new people for quests. Games like Baldur's Gate and its sequel (this game's main influences) had very strong yet simple plots with clear antagonists that you either saw regularly through the story or had a main impact on the world so they were never forgotten. 

For example, Sarevok in BG1 approaches the PC at the very beginning and commits a brutal act. Then what follows is the PC tracking him down by killing his personal guards one by one as they get closer to reaching the main city of Baldur's Gate. In BG2, the PC is once again faced against the antagonist at the very beginning where they must escape his dungeon. Afterwards Irenicus kidnaps one of your closest friends and tortures them while also assaulting the PC in there sleep with visions throughout the story. These are both good examples of how to have a compelling villain that the character has motivation to take down while also giving the villain a constant reminding presence in the world. 
Pillars on the other hand doesn't introduce the villain in the beginning. It tries to keep the main plot and purpose of your PC vague for as long as it can get away with, which makes it really hard to care or get invested in the story at the start of the game. It's honestly hard to even recall what happens during the story or when exactly the main antagonist is introduced because the main plot is not only not very memorable but just really convoluted and hard to follow when there is so much other stuff going on in Pillars and the important story bits are only fed to you little by little throughout the game.

Pillars can also be overly descriptive during dialogues with npcs by having to describe everything they are doing and what they look like down to each wrinkle on their forehead. Okay maybe its not that descriptive but it does feel like a bit much and can get really graining on you after a while. This is a long game especially with the DLC and having to read through paragraph after paragraph of lore dumps or descriptions of what the npcs are doing during dialogue can get a bit boring. Sorry I hate to say it but it is true. The thing is in Planescape Torment, for example, it also had very descriptive dialogue and also a huge world and lore that it had to explain to the player, but I feel like it was done much better in that game then in Pillars. It helped that the world it was set in was so unique and otherworldly that I was just craving to read everything I could about it. Also Planescape didn't out stay its welcome. It was well paced and not an overly long experience. Planescape took me about 45-50 hours to complete while Pillars plus its 2 DLCs took me about 92 hours. So not only was I just not engrossed enough in Pillar's world like I was with Planescape, the game was way longer and felt overall very slow paced. 

To wrap up this review I want to say that They did a phenomenal job with the artwork in this game and the 2D backgrounds look absolutely beautiful. The combat is also very smooth and fun but definitely doesn't have that over the top insanity that BG2 provides with its overpowered spells and awesome demonic enemies. Pillars is definitely a lot more balanced and toned down compared to Baldur's Gate and classic D&D. In conclusion I still recommend Pillars Of Eternity because I feel like the foundations of this game are really solid and the world design is amazing. The classic Obsidian and Black Isle writing is there but it is intertwined with a lot of overly descriptive flavor text that you may love or hate. This is also a true and pure Role Playing Game which is saying a lot in an era where less real RPGs are made anymore. 
I look forward to playing its sequel which I hear is even better than the first one, and also the upcoming Avowed which will take place in Eora.
7/10 - Good setting and graphics, decent gameplay, but the story is boring and uninteresting.

If you are more interested in story telling, meaningful companions, world building, and decision making, I would recommend Pillars. Both are great games with something different to offer.

" A Modern Masterpiece of Classic RPG Brilliance"

Pillars of Eternity is a modern-day gem that pays homage to the golden age of classic RPGs while simultaneously carving its path as an unforgettable adventure. Developed by Obsidian Entertainment, this game is a love letter to fans of deep storytelling, complex characters, and strategic gameplay, and it stands as a shining example of the genre's potential.

One of the game's most outstanding features is its gripping narrative. From the very beginning, you'll find yourself captivated by a richly woven tale, filled with political intrigue, moral dilemmas, and mystical phenomena. The depth of lore is astounding, and the writing is top-notch, immersing players in a world brimming with history, myths, and unique cultures. Every decision you make, big or small, can have far-reaching consequences, and the weight of your choices adds a layer of realism to the game's immersive storytelling.

The characters in Pillars of Eternity are a true testament to Obsidian's craftsmanship. Each companion is beautifully fleshed out, with personal quests, beliefs, and motivations that evolve throughout the journey. Interacting with them not only strengthens your connection to the story but also provides insights into their individual struggles and growth. The party dynamics are nuanced and engaging, making each member feel indispensable in your quest to save the world.

Gameplay in Pillars of Eternity is a delightful blend of old-school RPG mechanics and modern innovations. The real-time with pause combat system allows for strategic planning, enabling you to pause the action, issue commands, and watch your tactics unfold in glorious detail. Customizable character classes and a diverse array of abilities provide ample opportunities to tailor your party to suit your preferred playstyle.

The world design is masterfully crafted, with hand-painted environments that evoke a sense of wonder and discovery. Exploring the game's intricately designed locales is a joy, and the attention to detail is evident in every nook and cranny. Whether you're venturing into ancient ruins, traversing rugged wilderness, or navigating treacherous dungeons, you'll find yourself constantly drawn into the world of Eora.

While the game is a triumph in many regards, some players may find the learning curve steep, especially for those new to the genre. Understanding the nuances of character development and the game's deep mechanics may take time, but the effort is well worth it for the rich and rewarding experience that awaits.

In conclusion, Pillars of Eternity stands tall as a modern masterpiece of classic RPG brilliance. With its compelling narrative, unforgettable characters, and strategic gameplay, it sets a new standard for immersive storytelling and role-playing excellence. Whether you're a die-hard fan of old-school RPGs or a newcomer seeking a deep and captivating adventure, Pillars of Eternity promises a journey that will leave a lasting impression on your gaming soul.
Yes

This game has a number of story threads that could be interesting and engaging, but the writers seem to have a very limited set of quest implementation "recipes" and "Surprise! Meatgrinder!" is on the menu far too often.  This might not have been as much of a problem if the game allowed effective retreats from combat, or gave some feedback prior to the meatgrinder that there was a meatgrinder coming, or gave some indication afterward of "Remember that meatgrinder you had to give up on four whole character levels ago?  It's now within your capability.", but it does none of these things.  You have to blunder into the deathtrap and either die or realize you've got no chance, then load a save you made from before blundering into it and turn around with no in-character reason or explanation.  And then come back every so often to find out if you can handle it yet.

I honestly don't know if the story ends in a satisfying way.  I don't know how things get resolved.  And I'm never going to, because the story isn't engaging enough, early enough, to justify continuing to get murdered repeatedly because there's no difficulty feedback and no retreat.  That's something you expect on elevated difficulty settings, on subsequent playthroughs.  It's not appropriate, it's not fun, on below-default difficulty before someone's ever seen the story.

A good and extremely well written game marred by schizophrenic and at times outright unfair difficulty which turns the late game and the expansions into a joyless, miserable slog. Enemies will come in vast swarms that envelop your party and hit you with endless status effects to constantly paralyse, petrify, knock down or terrify your party members, making combat confusing and incredibly annoying. I found myself playing the same obnoxious encounters over and over again, and I got through them only to have my max level party repeatedly one shot by certain bosses.  I'm not saying that the difficulty is insurmountable, I'm saying it's frustrating and tedious and that I stopped enjoying the game a good ten hours before I stopped playing. I kept hoping it would get better, but I just got more miserable, and I honestly cannot work up the motivation to actually finish. I don't think it's a bad game, the world is rich, the art is nice and the mechanics are good, but the latter half of it is such a joyless experience I couldn't finish it and I can't in good faith recommend it.

[h1] Apathy is death [/h1] 

And sadly apathy is what I felt throughout the entire game.  Every chapter was a slog, every event was underwhelming, and every fight felt sluggish and boring. 

I didn't care for the main story or the world-building. They were all presented in the most boring way possible. Companions felt like sheep following a shepherd; I never felt they oppose me or bring an argument worth debating. 

I didn't care for the gods or factions; they all seemed shoved into the world. Interacting with them was either fetch me this or kill me that. Or Find me this or solve me that. Without connecting a personal motive. 
I swear, every time I entered a city or a big place with multiple NPC's I made a gigantic sigh. This is not surprising seeing how low the percentage of completing this game is. The game isn't designed in an engaging way to incentivise the player to do quests.   

But what bugs me is the fact Obsidian created Tyranny, FNV, and SWKotOP which had an amazing story and world-building. I felt 100x more immersed and amused by them instead of POE.  

For context, I have finished both POE 1&2. Both of them have very weak narratives and sluggish pacing. And I don't understand why. POE has very interesting concepts and Ideas, yet they fail to bring any of them in an interesting way that would keep me engaged. I could have sworn that each time I was engaging in dialogue it would always be an endless amount of exposition. 

2/5

Pretty similar in game play to the Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale games and has a decent story too :)  In that one area it's not bad.  However I must warn you that this game really isn't noob friendly.  If you really want a challenge I'd would recommend it though.  This game differs from other rpgs in that character health pools are divided into health and endurance. Character's can only regain the health portion through rest and their health is 5 times a large as endurance.  When a character's endurance reaches zero they are knocked out and can't do anything until that battle is over.  This happens constantly in battles so you are forced to pause the game every 5 seconds or so in them if you want to win the tougher ones.  Also you don't always get xp from killing enemies :P.  The permanent death in this game if your health reaches zero along with being unable to heal health outside of resting or a few very limited abilities makes it a bit annoying as it forces you to rest a lot.  Iv'e noticed as Iv'e played a bit more that thankfully, enemies do seem to ignore your knocked out party members "at least so far".  Also try to get DR bypass weapons of 5 or better as soon as you can "makes killing mobs so much easier :)".  So really the difficulty with the low endurance seems to be the biggest issue Iv'e encountered.  I'm still undecided on the stronghold although I have read you can skip it if you want :)  I had a lower opinion of the game earlier but now I'm on the fence if the game is worth it.

God-S tier crpg

Pillars of Eternity is a weird case. It certainly gets a lot of praise, and if you enjoy old-school isometric crpgs, then it will certainly catch your eye at some point, some might even credit it with starting the current 'golden era of RPG's' we are currently living it. If this 'golden era' is happening right now it's up to debate, what is not up for the debate is that PoE is regarded by many as a new classic in the genre.
I know a lot of people who have never seen 'The Godfather', but if I were to ask them to name me 5 'masterpieces of cinema' regardless of their personal preferences, then certainly Copolla's movie would figure in tha list. It's only natural that we are drawn to share the general consensus, after all, if everyone agrees about something, it must be true, right?
Well, I got duped by the general consensus into thinking PoE was a great game. It's not a great game but it's certainly the corpse of one. It looks like a great game, it talks like one, it waves its hands, it might even do a little dance for you, but upon further examination all you see is the rotten flesh of a zombie.
The character development and scenario construction fail to captivate, as does the central conflict. Instead of immersing yourself in a vivid and engaging world, you find yourself merely observing a robotic narrative of fabricated plot. 
PoE is always trying to connect what made the good RPG's of the past great with what modern audiences would want whilist still faling for the traps of it's own making. PoE main problem is not it's combat or it's core mechanics, they are all prety serviceable and that's the problem. Nothing about it is exceptional or even note-worthy.  A game made with no passion, it seems. Everything from the mechanics, uninspired world and stats is simply forgettable.  
The way it just spits blatant exposition at you in EVERY single line of dialog is extremely annoying. It makes the whole game feel like like reading a wikipedia article.

This game is a complete waste of time and I regret buying it.
