[i]Pillars of Eternity[/i] is an isometric RPG title developed by Obsidian Entertainment. You begin your journey as an ordinary member of a caravan travelling to the town of Gilded Vale, for the reasons of your choice, but this quickly changes as the unfolding events connect you to the world of spirits. Troubled with visions of a dark future and mysterious past, you set off to find the answers to a terrifying curse, only to find more questions.

[b]THE GOOD[/b][list]
[*] I’m a sucker for a good story and [i]Pillars of Eternity[/i] delivers exactly that, with the plot revolving around sinister happenings in the region of Dyrwood that cause tragic consequences for all of its denizens. While intrigues between the gods and mortals may be a common trope in RPG genre, here it’s expanded on by the lore that’s exceptionally rich and original. The story may not be the easiest to get a full grasp on, but the superb focus on lore and plot presentation makes it absolutely special. There’s also tons of extra information about the world, its history and mystical forces that drive it, for those interested in fuller immersion.
[*] At first I was sceptical of a story DLC split into two parts, but then it turned out it was completely unfounded. Don’t be fooled by the shared title ([i]The White March[/i]) – both DLCs bring plenty of different gameplay extras. Part 1 adds a new region to explore, a storyline of an abandoned forge able to shape the world and a couple of mechanical improvements. Part 2 expands on that, as well as grants access to a couple of high-level challenges. Overall, a very strong (and long) addition, definitely worth its price. The only caveat I have is that the storyline isn’t well matched with the main game and can provide too much distraction from, you know, actually saving the world. Maybe it’s not that important after all?
[*] There’s so much stuff to do in the game you’ll have spent dozens of hours before you’re finished. An incredible asset of Pillars of Eternity is that no quest seems unsubstantial, not even the most trivial task feels forcefully shoved into the game to artificially bloat it, and your hero always feels to exist in the middle of affairs of great importance. And some of these really are important, as your choices craft your further experience with people you meet, organisations of dubious intents and events that progress your way to an inevitable clash with the ultimate evil.
[*] And speaking of choices, the game emphasises their significance through the system of reputation and personality traits, a multivariate approach to shaping the world’s responses to your actions. Each region and major organisation has its own view on your hero through separate reputation stats, allowing you to be the saviour and the villain at the same time, depending on your roleplaying needs. And consequences of treading your path reach beyond just that with the personality trait scores that increase purely based on your decisions. Gaining some traits open new options for resolving quests or dialoguing and may as well make some things harder if your interlocutor doesn’t fancy you being too honest or cruel.
[*] The classes are the shining beacon of mechanical diversity of the game. Even the RPG usuals such as the warrior or the wizard aren’t just a copy-paste of what you see in an average representative of the genre, gaining multiplicity of advancement perks and options that may lean their progress towards a satisfactorily different playstyle if that’s what you want. And then you have the bard with their chants you get to craft depending on what passive boons you need at the moment, only to strike with powerful magic once you’ve sung enough, the cipher that uses psychic abilities to easily break through the enemy’s defences, or the monk whose powers rely on getting their cheeks clapped during a fight. If you’re in for somewhat expansive mechanics that at the same time aren’t overwhelming, your playthrough may get a couple of more hours spent on checking out the available options.
[*] The stronghold is such a cool base of operations it actually needs its own point on this list. Not only you get to bring back its greatness with various upgrades, but you also get a couple of different “filler” types of content, like deciding the fates of people in the area, extra side quests for your inactive companions or getting ingredients for your alchemical shenanigans. It’s a very interesting way of expanding the game’s lore and strengthening the immersion.
[*] A lot of thought was put into the sonic presentation of the game. The music hauntingly fills the atmosphere of events and places together with thoroughly mastered sound effects, and voice actors clearly committed to their jobs as well.
[*] It’s a game tailored for a wide range of RPG fans out there. Whether you’re a casual player, a tactical mastermind or anyone in between, there’s enough gameplay settings for you to craft your ideal experience. Need an extra safeguard when your companion is about to die? No problem. Want to disable tooltips to seep more realism into your game? Sure thing. Feel like getting ultimately challenged? Try the Path of the Damned mode (and regret later!). Or go the other way around and explore the world (almost) freely with the Story Time difficulty.[/list]

[b]THE SO-SO[/b][list]
[*] There’s a good deal of dialogue option to choose from and some of them bear great importance and equally great consequences, but too many are hidden behind ridiculous stat requirements that feel almost unreachable at the current level of progress. Sometimes you can’t get back to the core of a discussion after picking an option that may have sounded completely neutral, like an innocent question before digging deeper into the topic. In a way it’s a method of preventing your hero from becoming an all-knowing Mary Sue – which is a good thing – but then you may be left with a feeling that they’re actually quite dumb for not having come up with an idea that seemed pretty obvious, but it’s locked behind a stat requirement. Also screw you, Resolve, for almost being a must pick in this department.
[*] There’s many equipment options to fit into your desired playstyle and those more gifted in figuring out mechanical details may feel at home with the ability to switch weapon sets depending on the enemy’s armour type and whatnot, but to me it all lacks the oomph. There’s a couple of powerful items you need to upgrade by meeting certain conditions (which is an interesting concept), but everything else feels rather samey. It’s not entirely bad, because you don’t need to push for the greatest rewards in order to enjoy the game, but at the same time you don’t even have to look at your inventory screen after a certain point.[/list]

[b]THE BAD[/b][list]
[*] Pathfinding is just dire. The characters seem to take up more space than what’s shown on the screen, or maybe they’re just all stupid, who knows. What I definitely know, though, is that multiple encounters ended up much worse than they could have purely because my companions struggled to move their pixel bodies to designated points, even though they really shouldn’t. If there’s two tips I can give you, one is “avoid fighting in corridors, even if they seem wide enough”…
[*] …and the other one is “practice your patience”, because that’s what’s going to be strained during loading screens. The game just loads forever. Maybe that’s the “eternity” part of the title, since I actually never figured that one out.[/list]

[b]OVERALL[/b]
[i]Pillars of Eternity[/i] takes what’s best in RPG genre and incorporates it into a unique universe. It’s packed with a really great plot, interesting events and memorable characters, as well as fun mechanics that are void of major holes. For me it was definitely more of a story-driven game than one that shines bright with its gameplay, but nonetheless it is without a doubt a worthy successor to the classics like [i]Baldur’s Gate[/i].

Pillars of Eternity offers a strategic and immersive gameplay experience that goes beyond typical hack-and-slash mechanics. With a focus on tactical combat, character abilities, and careful planning, the game provides a refreshing challenge for players. This review will delve into the strategic elements, immersive world, and overall recommendation for Pillars of Eternity.

Review:
Pillars of Eternity sets itself apart from run-of-the-mill hack-and-slash games by emphasizing strategic gameplay and thoughtful decision-making. Each battle requires careful consideration of ally positioning, abilities, and resources such as health and endurance. Ignoring these factors can lead to swift defeat, compelling players to strategize, plan their moves ahead, and utilize stealth to position themselves advantageously.

The game's combat mechanics demand strategic thinking and a proactive approach. Players must analyze the number of enemies, their strengths, and weaknesses, and devise a battle plan accordingly. This level of depth and tactical engagement adds a layer of immersion and challenge that sets Pillars of Eternity apart from its counterparts.

Beyond the strategic combat, Pillars of Eternity offers an immersive world filled with rich lore and captivating storytelling. The game presents players with an intricate web of relationships, political intrigue, and moral dilemmas. Exploring the game's vast and well-crafted world unveils a narrative tapestry that keeps players engaged and invested in the outcome.

While the learning curve may be steep initially, with abundant lore and complex gameplay systems, the effort is well worth it. Pillars of Eternity rewards players who invest time and effort into understanding its mechanics and lore, offering a deeply satisfying and fulfilling experience.

Conclusion:
Pillars of Eternity provides a refreshing departure from typical hack-and-slash games, emphasizing strategic combat, thoughtful planning, and immersive storytelling. The game's emphasis on tactical decision-making, ally positioning, and resource management adds depth and challenge to every battle. With its intricate world and captivating narrative, Pillars of Eternity offers an engaging and immersive experience for players willing to embrace its strategic gameplay mechanics. For those seeking a game that requires careful planning and strategic thinking, Pillars of Eternity comes highly recommended.

I'll just go ahead and say this: the game's great. So why is this a negative review?

Because I hate, HATE real time with pause option with a burning passion. I cannot stress how much I hate this mechanic. 

The very nature of combat in tabletop RPGs start with an initiative roll that determines the action TURN order and you do things when it's your TURN. Every TURN has a set amount of action + movement allowance that forms your strategy. So, if I'm making an isometric RPG that has the feel of a tabletop adventure game, which combat scheme should I follow?

The answer really isn't real-time baby boo. 

"Baldur's Gate did it" isn't a valid argument either. There was a time in gaming where we didn't have f-ing mouse look, and look where we are now. Try playing Might and Magic 6 without all the modern additions and then try playing it with fan-made unofficial patches and you tell me that the classic schemes rock and we should never change anything.

Maybe this is because I'm salty but look at my played time. I tried to play this game literally 5 times but every single time I have to quit because either a surprise combat or some shit starts with my characters being placed randomly (instead of following the party order that I define) or pathfinding of my companions stuck somewhere cause they cannot comprehend the apparent 200 IQ complexity way of thinking that is moving AROUND the thing standing in front of you.

Which wouldn't be a problem if I was taking turns playing the game.

Look, as I said the game's good. The game's setting is really unique, the art style is phenomenal and a new setting in RPG is always appreciated. If you'd play a game with these no matter how the gameplay feels, go for it. I'll try to give it one more shot on, I don't know maybe in story mode with preferably no combat whatsoever and just play it like a walking sim or something.

I don't usually have general statements for anything in gaming but I think I finally found the hill I'd die on: real time RPGs fucking sucks donkey dick. I really liked Neverwinter Nights and Icewind Dale so I don't know maybe I'm getting older for this shit or maybe it's the change in the ruleset. Whatever it is, I'm so glad games like Pathfinder and Divinity: Original Sin exist.

Pillars is a game that can't compete with its contemporaries. It is graphically minimal, but somehow runs more poorly than the aesthetically beautiful Divinity 2, which is the superior choice if you're looking for a classic CRPG (it also has optional multiplayer). The companions are all poorly optimized and better replaced by adventurers you can create for yourself, and the story itself is bloated with boring lore that limits instead of inspires. I struggled to create characters that felt like they made sense in this world. Not to mention the constraints of classes; if you want to make any interesting builds, forget it. This game is so heavily based around a meta it leaves little room to experiment. If you're looking to have a good time, try Divinity. If you're a fun-hating masochist, this game is for you.

Sometimes I wonder to myself why do i like these kind of CRPG games, having played and loved titles like Baldur's Gate and Dragon Age... and I came to a conclusion that story and characters matter immensely to me.

PoE has some-how interesting characters but they lack development or interactions. There are no banters between companions, and they seldom say anything or react to anything (either in plots or decisions i made), they are there just for the sake of 'because the main character needs companions' (except Grieving Mother perhaps, she has a complete story-arc compared to others). This irks me a lot and greatly diminishes my enjoyment .

As for the story-telling, I can see what the writer was trying to do, and it all came to a climax when I entered that cavern altar and appeased to the Gods. But this climax came too late and took too much to build (you need to read all the books concerning the Gods to fully grasp the setting and the power struggle between them). Other than that scenario, I find most of the plots just okay. Moreover, it's quite lazy to let companions 'tell their background stories' to the main character rather than 'letting the story plays itself out'  ("Tell me about yourself", no, this is not the kind of dialogue I want to see in games like this). But I do understand Obsidian has time concern and companion presentation may not be their priority here.

Combat system is okay, UI interface is great in explaining special terms and rules, but other than that I find no particular excitement in battling.

Overall, PoE has done its job decently, but it doesn't meet my expectations.

Forgot to write a review for this one.

This game is not a bar raiser; maybe it's worth 5 or 10 bucks.  

1. It's similar to Baldur's Gate 1 & 2 which is a good idea, but it doesn't bring anything new to the table.
2. The combat is not great.
3.  The strongest story is about one or two of your companions, Eder and Aeloth. One struggles with the death of his god, the other is losing their mind. This is great having struggling ideas of a worshiper of a dead god is new and interesting. Having a mentally unstable companion is a good contrast of utility vs. risk of unpredictability. However, the companion stories stop there at the idea phase and don't push any boundaries of game play with these characters. Eder is never burdened by this like Boon in Fallout:NV. Aeloth never has any drawbacks to his mental issues which is now just this muted dialogue tree that presents not gameplay advantage or disadvantage. I think Neira is a good example from BG1&2EE as to a fun gamplay element to unorthodox companions with her wild magic.
4. The main story is so muted and toothless. It has no meat as to what it's about which is talking to spirits. This ability is treated like walking on water in a world of fireballs and bear pets. It's a bit absurd to think talking to the dead is somehow beyond imagination. It doesn't push boundaries because players have talked with ghosts and ghoulies for forever. Unlike BG where your the son of the murder god and that's why you get XP from killing, or in Skyrim where you are the dragonborn and you eat dragon souls for power. This ability is kinda boring and uninteresting and the whole plot revolves around the boring thing about the after life? idk It's a stretch for me to care.

The atmosphere, world-building and characters are top tier. Of course, they are tinged with a pretty noticeable American cultural hue, but this is to be expected from an american dev studio. 

Overall, this will be remembered as one of the greatest CRPGs ever made, not to mention single-handedly reviving the genre thereby giving us the Pathfinder series and many more.

Pillars of Eternity is a tough one. There is plenty to like here - an engaging story, deep and interesting lore, fun companions... but it ends up just feeling bloated. 

I'll try to break down why that is. Combat is okay, nothing special, and ends up being mostly automatic when your party is high leveled. This is a problem due to the fact that there are so, so many combat encounters. By just exploring a single area, you'll end up fighting at least ten separate times. It reminds me of the pain of trying to walk through bushes in the early Pokemon games, screaming as you face your fifth hidden enemy in as many steps. Because the combat isn't terribly interesting, it just feels like bloat.

The dialogue is similar. There are certainly great pieces of writing in here, but it just feels like there's too much fluff. A lot of text is devoted to describing facial expressions, nuances in speech, and environmental descriptions that should be essentially unnecessary considering the media. While the main story beats are fun, so much of the side content and conversations just feel like padding and end up feeling like a SLOG to get through.

Finally, the graphics and interface are really not great. This game is from 2015, but I don't think that's an excuse - look at the Homeworld Remastered Collection, which is also from 2015. Pillars of Eternity uses the same few character models for every NPC, has janky animations, lacks decent anti-analyzing, and is generally just not pretty. Additionally, there is a lack of character portraits and expressions, especially in side characters. All of this makes it difficult to really plant yourself in the world and connect with the characters.

Overall, I would say that Pillars of Eternity is only worth playing for the hardcore CRPG fans, or those that are willing to avoid side content. I generally love Obsidian's work, and the main story and lore is up to that standard in this one, but there's a LOT of boring bloat here that's hard to ignore.

A good, if a little underwhelming, successor to the old IE games like Baldur's Gate 1 + 2.  It's an upgrade in a lot of areas - graphics, rule sets, etc.  Attributes actually mean things as you can influence dialog and scripted events based on your stats, spells, skills, class, race, and disposition - if you keep choosing Benevolent options, people may recognize that etc.  I felt the scripted interactions were, if nothing else, a nice diversion.

That said, I did have issues.  There's a lot of lore dumped on you that doesn't really have an impact.  I've played the Baldur's Gate series a lot, but don't really know much about the world.  Baldur's Gate 1 basically has you start out in a town, you are attacked, told to speak to someone in an Inn, who then tell you about checking out a town down South because of some troubles and you basically pick up on things as you go on.  Pillars starts you off and immediately throws a bunch of terms and history at you - there were battles, a god was walking around, killed, etc. it was too much to take in and honestly I didn't think much had any relevance.

I also see people talk about how complex 2E was and how Pillars system is more newbie friendly and as someone who's only real experience with D & D is playing the games, I can't say I agree.  In Baldur's Gate, you only really need to know that some things aren't obvious - like your defense/AC is better the lower the number (-2 is better than -1 is better than 0 is better than 1 is better than 2, etc.) which is all I ever really bothered to learn. That and knowing what spells you needed to learn to buff your team and remove buffs from the enemy. A class like the Fighter was simple - just send them to an enemy and that attack. That was pretty much it.  Classes like the Paladin had things like turn undead and some spells or unique abilities.  The most complex was the mages and knowing what spells to learn (again the buffs/debuffs).  Once you figure that out (they are old games so there's a lot of info online to help).  However, in Pillars, a fighter has all sorts of abilities and when you level, you aren't just getting proficiency points, but also talents and such which adds a complexity. Plus, abilities might only be available in combat, can be used a certain number of times per encounter or rest, or a certain number of casts.

One of the big debates is turn-based (like Divinity Original Sin games) or real time with pause (RtWP, like Pillars).  I personally just want a good game, but one of the arguments against turn based is all the trash fights and how long it takes, yet that was exactly an issue I had with Pillars - too many trash fights that take too long.  Baldur's Gate 1 has complaints of open areas with nothing in them, but I can't say that was worse than Pillars where it just seemed like enemies were placed there just to add something.  At least, in Baldur's Gate most fights were pretty quick whether it was a trash fight or a boss fight (at least if you were unprepared to fight a lich or dragon and they kill you pretty quickly).

You can control the speed of combat and it defaulted to slow which combined with an okay AI system (I used it for most fights on hard without much issue) and the ability to pause.  However, fights still got hard to follow due to the effects going around and the size of some enemies.  I also wasn't a fan of the engagement system where each character can only occupy a certain number of enemies before additional ones can move away without suffering disengagement attacks which enemies mostly seemed to ignore that and it ended up only really impacting your party.

I also didn't think the companions were particularly exceptional (even fan favorite Eder) Though I was impressed by Durance given how divisive he seems to be (he is rather unpleasant and crude), but doing his quest and getting respect felt even better. I got all companions, did all their quests, and I am happy for their endings.  They just didn't grab me like those in Baldur's Gate).  I did find it annoying how Durance's quest was basically rest, exhaust his dialog until he refuses to talk anymore, rest, and repeat until you rest and get a vision.  There's one vision in Act 1 and one in Act 2 that you must see before really progressing the plot if you want to get his good ending. However, you can only do this if you rest outside (or at Caed Nua) as resting at an Inn doesn't count.

Speaking of Caed Nua, that's the stronghold you can get and while I like things like this, it felt underwhelming even compared to those in Baldur's Gate II which weren't that special.  I think I had purchased every upgrade by 20 hours and I had gotten the adventures and hirelings I wanted long before the end of the game. You have prestige and security to manage and need 30 in both for a good Caed Nua ending and 50+ Security to stop attacks.  I think I had like 3 attacks before I got 50+ Security (I do wonder if it bugged because I kept seeing complaints about the attacks?).

I played on Hard which was the hardest difficulty you could get and still change it which wasn't really needed because outside maybe the first 5 levels and some of the bosses and harder content (endless paths, bounties), the game was relatively easy coming from Baldur's Gate 1 & 2 (Core difficulty).  Again, the bigger issue was the fights were numerous and just tedious to get through.

I also thought the story was pretty weak until you get to Twin Elms/White March (which was like 50 hours for me doing everything) and items were pretty lackluster.  There wasn't a weapon that made me feel like I really wanted it like the Flail of Ages in Baldur's Gate II.  You didn't need any special weapons (like a +3 or better weapon to hit tougher foes) and so my gear basically remained unchanged after some time. I even stopped bothering to worrying about equipping the new stuff or enchant them (gain I found the game relatively easier overall on Hard so I felt no need though this could be different for others).

In the end, I still recommend it, but unlike Baldur's Gate where I started with I and played through the end of throne of Bhaal - clockng about 250 hours and thought of a next play through, I'm not really feeling like playing Pillars 1 again and I'm not really in a rush to play Pillars 2. I've heard it's improved, but also had worse sails (and honestly, I can see why).

2016 - what can I say. Newly married, newly jobless. But a host of great games that I played came out in that period - Pillars of Eternity, Total Warhammer, Darkest Dungeon, Paladins.  And I suddenly had the newfound time to play them.

Pillars of Eternity is a legendary game that is generally felt as being the catalyst for the revival of the cRPG genre.  Being a cRPG, the significance of hardware, frames-per-second, and so on is vastly reduced compared with other genres.  When I play a cRPG, I am expecting an experience that is akin to reading a fantasy/sci-fi novel ("Choose Your Own Adventure" for my fellow Gen-Xers), or akin to a tabletop gaming experience.  The latter (tabletop experience) was not a criterion for Pillars of Eternity (PoE) because to my knowledge, it is an entirely new gameplay system (that is similar to D&D, Pathfinder, but different as well).  

Therefore, my main criterion for PoE was the story.  How intrigued am I by the unfolding of the storyline?  Do I want to keep playing in order to find out "what happens next"?  Am I touched deeply by the storyline (as I was for Dragon Age: Origins)?  Do I remember iconic NPCs in the game?  Are the choices significant?  Do they matter?  Are there multiple endings?

My secondary criterion is the game system.  As many (most) people who enjoy RPGs, I enjoy trying to develop innovative builds or novel playstyles using the game system.  I am definitely not a min/maxer - for me personally that detracts from my primary criterion (storyline);  the ability to build my party, skills, and equipment is kind of my own personal creative input into the story.  

The final criterion is the "technical/engineering" group - graphics, sound, ability to switch into turn-based mode, user interface, and so on.  As I had stated initially, unlike an FPS or some other genres, I don't expect to continually receive  "dopamine hits" as I play the game, and I don't expect some sort of immersive visual experience.  There are other genres for that.  

Regarding the storyline, I liked how it developed from the start, from very humble beginnings.  But one issue that kept irking me throughout the PoE series (both PoE1 and PoE2) was the emphasis on religion and gods.  I have my own religious views in real-life, so having some sort of deity is not what I take issue with.  The part that I take issue with is the introduction of an entire pantheon of gods along with their own personality and lore.  I felt as I played the game that the entire purpose of the game was to serve a didactic goal:  to educate the player in this seminal new lore.  As a stark contrast, in Dragon Age: Origins there was no major emphasis on deities - only the notion of a "Maker" and interactions (sometimes very substantial) with NPCs who would discuss the "Maker".  The actual story for Dragon Age: Origins was based on an impending threat to the entire world, and that you as the player are tasked with saving humanity.  The "education" in the game was learning about the other races that occupied the world, their histories, and dealing with iconic NPCs - many of whom I'll remember the rest of my life.

I didn't get that kind of feel at all from PoE.  I felt I was immersing myself in philosophical dialogues about entities and events that I had no awareness of.  It was too much most of the time to go through the dialogues where they would keep referring to events/objects/deities that I was not familiar with;  very taxing mentally.   

So the storyline - no, I did not really enjoy it.  In fact, as I played, it began to detract from my playing experience.

My second criterion is the aspect of PoE that really shined.  The gameplay mechanics were really interesting, varied, and kept me occupied in terms of how to continually improve my character and my party.   I enjoyed many of the fights, and in my recollection, I never experienced a fight that was too easy or too difficult.  I have to be honest - I never played Baldur's gate - though I started my gaming career back in 1981.  By the time Baldur's Gate had arrived, I was already starting my first jobs and simply was not engaged in computer games between 1991 - 2004.   The mechanics were really nice though of an incremental reveal of an area as the party explores it.  Additionally, highlighting important items that can be searched, interacted with, or picked up was important;  without it I would have to have internet searches continually to ensure I didn't miss out on an important aspect of the exploration.   

I did have a problem with Druids because they're spells injured both friend and foe;  therefore I had to primarily use the Druid as a summoner and healer.  I felt that many of the more destructive spells were off-limits or difficult to use.  But maybe that was just my lack of knowledge of the game - but then again - maybe not.

This one is a really rough start. Having just finished Divinity Original Sin 2 and a replay of the old best in class Baldur's Gate, Pillars of Eternity didn't measure up at first. But once I started to play the way the game wanted me to rather than how I wanted to, it got much more enjoyable. My most major complaint is combat is either far too easy or far too hard depending on how you go about things, there never really feels like a point where it feels what I'd call balanced. Story was very good, however my main complaint is it really wants you to know the lore of the game without allowing you a slow immersion into it. If you're not willing to read the in-game lore deeply to understand the forces at play, it's best to make your decisions moment by moment. Overall, while this game doesn't measure up to the S tier kings of the genre type games, it is a solid, well made A tier game that I'm sure I'll play again at some point.

I started this game to find a substitute to Divinity Original Sins.
Everything you want is there. But it is all poorely executed:

- the combat system would be better turn-based, as in the end you just spam click the pause button to simulate a turn base game
- characters gets stuck in invisible walls or doorframes all the time
- the camera needs to be manually adjusted in permanance because it does not center on your team. You end up playing league of legend with your camera
- craft exist, but is useless
- the lore is rich. But very badly exposed
- 50% of the already overwehlming textboxes are description of what is displayed on your screen. Here is the thing: YOU HAVE A SCREEN, YOU ALREADY SEE THAT. During the adaptation process devs forgot that the visual interface replaces the books and books of descriptions.
- I'm 20h in, I win all my battles. But I still don't know if I play correctly
- the storyline is uninterresting. I have no empathy toward my main characters and have no clue about his motivations. It is also hard to figure out why those randoms want to join my party
- the environment is "rich" of description but nothing to interact with. Most NPCs don't talk to you, but through a spiritual power you can read 40 lines of their backstory. And then ... nothing. It serves no purpose. It feels like a museum of RPG characters created by the devellopers during their weekend playthroughs

Had some questionable decisions regarding stat effect choices.

noting that Wizard primary stat is perception, max that out and then increase strength or intelligence based on your goals. Strength for blaster/buffs, intelligence for heavier crowd control. I was looking for a new style of games to play and ended up getting interested in Classic RPGs.
I've never played one that uses the real-time combat mechanic with pauses. I got used to it after a few hours and replaying some parts of the game.

I restarted the game twice because creating a character in this game is so complete and complex.

The art of the game is impeccable. The world, characters and especially the map.

Dialogues and interactions with other characters is also surreal. I imagine that the result I had in my game is totally different from someone else's. Many variables about sub races, classes and origin that I confess I felt a little lost sometimes.

Combat is incredible, My main character was a paladin who caught everyone's attention while the other members of my party used different skills that could be combined and performed in infinite ways.

Really the technique and strategy is very unique to each player.

The party can be composed of charismatic characters with quests about their past and personal life. Or simply composed of mercenaries that can be hired from the first city of the game.

Impressive soundtrack, recording work and audio quality is excellent. Many times I paused the game to work (draw) and left the game open to listen to the full soundtrack of some scenarios.

Finally, I can say that this game really had all the attention and dedication since the beginning of production. I recommend anyone who likes documentaries to watch Road To Eternity. About the dedicated people who worked on it!

Looking forward to playing the second one and recommend it to anyone who has ever had any sort of interest in classic rpgs.

This CRPG is a true classic. Obsidian outdid themselves with the story, world building, and unique magic system. The amount of in-game lore for the setting is massive, rivaling other RPG's such as Skyrim with the amount of books you can read as you explore. 

One criticism you will often hear is that this game is LONG. While true, the game is very long it is also very addicting if you are a fan of the fantasy genre. The biggest negative for me is that there is no way to figure out ahead of time what build you want for your character and party members. While this was added in the sequel the lack of it in this game was a little disappointing.

10/10 would recommend

Lovingly crafted updated 90's classic CRPG. All new IP with fantastic world building and art. Strong characters, and the original combat and magic is well done. Long load times make getting settled into a session a bit clunky, and while the combat is well designed and fun, because it is mechanically deep, positioning becomes extremely powerful. This means that a lot of combat actually hinges on the position of your characters at the beginning of the fight, as well as the utilization of doorway bottlenecks and corners; things that the AI is (understandably) unable to meaningfully approach in an immersive manner. A few combat sequences can be significantly frustrating as the scripted event repositions your team as part of a pre-combat cut-scene dialog, or spawns massive threats from nowhere on top of your backline with your tanks a million miles away. 

The story and writing was strong and deep. I had no issues reading the lengthy dialog and narration carefully, and I believe this title gives the IP a fantastic foundation for future games to retun to and build upon. This is a far more sophisticated world than Tamriel or even Faerûn.

I was, however, left with significant bad feels with how the endgame plot resolutions are handled. Killing the final boss terminates the playthrough permanently and feeds you a series of narrations that explain the resolution of all the interactable plot points. This ends up being highly frustrating because failing to complete side quests results in real negative narrative consequences. One cannot simply reload from before the boss encounter and go back into the world to continue your side quests because the entrance to the endgame is a one-way drop multiple maps back from the final boss fight. By the time you realize the full consequences of your decision to enter the end-game area, it has already become a massive headache to roll back your decision, and some of the narrative resolutions you get locked into are downright infuriating. The absolute worst one for me was caused directly by the natural combat difficulty of the zones. I completed White March I but planned on finishing White March II after I resolved the main quest. This turned out to be actually not possible and instead actively punished with the ultimate narrative sequence informing me that "Despite all of the good that was achieved, your happiness did not last long as massive creatures [from White March II] came and found your keep and destroyed it and pulled it down around you. THE END." Nice one, Obsidian.

Still, a good game, particularly for fans of Baldurs Gate 2 that want a way to revisit some of the highs of that classic experience. Just make sure you finish absolutely all content before going to Burial Isle.

If you're an old time D&D dude and want to scratch that itch, stay away. Because their stat system is stupid. Gone are the days when Strength affected melee and intelligence, wisdom or even Charisma affected your ability damage. Now Might simply means damage, dexterity means how often you can hit, Perception how accurate those hits are. Intellect for ability range and duration. And Resolve? A useless stat in combat but very very important in dialogue. So much so that you aren't given any other options to to (heh) resolve quests.

Doesn't matter if you're a barbarian, wizard or a ranger. If you want to do damage, you have to go might. And then the skills? Attributes don't affect them anymore. You can make a barbarian with high lore or mechanics/stealth skills. Or you can make a wizard with high survival and athleticism. Doesn't matter. They all get equal skill points. Upto you on how you want to spend it.

This makes no sense in a CRPG. Stats wise, a wizard looks exactly the same as a barbarian. High might, high perception and medium/high level intellect. What's the point of playing other  classes? I'm still going to have use the same damn checks for conversation anyway. Instead of..oh I dunno, using Strength as a Barbarian and using Intelligence as a wizard for conversations.

PoE is a favorite to which I return every few years; it's the clear spiritual successor to the Baldur's Gate/Icewind Dale/Neverwinter Nights games that I love.  It's a beautifully crafted homage to those prior games - instantly playable by anyone who enjoyed them, but with nice updated visuals. It features RTWP combat, which is my ideal (I find turn-based combat to be unbearably slow, though I know many love it). Companions are genuinely interesting - with some decent banter and good voice acting - and many of them are unusual builds:  a rouge in (permanent) heavy armor,  a ranger with unremarkable dexterity, and so on, which makes utilizing them effectively an interesting challenge.  Story line is complex.  

Highly recommended for anyone who likes the aforementioned games.

I am gutted that I can't give a positive review for this game and regrettably, devs, the wounds were self-inflictd.

  I've played Baldur's Gate trilogy from start to finish and still rate as amongst the best ever CRPG on PC, perhaps even the best.

  And to be honest at the outset PoE is more of the same - to the extent that Gary Gygax (creator of Dungeons and Dragons) could have taken a litigious view of PoE's systems (although thanks to Wikipedia I note that he'd (1) left TSR and (2) died before PoE came out)   - character classes, stats, armour slots are all so close to the D&D licensed Baldur's Gate as to be indistinguishable.

  However there are differences and this is where the problems arise.

  Baldur's Gate had the clear cut system that spellcasters had a certain number of spells per day and had to rest to regain their spells.  This did mean that beginning magic users were fragile and weak to a ridiculous extent.  Dynaheir's role for half of the first part of Baldur's Gate was to stand at the back of the party throwing sling shots which rarely hit and didn't do much damage when they did hit whilst the rest of the party got down to the heavy business of actually killing monsters.  To compensate there was a glorious moment at the end game where she wiped out an entire army of undead with a single fireball spell but that was a long time later.

  PoE instead has a rule that spells can be cast only "once per encounter".  What's an encounter ?  Eleven hours in I couldn't provide you with a sound definition which makes economising on spell use tricky.

  The worst change however was adding Endurance and then having basic heal spells cure only Endurance not health.  The only way to restore health is to restore at an inn (If you've done the right thing there's an accessible and free inn - for basic care from the start of the game) or use limited camping supplies which can be purchased at a modest price from the inn. 

  The problem is after the introductory prologue enemy get tougher and deal significant amounts of damage.  Certain encounters are lethal.  You're left therefore to "cheese" your way through the game - encounter one set of monsters where you literally use every spell in your books, run back to the inn, heal up, start again.  And this isn't fun...

   I'm guessing later in the game both spells and abilities start to restore health as well as endurance because otherwise the reviews should be far worse.  But this was an unnecessary modification and one that generally shouldn't have been introduced.

If you're a fan of the Baldur's Gate series, this is a given.

Be aware, though, that even as a lifelong RPG player, I find this one to be challenging at times. There are so many complicated mechanics in place, all the time, that make this a technical marvel, but you really have to know what you're doing in order to be successful. If you're starting out with CRPG's, are a casual player, or haven't yet stomped Sarevok, I would probably recommend starting a character, running through the first couple scenarios until you unlock Caed Nua, and then restarting from the beginning with a build that's maximized for your play-style. I didn't cover all the bases, and as a result I missed out on a lot of options in the early gameplay hours. Plus, I have to play a LOT of catch-up just to be able to handle the challenges as they arise.

Great game, VERY engaging, and will likely keep you busy for 100+ hours (if you're going trial-and-error all the way through like I am).  Can't wait to play the sequel too.

I grew up with Baldurs Gate and Neverwinter, and I still thoroughly enjoy crpgs. 

This game, however, while tries to evoke feelings that Baldurs Gate did, falls miserably short. 

The worldbuilding in Pillars of Eternity is simply too much. It's trying so hard to be original and unique, it spams you with long pages of lore and made-up words, that it doesn't even stop to wonder if it should be doing it. There's so much flavor that is meaningless, and none of it is interesting or gripping. 
All the dialogs feel dry, and all the drama feels strangely detached, manufactured. Game has so many concepts that it pours out on you all at once, that you are quickly lost in the word salad, bland characters and bland lore. 

The plot hook, also just doesn't feel all that interesting. It's just detached, cold, it tries to be like the intro of the Baldurs Gate, but instead of your step-father, it tries to grip you with death of some randos you just met. And instead of menace that was Sarevok (admittedly conanthebarbarian-esque) you just see some guy that doesn't even try to kill you directly, he's just there, doing something unrelated. And this weak, soggy beginning just carries through the game as it goes. You just end up places, doing things, and none of it seems to matter.

I sort of like the combat, and I like the graphic style. It feels nice, but all in all, I hope coming forward people who make crpgs realize, that more text isn't necessarily better, if you have no strong idea behind it.

I was born Hollowborn but playing this game gave me a soul.

I liked the game in the first 8 hours. The first 8 hours I build my character, tried learning about the game and what it is. As I eventually learned what the game is and how it tells me its story it became quite tedious for me. A mixture of too many facts, too many regions, names, wars, gods with no feeling of relevance. 
Hard to explain, but it felt pretty shallow and then I got some bad game play mechanics on top of it (castle management for example). 

Why do games that have almost no story at all, feel more fun to play, than this? I can only make theories about that.. maybe a badly written/told story is worse than letting people make their own story in their mind (in the sense of less is more)? 

The castle system personally triggered me. I do not often say something like this, but this was so painful to me. What a wasted potential this is. Kingdom Come Deliverance, for example, does this better. You feel a connection to the place, you personally recruit the people for it, care about its development, not only for yourself or your personal gain, but also for the people that live there. Here it is just letters in a logbook. This cannot be the product, that the developers thought of.

Of course "bad" is not a good statement about someones work, more appealing would be: it is just not for me. 
There are worse games out there, but definitely better ones too.

This game was an attempt to emulate RPGs from circa 2000, and it did the job *too* well.  The RPG rules system is basically the store brand version of Dungeons and Dragons 3rd edition, with almost every ability refreshing after a rest...which are doled out by a resource you can only carry 8 of.  The end result is that the game motivates you to play it in the most, boring repetitive way possible, only using your cool abilities when you have no choice.

They fixed this for the sequel.  It is leagues better than this game.  Skip this one and go straight to Pillars of Eternity II: Deadfire.

Now I remember why  I stopped playing this game, so many issues: 
- Saving game is awkward, You can't easily tell which is your latest save. 
- If you have multiple monitors with different resolutions, you can't play in fullscreen if the monitor you play on isn't the main monitor.
- Dialog trees are super long but sometimes you can't save before it jumps into battle; e.g. Maerwald. So if you die, you have to go thru the entire ordeal again. It's like the devs never really bother doing any play testing
- The writing is so long-winded that it feels like the writers were trying too hard. Half the crap doesn't even make sense. 
- This game tried to horn in on the Baldur's Gate fame but it's a poor imitation. Baldur's Gate was the gold standard; this is, at best, a Yugo.

Nie raz czułem się zmuszony zmniejszyć poziom trudności by móc grać dalej (ale to też może być po prostu moja nieogarnięta natura), po za tym zmęczeniem gdy na koniec gry już nawet zostawiłem questy nieskończone iż chciałem już ją skończyć.

Za to mamy całą grupę towarzyszy od (nie aż tak typowego) weterana wojny po...jakąś kobietę której nie mam pojęcia jak ją opisać bez spoilerów by wskazać jak szeroki wachlarz towarzyszy się tu znajduje.
Postęp postaci jest dość prosty i nie daje wielkiej swobody, ta swoboda znajduje się natomiast w wyborach podczas gry. Aczkolwiek nie jestem pewien czy konsekwencje i wybory z zadań pobocznych mają jakiś wpływ na główną fabułę. 
Dubbing prawie nie istnieje. Nawet w dialogach głównej fabuły często 1/30 jest mówiona (język angielski, nie sprawdzałem czy jest polski dubbing) a reszta jak wcześniej wspomniałem to czytelniana głusza. 
Dochodząc do muzyki jestem lekko zawiedziony. Były momenty gdzie jest przyjemna ale w większości o niej zapominam, i nawet nie zauważam. 

Ze strony technicznej nie dawała mi problemów.
Dla tych którzy uważają to za ważne, gra odbywa się w pełni w trybie czasu rzeczywistego z pauzą.

Polecam bo pomimo paru niedociągnięć jest solidnym RPG-iem. A jak do tej pory POE2 poprawiła większość problemów jakie POE1 posiada.

TL;DR: It's an RPG with clunky, hard-to-parse abilities; a cookie-cutter fantasy story; and an unacceptable amount of time spent sitting in loading screens.

Review: 

I forced myself to finish this because I bought the this and the sequel at the same time and I wanted to see if the sequel would be any more enjoyable.

The gameplay felt clunky and overly obtuse. Skill abilities feel sapped of fun because they're so damn hard to read and don't really feel impactful in gameplay. I think I was mostly okay with these shortcomings because Obsidian tried uber hard to make the most RPG RPG.

The straw that broke the camel's back for me were the loading screens. The maps are so small and even small buildings are usually made up of at least 2 or more maps. To simply get a rested bonus for your party, you have to sit through 6 loading screens... Why...? How was this not a major complaint even in 2015? It took me 62 hours to beat the game because I'm a partial completionist and masochist.

The plot also wasn't that interesting. I'm not going to say anything about it because it's a huge part of the game and I don't want to ruin it for anyone who is totally okay with sitting through lots of long loading screens. This is not normally a major issue, but this is an RPG and that's kind of a big deal.

Epic CRPG that plays like the classics of the late 90s. Well written story, and modernized gameplay that was inspired by titles such as Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale. If you haven't play this one yet I couldn't recommended it enough. It is well worth the 80+ hours of content.

Final Score: 5/5 - Amazing Game

An astoundingly mediocre game. Pillars of Eternity is almost never bad, but just as rarely is it good. From a foundation of generic fantasy, the game presents some interesting ideas here and there and has decent writing throughout, but it ultimately drowns in its sheer repetitiveness and breadth.

Every quest follows the same template: receive a task. Learn that the situation is more complicated than initially presented. Make a choice on how to resolve the matter -- often a genuinely difficult choice with no clear right answer. This is great! Then you do it so many times that it turns hollow. I was utterly sick of side quests by the end of Pillars of Eternity, which I recognize is partially my fault for refusing to turn away from them, but I wanted to give the game a fair shake by experiencing as much of its writing as possible. It's not bad, it's just... okay, and overabundant.

Combat is where the real problems begin. It's not uncommon for CRPGs to go down as all-time classics despite abhorrent battle systems, and Pillars fares better than many of its predecessors in this regard. It has solid, intricate real-time-with-pause combat that gives you plenty of tactical options. Unfortunately, the game commits the other cardinal CRPG combat sin: having waaaay to much of it. There are an insane number of battles in Pillars of Eternity, and it's a shame that only a tiny handful of them are especially interesting. This game loves to throw trash mobs at you, over and over again, seemingly for the simple reason that this is a dungeon crawler and it wouldn't be right if it didn't toss an army of slimes at you every 10 feet. What's most bizarre is that Pillars sharply limits combat EXP per enemy type and has non-respawning enemies. It baffles me that the developers manually placed all combat encounters, created systems that disincentivize solving every problem with violence, then saturated the world with meaningless encounters. A significant portion of my fatigue with Pillars of Eternity can be attributed to its combat.

The White March dlcs are the final nail in the coffin. They're horrifically overstuffed, bloated trudges that act as microcosms of all Pillar's worst instinct. Side quests are packed together in tiny zones. It's a bad sign when the vampire clan I was sent to destroy and the completely unrelated local ogre encampment are so close together they probably share a street address. I was utterly bored of the White March by the halfway point of part 1. When part 2 unveiled its main enemy type as easy-to-disable damage sponges that took an eternity to kill while posing very little threat, my disappointment gave way to disgust. The White March may have damaged my appreciation for Pillars of Eternity more than any other part of the game.

Lastly, I want to give a special call-out to the walking. Exploring new areas was always fun, but when I had to trek across them again? Dear god, no other game is more deserving of a 5x speed toggle. A minor problem to be sure, but after ~85 hours of gameplay I would have killed for faster walking. I never want to trek from Caed Nua's gate to its keep again. And yes, I'm aware of the fast forward option. I used it constantly when revisiting explored areas, and it is not enough.

Visually, the game is fine. It looks great for an 8 year-old CRPG, although it sometimes does a poor job of conveying the interesting parts of its environment. Am I spoiled by Elden Ring, or is it bad when something as striking as a gigantic elm tree wrapped around an ancient ruined tower is barely visible? Perhaps we've simply come a long way in tree-based video game visuals since. The aesthetic in general does nothing for me, however. It's incredibly generic even when it looks good.

So that's Pillars of Eternity, a game that could have been great if it was 30 or 40 hours shorter. I guess it's not surprising that a game which is credited with resurrecting a dead genre played things safe. I'm not shocked that plenty of people enjoy it, and I hear that the sequel was a drastic improvement, but I have no energy for it after completing an exhaustive and exhausting playthrough. If anything, Pillars of Eternity works best as a measuring stick. Is a CRPG worse than PoE? It's a bad game. Is a CRPG better than PoE? It's a good game. But as it stands, I would not recommend it to anyone but hardcore genre enthusiasts.
Really enjoying my long delayed playthrough of Pillars of Eternity.  Definitely has the old Baldur's Gate feel to it, but with some nice tweaks.

Pillars of Eternity is a worthy heir to the classic CRPG genre. It offers an adventure that feels epic yet personal, a host of well-written, multifaceted party members, and a broad, immersive world to explore. This game is one of the best available for role-playing in the conventional sense, as its many conversations and questlines offer a wide variety of compelling options for developing your character's personality and establishing their place in the world.

The two most common complaints levelled at Pillars is the lore density and the real-time-with-pause combat system, but I feel these criticisms are unfair. The lore is rather dense, but if you pay attention and ask questions you'll pick up the history and culture of the world fairly quickly without any particular need for consulting any external resources, as some claim. And ultimately, the well-developed lore of Pillars's world plays in its favour, as the unique flavour of its metaphysics and geopolitics more than compensates for the initial blandness of its generic fantasy presentation. The combat, another sticking point, is another place your mileage may vary. Players who enjoy finding build synergies and approaching combat with a slower, more strategy-oriented approach will probably enjoy the depth of its systems, but players who wish to ignore these systems will probably find it a bit clumsy and unengaging. 

One criticism that's pretty objective, unfortunately, is that the game is poorly optimised and will likely struggle with stuttering and framerate drops even on powerful systems, especially towards the endgame for some reason.

Despite its roughness around the edges, Pillars of Eternity is a real gem that will suck in any fan of the CRPG genre and stick with them for a long time after the credits roll. If you're looking to embark on a grand adventure, to get to know a party of dependable friends, to immerse yourself fully in an expansive fantasy world and uncover its ancient secrets, then look no further.

Even though this is a recommended review, this game is not for everyone. It's a very slow game and definitely kept more of the table top RPG elements than modifying them to make a better PC game like DOS2. And some design choices didn't help either, I guess some game mechanics strengthened the roll play element, but at the same time lengthened the game time unnecessarily. Especially in the form of increased loading screens, you better have an SSD for this game, otherwise the time you have to wait for loading screens will really test your patience.

Now up to the good stuff for RPG fans. The environment of the game and the background lore setup is quite good, probably further enhanced by the exceptionally well done writting. The voice acting when present is very good, it makes each character unique and lively. Sadly probably only half of the conversation has voice acting. The character building and combat is beyond most PC RPG games. The system is rather complicated and will take you hours to do research on them online to fully understand, or if you'd prefer to play around yourself, it will just take even longer. However, building a right character can be very rewarding, the power curve till the end of the game is very satisfying. On top of all that, the classes are quite unique as well, there are more interesting ones of course, but the number of unique interesting classes are enough for multiple playthroughs. Personally I found the story interesting, it's not the best story in game history and have loopholes here and there, but I never felt bored to want to stop playing. On the other hand, the side stories are really well done, or in some way there are no side stories in this game. Even though some quests are marked as side quests, it just means it's not tightly related to the main event. Since you only gain exp from quest, you probably will end up doing a lot of the side quests just to get enough exp to level up to proceed in the main story. That's why I say there are no side quest like a normal game as you are kind of required to do a decent amount of them. The good news is they are really well done, so it's a fair trade off. Just don't expect to ignore everything and only focus on the main quest, it's almost not viable and you are probably missing a lot of the better stories in the game. It's a old game but I feel the graphics has held up well. It's not anything special in today's standard but it doesn't look too bad. 

All in all, for RPG fans it's definitely a game worth checking out. Even though the options you make can't really affect the events too much, it does still has enough effect to make you feel immersive. It's probably not as well optimized for PC games as DOS2, but it's probably more roll play and D&D like than it for more hardcore fans. 

P.S. Through my almost 50 hrs game time, hasn't encountered a single bug, so in that perspective, it's really well optimized for PC. So don't worry about that part.

To sum up what will probably be a longer review, this is a very good CRPG to sink your teeth into if you're craving that sort of thing, with good writing and unique (but still firmly comfortable in it's fantasy genre) world building.

Firstly, this game very much wears its inspirations on its sleeve, while not being overly tied to them. In some of its advertising it specifically mentions games it's emulating/drawing inspiration from. I haven't played all of those games (yet), but it takes those classic isometric CRPGs and builds a solid modern game out of them.

To me, the main story, especially the final act of the game, is very reminiscent of Planescape: Torment. It handles that mixture of grand metaphysical concepts, with deep personal stakes quite well. Not nearly as well as Planescape does, but better than one might expect. 

To expand on the quality of writing for a few paragraphs, it's solid all around. No quest is a faceless fetch-quest, there's at least a small story with everything (which i hugely appreciate). The main quest is quite interesting and makes your character feel rounded, despite having to be the changing amorphous blob all "make-your-own" characters in these games have to be. The DLC was surprisingly chunky, so much so it took me out of the main game for a while and i had to re-adjust.

The lore and setting in this game is...well, it's not anything special honestly. However, I *really* enjoyed it. It's very standard fantasy but it's been crafted and tweaked to give an honest attempt at standing out from the crowd. It's history, religions, world, technology level I find compelling. I particularly like the godlike and orlans. The godlike being your genasi/tiefling equivalent. And the orlans being a more unique take on halflings/gnomes. It all feels lovingly crafted. The most unique element by far is the concept of souls and animancy (the study and use of souls). This is central to the world and story and is really what makes this game stand out. You play as a "Watcher" someone who's developed the ability to interact/see souls, which provides some opportunity for some really unique stories and gameplay. Funnily, I feel as though it's a bit underdeveloped for such a central concept to the game. I found myself asking a lot of questions about it and not really always finding consistent answers. It's not a huge issue (hardly even necessarily an issue), but is something you might find wondering about, as i did. To be fair, I wouldn't ask these questions about how the magic in this game works, as it's an expected trope - perhaps I should be treating animancy in the same way.

The companions are all (at the least) mildly interesting and have definite personalities. You'll have ones you like and don't like, but they're all well-handled and contribute to conversations in interesting/funny/meaningful ways. It seems some of them got more love than others, but all are unique. There's that banter and intrigue from the companions you always want from this sort of game. It's the main appeal of party-based games, I'd argue. You get 6 in a party, including yourself, which feels a good number (although you'll have to swap out if you want to do all their associated companion quests). There's definitely reason to replay, make different choices, party up with different characters and see their reactions and those consequences. 

Dialogue in this game is something i was extremely happy with, mostly. I think having an option to see how much meta-game information you see is such an excellent idea, and one i wish more games implemented. There is a bit of fussing you can do with buffs and stats to get dialogue options to work. There's a lot of variation on how you can go about talking to people. On top of of stat-based options, there's also reputation-based options, which they did an excellent job with. What i felt they did a lesser job with was background/class/race dialogue options - they are there, don't get me wrong, but i expected more. Places where i expected to have something to say as either a druid/godlike just didn't have an option often (this might be better with other options, but for me it was sometimes lacking). Resolve is a bit of a funny stat, and is the most used dialogue-stat as your sort of charisma equivalent. So having low resolve makes it harder to generally convince people of things. By the end of the game i could buff myself to 20 resolve (the max of any stat you'll need in dialogue) from 10, with a bit of effort. But at that point, a little late for most of the quests. I don't think that all is an issue, necessarily, but it is something I had mixed feelings on.

That gets into the next thing I find need to comment on in this game, stats. It handles them differently to most RPGs. Some feel much more important than others, but there's still uses for everything. There's a bit of an nontraditional approach to how they all work. They all affect some sort of combat stat and give you the option to use them in dialogue. I found them a bit awkward in the start, but grew to actually quite enjoy how they were implemented. Might is used for both physical *and* magical damage (as well as healing capability), which i still find straaaange. I mean, it works, but yeah, a choice was made there.

I really like the classes in this game. They're all designed impressively well. I played the druid, which is usually snubbed in most games, but got some real love here. It's the proper jack-of-all trades with melee (Shapeshift) combat, elemental magic, and heal/buff magic. The other classes are all fairly unique and have their different systems implemented. Combat is pretty good, even if it is RTWP - it's designed around that and you get used to it. There are a lot of spells in this game, and if you have multiple spell casters in your party it gets a bit overwhelming remembering everything you have. I was constantly forgetting where/what buffs/debuffs/cures my cleric had. The customising element is pretty solid as well, with talents/stats/skills all giving a good depth to levelling. 

I don't have any major strifes with this game. I suppose the backer content and stories and characters are annoying, but easily ignored. I was confused by their addition, as it's not explained what they are, and I assumed a lot of characters just had backstories I could see as a "Watcher". 
Edit: I CAN'T BELIEVE I FORGOT. The fucking load times in this game are not great, and get very annoying. I Have no idea why they are as bad as they are.

Overall, give it a go, as per my above recommendation. I'm looking forward to when I get around to the second game and seeing where the Watcher's story goes next AND AVOWED, whenever that's released.

Just like many others before me, I absolutely recommend this game! It captures the spirit of Baldur's Gate like no other game I've played.

I do think its a bit overhyped. Don't get me wrong, this game is a great experience for all who love party-based classical rpgs in the style of Baldur's Gate. At the same time though, it does have its shortcomings that you may not expect given the fantastic receptions from press and players alike.

So first things first: 
the good stuff:
[list]
[*]the classes: they feel distinct from one another, some more unique arche types, like Cipher (a resource-building-resource spending class with lots of damage and utility potential) as well as plenty of the familiar classes we all know from D&D (like Fighter, Mage, Priest, etc.)
personal bonus: they have a Druid and (s)he is a lot of fun!
[*] the story: the main story of the base game and its 2 DLCs is really well made, has a lot of depths and care.
[*] the world: they acomplished to create their own lore, not a ripoff on somebody else's IP and as a player you're drawn into it and its many inhabitants, its races and views of the people in it
[*] freedom of choice: you're not locked into creating a rogue to get all the doors unlocked or traps disarmed. you can choose to play without a character that has access to these tools (you're often given keys from carefully exploring), or simply create a Ranger, Cipher or even a Wizard with access to trap disarmament and lock picking
[*] there are also many helpful tips in the beginning to get you started on the base mechanics of the game
[*] the improvement felt in the DLC content. For me, the areas outside of cities felt pretty barren in the base game. There was only one major encounter per map, mostly for a single quest and other than that there was nothing worth noting happening in a single region. This was quite a disappointment. But they improved immensly in the DLC areas. The areas a larger, and more events and encounter are present on a given map. It didn't felt barren but exciting to explore.
[*] an extra positive point, as this is where many RPGs fail: the story of the DLCs is really good. Not as good as the main story of the base game but really well made.
[/list]

and now the bad or less good stuff:
[list]
[*]crafting: its a bit lack luster. you can craft potions, food and scrolls. I never did any of those, you simply get enough from looting and exploring, unless you play on hardest difficulty I guess
[*]graphics: this is one area where you feel that its an indie title the most. Its a game from 2015, but if you compare it to other titles of its time, it is apparent that this game is a not a high budget production. The Witcher 3 has phenomenal graphics, and even Larian Games' party-rpg Divinity Original Sin 1 from 2013 (and polished in 2015) looks better.
[*] the way DLC content is being handled: you absolutely have to play it before you complete the main story of the base game. There is no way around it. At least the devs gave you a pre-end save, so you can go back and play DLC content, if you didn't before finishing the main story of the base game. But if you can't play anymore after viewing the end credits. The game doesn't throw you into the world again after this point. This is poorly handled in my opinion.
[*] the side quests: they feel forgettable, and just not really interesting. A bit similar to general questing in MMOs.
[*] the health/endurance system. It felt awkward in the beginning, and it still felt awkward in the end. When you're in combat and you loose life, your endurance gets lowered. But once out of combat, your life is measured in health. You can't restore health with healing spells, only endurance. So you can only restore endurance. And the lost endurance is striped from your health at the end of combat. I see that this system has its advantages, but to me it was an inconvienence during the game.
[/list]

All in all, I wholeheartedly recommend this game, even though there are some downsides. Overall, it was a really good experience I recommend others to share! 
And given all of its improvements over the course of its development, I am looking forward to play Pillars of Eternity 2!

Still, an enjoyable game with lots of ways to play and interact with the world.

Yeah, I know. Obsidian good. Obsidian never no wrong do. Hogwash. Orc dung. Elf excrement. How could I speak such blasphemy? The world crafting is exceptional, with unique races and character builds that allow for real choices that change the world around you. So they say. Some of this is right: the world building and character creation is exceptional. I didn't get far enough to know what kind of effect my choices had on the world. All the stuff I hated derailed my play-through. I absolutely hated the game play. 

Being an isometric game, it would have taken a lot for me to love the game. Sure, I have played lots of these games. But most of them don't have such poor pathing. Getting anywhere involves weaving your way through confusing pathways. At least in forest areas. 

Battles involve a lot of tedious micromanaging if you want to have a chance at victory. Worst, not all battles will earn you xp. This alone breaks the game for me. If you stumble into a group of lower-level enemies, you will waste resources  but get no xp. It seems like I was always running into these groups. 

Obsidian is known for their writing. Could this save the game? Not for me. All the endless scrolls of writing belonged in a bad fantasy book, not a bad fantasy game. By far the worst writing came from all the random individuals who inhabited the world. Evidently the developers rewarded early supporters by having their fantasy stories shared through random npcs. If you love fan fiction, or fantasy fiction written by high school students, these stories will thrill you. For the rest of us, they are offensively bad. Prostituting quality for cash is shameful.

But who cares what I think. Obsidian good, Obsidian no wrong do. Obsidian good game make. Wrong. Game no fun. Game tedious. Game no buy.

Pillars of Eternity is truly a phenomenal RPG. Among the best around. This stands right alongside the greatest RPGs like Baldur's Gate, Planescape Torment, and Icewind Dale. If you liked those games, you will love this. While not a Dungeons and Dragons game/ruleset, PoE uses a familiar isometric top down look like those classics and adds its own lore, lands, ruleset, magic, and mechanics to weave one of the best role playing games around. Tons of content and great interaction with different endings truly allowing you to play how you want while keeping it grounded with that old school feel. Josh and company created an amazing game that you would cheat yourself if you didn't allow yourself to try it, especially if you loved the Black Isle and Black Isle inspired games. Grab yourself an ale, light a pipe of good pipe weed, and sit down and enjoy the interesting and unique story, lore, and characters this fantastic RPG offers.

I strongly recommend this game. The pros and cons are best to express why I recommend it:

PROS
 - In the grand tradition of Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, etc. A grand CRPG adventure with roleplay and monsters and loot. Go from Lvl1 to Lvl16 with the expansion.
 - The game is beautiful: Very beautiful with a toned-down colour palette that pleases the eyes.
 - The music is excellent. When the battle starts, OMG! the music is epic. It is orchestral and makes your adventures memorable. The main theme is sad and I thus associate sadness with this game (as was intended, I think)
 - You can customise your entire party or hire companions or both. I recruited my own Barbarian and Rogue because I wanted to but still did all the companion quests. The system works very well.
 - Your stash has infinite capacity and is accessible at all times. Compare that with Dragon Age Origins or Baldur's Gate where you had to run back and forth between the dungeon and the town vendor. This is a very nice quality of life improvement.
 - The world is open so you can go where you want, when you want.
 - There are many quests, enough to suit your desires.
 - The world is credible with its inhabitants, its lore, the companions, the gods, the towns, etc.
 - It is well written.
 - The voice acting is great.
 - There is a ton of loot for every party member.
 - You have a keep that you use as HQ, which you can improve, defend and spend time there for bonuses.
 - The game-engine is fabulous: crisp, precise, things are explained on tool-tips.
 - Hover on top of statistics to see the detail of their calculations.

CONS
 - You must enjoy reading. You don't have to read 100% of the stuff (like I didn't read the in-game books) but most of the plot is delivered to you via text.
 - I would've taken a few more dungeons (Durlag's Tower (from BG1) is still the best dungeon IMO)
 - The Loading screens are long and they happen every time you change locations, which can happen often.

That's it! There's very little bad to say about this game. If you enjoyed Baldur's Gate I or II, Icewind Dale I or II, Ruins of Myth Drannor or the Temple of Elemental Evil (all similar titles), this one won't disappoint. It is better than many similar titles that preceded it.

Also, it is similar to Tyranny, which I also recommend and to Pathfinder: Kingmaker, once again recommended by me!

I have played more than 100 hours of the game and I can say I do recommend this game to others IF you like CRPGS, reading, and dense, story-driven gameplay.

First off, let me get through the bad - it's a slow burn, a slow startup, and you don't start feeling the rewards until after you're well into the first act. After acquiring your stronghold, moving onto ACT II the game picks up steam. By then you should be fully invested in the lore, the sidequests, the NPC quests, and looting.

The battle system is a bit tricky to get into and will turn you off if you're just used to defense being defense, attack being attack. See, there's about 4 defenses in this game with 3 attack modules. Enemies have different attacks and defenses and learning about which does which can be a chore most times. You can bully your team on a singular enemy, but when there's a mob you;ll need to have knowledge of the system so you won't spam reload.

The good: The story. I am enjoying this tale of cat and mouse as much as I can and never imagined playing this game to completion. The lore is rich and full of wander, but it's nothing compared to the choice driven narrative where you feel your actions have consequences. 

The game doesn't hold your hand nor does it suggest which decisions you make affects the overall state of the world, finding out only after you've made your choices - much like real life.  The game offers multiple difficulties you can try out depending on what kind of game you're expecting. For me, I play on normal since the game is already a slowburn as is and I didn't need threats being amped up for an already hard game. 

The music feels very John Williams and ushers you into the action, I'll say it feels like you're on the battlefield issuing commands and trying to survive attacks. Traveling is also not as labourious since you have fast mode which speeds up the gameplay to help you cover distances.

The characters are welcoming - though I didn't feel much for them in the beginning because of how generic they were at first, it wasn't until the meat of the storytelling kicked in that I crew to care about these misfits. Aloth will always be a charm and so is Hiravias. 

I recommend this game at 8/10.
