I've tried to get into this one multiple times. On paper a classic CRPG, it sounds like it would be right up my alley. However, I found the RPG system rather strange to get to grips with, and the initial forays into the world felt rather rudderless and filled with spiky pitfalls. In time I might have worked past those things, those are very much issues of familarity, but before I could reach that point of familiarity I kept finding myself unable to find the desire to stay engaged. It's a small thing really, objectively speaking.. the backer NPCs. 

They are just so frequently and jarringly implemented, starting quite near the beginning of the game. It may have only taken a straw to break the back of my desire to play but they are anvils. Just littering many locations that you must travel through, sometimes sprinkled among actually proper NPCs that actually exist in the world, there are these special gold-plated NPCs with fancy names. Click on one and you may be treated to a surreal 'Original Character Do Not Steal' backstory, generally filled with fanfiction-grade tropes and stereotypes. Even once I learned to just never click on them, I just could just feel them there, archives of other fictions written generally quite poorly (it only takes one hack writer among a dozen to leave a bad impression), as I tried to search about towns and taverns for quests.

Honestly they're just on my mind because I booted up the game again recently due to some lying Redditor saying there was an option in the settings to just turn them off. There isn't. There are some mods, actually a series of mods that would be required to be installed from outside steam, that slightly reduce the jarring nature of these kickstarter NPCs, but I can't find the enthusiasm to track them down, install them, make sure they're working, etc, just to make a game I didn't really enjoy a little more tolerable. 

In the end this is just another critical darling game that simply didn't capture me, but for my two cents I couldn't recommend it to anyone. I don't think the gaming world is any longer so starved for classic CRPGs that we have to keep something like this on a pedestal. It's good that they helped bring back the genre, but that doesn't mean I'd recommend playing it.

So, this game was kind of a disappointment to me for a multitude of reasons. Admittedly, none of them were deal breakers on their own.

I'll start with the most immediate: the visual style is rather tiring on the eyes. It's beautiful but it has very sharp color gradients. If you often get eye strain from games this is probably going to be an issue.

The game is poorly optimized, though not critically so. If you are running it on a lower end or older laptop it will continuously drain over 30% of the CPU, even in the start menu, and for me it would cause a massive racket from my laptop's ventilation, severely hindering immersion. In my opinion for an isometric game with no physics, this shouldn't be acceptable. I am guessing it's so demanding because it's actually running as a full 3D Unity game with an isometric camera, who knows. Besides that it has other weird optimization issues: it takes 20 to 30 seconds to go from area to area, presumably because it has no ahead-of-time loading. It also has a tendency to lag in the level-up menu.

I personally didn't find the combat *that* enjoyable. A weird quirk is that for most spells the game limits how many times a character may cast them per rest. You can rest anywhere with camping supplies, but the amount of those you can carry is limited and tied to difficulty. This made me anxious to use those spells much at all, in case I might need them later, especially since you can't really estimate when you'll get to restock on those camping supplies. Some may point out that the camping supplies are pretty common and worse case you can buy them at an inn, but if that's true what is the point of this mechanic anyway? If this was meant to be a punishment by having to backtrack to an inn, why is the number of camping supplies tied to difficulty, implying they constitute a test of skill? Besides this specific quirk, the combat was ok. I especially appreciate that every stat is clearly explained when you hover over it.

The lore of the game was interesting and the dialog was well written and voice-acted. It also has a bestiary which explained the nature of specific enemies, like the various types of ghouls, which I found interesting.

I hate that the game auto-saves at every new area and there's no way to turn that off. If you want to only keep meaningful saves you have to constantly delete auto-saves, cumbersome.

Weirdly I constantly dreaded having to level up because the game showers you with spells and abilities to choose from, causing, at least for me, massive choice overload.

Overall I don't massively dislike this game, but it didn't really meet my expectations. I hope this ramble will be useful to someone's purchase decision.

Finally got around to playing PoE several years after buying it on Steam. The point-and-click gameplay is very good. The graphics are still good, and the GUI is clear and easy to navigate. Sound and music in PoE is better than I expected. The game runs smoothly however as I progressed, I occasionally experienced choppiness in the audio during the second half of the game.

The story is good in the sense that it is mature, however I would say it is forgettable because the way it's told is not entirely interesting. While I liked 3 of the companions, I took a strong dislike to 3 others. I found the script-writing to be incredibly dull and their backstories were in general, good but not always with a sense of completion. By the time I had reached halfway through the game I was keen to see the game finished and didn't feel compelled to know how it ended - I just wanted it to end. Without a romance option for these characters either, there is again, little onus to continue wanting to know about their verbose history. The heavy intake of text based story too, drove me to NOT want to know more, but simply have it be done with.

The world your party exists in is generally believable but limits to very basic NPC conversation alongside heavy and reiterative discussions about the world's gods. You will find yourself a bit lost and at the mercy of the religiosity and without being able to interface with these gods, they are characters without features that you only read about. In terms of other selectable NPC's, the world is loaded with kickstarter funded NPC's that ultimately have no point to conversing with unless you again desire to download each characters history/memories/backstory that serve no real purpose. 

My biggest gripe, apart from the story, is with the spells in game. I just didn't find many of them useful for the scenarios presented. Some spellcasters had spells that I thought were for the most part, not terribly effective. I found myself reading descriptions of spells frequently and pondering what the point of casting those spells was - many went untested and untried with no compulsion to use them - the cleric is guilty of this, whereas he druid was an exception to this, finding he and the mage are useful for crowd control and support. 

Now, my primary was a moon Godlike cypher. However with insufficient 'focus' (ie.magical stamina), this build comes off neutered in battle - but it seems the choice most new players may opt for because it's different. It felt however, a mistake to use the cypher and it would perhaps be a case of trial and error to find the best build to capitalise on this type. 

I liked in-game mechanics such as camping,and the mechanics of the inventory. However, how stats would stack (ie the higher of two stats would be the only relevant stat rather than both stats adding together) really sucked and I found i couldn't always get a satisfactory assortment of items to equip on companions or myself. 

In terms of having little helpers follow you around, that is cute, but ultimately useless as they don't really do anything. Enemies are varied and keep you on your toes. You will constantly find that positioning and targetting however, rather than spell-use, can be the difference between a won or lost battle. 

I did not proceed with buying White March expansion DLC because I felt I had enough of the core game, didn't like its over-verbose and dull storyline and was happy it was finished with. 

Overall, where this 'wins' in comparison against the ever popular Baldur's Gate 2 would be its visuals, GUI and inventory management. These aspects of it are well done. Where it ultimately cannot match it is its story delivery, interesting interactions with companions, and the tactics or strategies needed in a battle. Sometimes brevity of dialogue and mystery works better than loads of text revealing an encyclopaedia of information about a character's history.

However, while I enjoyed this game better than the first Divinity Original Sin, overall I give it an 'it's OK' rating and therefore have to say I don't recommend it above better competition. I have found myself far more invested and enjoying Tyranny. If you want a fun isometric RPG and do not plan on getting PoE 2, then I would recommend you buy Tyranny instead. Or get PoE and PoE 2 if they're on sale only and you're in the mood to get invested in a great deal of text consumption with less interesting characters.

The game has a bug that has been ongoing since the beta.2022 as of this post and it still exists. Going all the way back to perhaps 2013. This bug makes some aspects of the game not work properly such as taking over 5 minutes to load character portraits on character creation. There are ways to mitigate it but for most part, none of which I have tried has had any favorable outcome. However, I have managed to get the base game to play without the audio going all over the place or have the stutter/freeze when opening inventory.

Despite that bug, the game is actually good in my opinion. I had it on gog a long time ago and never played it on steam. Decided recently to do so. Probably have 100+ hours in it from days of old. For it's time, it was actually good. On par with others such as Tyranny. If you like games such as Icewind Dale or Baldur's gate series, this is a good choice. Story isn't say as good as perhaps with Planescape Torment, but is decent enough to keep a person enthralled.

Wanted to give this a solid thumbs down but changed my mind after playing it again a bit. All I can say is,the game was enjoyable to me and still can be. For you, if you want that little bit of nostalgia from games of old but can't get them to work on modern hardware, this is a decent substitution despite the bug.

Although I have grown old and cynical over the years, therefor generally disliking most of the high fantasy worlds I have previously loved as a child and adolescent, I did enjoy the world of Pillars of Eternity enough to see it through. I am much more of a sci-fi person nowadays, so Torment: Tides of Numenera impressed me way way more than Pillars did. It was worse in every other aspect, but in terms of its world and atmosphere it was just light years ahead. A complete matter of taste though.

As with any Obsidian game, you know you will get top tier quality top to bottom. Mechanics, gameplay, story, world building. No stone remains unturned and everything has a rhyme and rhythm to it, something you only get from veteran studios with experience and passion. Characters are likable and have reasonable motives and expectations, they’re interesting, the stories of side quests and main quests are great, combat mechanics are great, the world is great. Everything these people touch will turn into gold, absolutely no question about it. 

So if you don’t mind the very conservative high fantasy setting, this is obviously a must play.
Fantastic
Love

overwhelming amount of stuff but once you get used to it (and maybe with the wiki) it's tolerable and quite fun.  the quests are pretty fleshed out, i imagine #2 is even better but unsure.  Definitely a time-sink though but even just completing a few quests can be pretty fun.  Doesn't really pick up until 10 or so hours in the game but if you enjoyed baldur's gate (at ALL) you'll likely dig this.  get it on discount 4sure
If you like Baldur's Gate rpg this is a good game to pick up and play.

A great game that harkens back to the older style of isometric RPGs such as Baldur's Gate while managing to stay fresh. Has a very well written story done by a team of people who really care (Obsidian). If you enjoy this style of RPG, you won't be disappointed.

Pillars of Eternity, to me, feels like a very thoughtful refinement of the classic Infinity Engine games it takes inspiration from. Whenever anyone tries to fix something old, however, they usually create new problems in the process.

Although it is a truly fantastic game, Pillars feels almost like an amalgamation of different eras and ideas. Baldur’s Gate is clearly the core inspiration and it serves as the foundation for what Obsidian would build, and what they would build atop it offers many technical improvements and generational updates - this is probably the best Real-Time with Pause combat has ever been in a CRPG (bar PoE2), but some aspects like the player base and fall a little flat.

The only true issue I truly have with Pillars is that I only truly understood what was going on in the story starting at Act 3. The first two acts were spent chasing vague clues because of an event that occurs at the start of the game, which itself I thought almost too convenient.

It still manages to redeem itself, though, because when it finally clicked with me then it retroactively made the first two acts better. Everything up to that point made complete sense - what at first seemed convenient then seemed logical.

At first I felt like the worldbuilding and lore was laid on a little thick, but then I began to appreciate it, and the direction that the game goes really requires it to have its own world. Eora is fantastic, and it's worth learning about.

And if you see people leaving negative reviews because of the so called ‘Backer NPCs’, just know that they really don’t matter. It’s flavour text written by Kickstarter backers and presumably edited by the game’s writers, and I have no idea how someone could consider it immersion-breaking since it helps make the world feel more alive. and many of the stories are really great.

There are many great companions, the soundtrack feels very Icewind Dale-esque, the story behind the plot is phenomenal, the world is vast but not overwhelming, and for the first time I actually played a CRPG on Hard on my first attempt and didn’t regret it  - the challenge just made it more fun.

That is to say, I love it. Please check out the second game as well as this one.
RPG classic

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.
The story was excellent, combat and strategy were unique and had a learning curve, however it was very well done once understood. This is a must play for CRPG fans.

I'm loving the game but I hate hate hate this one design decision. 

When working with the game's factions the first faction you accept the 2nd quest from locks you into being their ally for the rest of the game. This comes with very little warning from the Dozens, a good warning from the Knights, and idk how well you're warned by the Domeneneneels (or however you spell it). Just by accepting this quest you're permanently enemied to all other factions for the rest of the game. There is no way to back out of the quest once accepted. Naturally like a fool I accepted a second faction quest from the Dozens with the vague warning that it might annoy the Crucible Knights, but I accepted and was then unable to back out after they told me what the quest would have me doing. I did not anticipate the game to lock me out of the other factions by the second quest. 

Otherwise the games been a damn delight. I'm just really mad about this one bad design choice.

Its hard to put into words just how board I was with this game. The major issue being that I just have no idea what my overall goal is. Like I know because I started playing the sequel first and then came back since the two games seemed very interconnected. But if I hadn't done that I would have no idea what my overall goal is here.
The game starts and you're on your way to this new land that's offering cheap land and you're allowed to role play why you want a fresh start, right before your group is attacked and you're forced to flee with two other group members. One being a barbarian girl and the other being a warrior, which complimented my chosen class of wizard very well. You go through a tutorial dungeon that was so small I actively thought I had missed something inside it because I breezed through it. During this I learned about the barbarian girls sister and the reason she came to this land and agreed to be our guide and how it's all important and how I could relate to my own- Oh she's dead. They both are. Yeah it kills both of your party right after the tutorial dungeon and then sends you out into the world. Which being a wizard, a very squishy class, seemed like a terrible idea. Clearly they weren't expecting you to play wizard because as I stumbled my way to the first town what was the first actual companion they gave me? A wizard. Fucking hell.
After that the game takes a massive nose dive. It became clear that I wasn't here to settle down and build a new life but the game didn't really provide a new goal for me to work towards. It just kind of went "Bam! You're a watcher now!" which the game fucking bombards you with an NPC telling you all about watchers in very explicit and yet veg ways. And then just kind of went "Only you can figure out whats going on with the hollow born children" which I already know! You showed me the evil guy doing the evil thing right out of the tutorial dungeon to the big egg. But the game just kind of sends you out into the world at that point. So I went in the only direction that really seemed available to me, which was east, and then met a dude who told me that the castle was super defended and that I shouldn't go that way. So I went that way assuming that this was setting up an end game location that I'd need to visit later. No, actually that was the way you were suppose to go. So as my second actual quest in this game I did a raid on the lord of this place's keep, talked to his generals who told me a lot of stuff I had no context for, then killed him and replaced him with his cousin. This was all in hour 4 of the game. So castle cleared, local lord killed, chaos left in my wake, I ventured forth to... I honestly had no idea. Next on my bumbling destructive journey I met a priest who was a dick, joined my party, and then immediately died. I could have save scumed to keep him alive, but I had zero attachment to him so I continued on where I thought the plot would start: Caed Nua
Turns out no, not really. Instead I meet the former watcher of this place and he's insane and of no use. And this is when the game introduces the vaguest reason for my character to not leave and never come back (which is kind of an important quality for role playing): You might. Might. Go crazy. Which doesn't seem like that big of an issue since my wizard companion also knows about his previous life and isn't going immediately crazy. Honestly the way I read it it seems more like the series of lives this guy lived weren't compatible and that's what drove him crazy and it didn't seem like that was an imminent threat for my character. So I killed him, took over the keep and got no new direction. So I went to the only city on the map and found a new companion who was a ranger, so combined with the guy I got at Caed Nua I now had a party consisting of 4 ranged characters and 1 melee character, so my combat turned into throwing my one melee guy into combat well the rest sat in the back doing volley fire at the enemy which was pretty boring. After acquiring this new companion I step into the city and that completed act 1. How was that an act? I stumbled around for about 6 hours, stabbing up the first person who was slightly important with little idea what I was doing or where I was going.
It was at that point I just decided to open up a walkthrough and used that for the next few hours of gameplay. At about the 14 hour point I realised I was just doing what the walkthrough said and had no real investment in what I was doing. I just wasn't having fun, I was barely following what was happening and at that point why am I still playing?

If you love well-written RPG then this game is an absolute must have!
This might be the best written RPG I've ever played. You can really immerse yourself into the world of Eora, and what a beautiful world it is!
The gameplay mechanics is special and you have to get used to it, but once you get there it's just so much fun and on harder difficulty levels you really have to micromanage the fights.
That's another great thing about this game,the difficulty levels are well tuned: You just wanna have some story-time, discover everything and not have to worry about having to optimize every detail? Story-Mode it is. You want the maximum challange, having to retry certain hard fights over and over again for finally defeating the enemy with the last breath? Harder modes deliver.

Awesome game!

After 5 years starting in 2017 it is now 2022 in September and I finally finished the game! I recommend going on normal or easy mode and you will flow so much more easier through this game then me. I started on hard trying to get the achievement but I couldn't. Hard mode made me lose interest in the game itself and I couldn't progress at all for years. That is until I started playing a month from now in August where I changed the difficulty to normal and I could finally play again. I then had to go to easy cause even normal was hard at times. But overall the story was actually rich and the world was rich with history and things going on. I love how many choices you make affect so many things. They even reach into Pillars of Eternity 2 Deadfire. 

Overall I really liked this game after changing to normal and easy modes. Was way less frustrating and enjoyable.

A truly magnificent cRPG, harking back to the good, old times of Baldur's Gates, Icewind Dale's and other great adventures! Great, long, multi-layered story, carefully introduces you to the world, its factions, events and calamities that befalls them. Flesh-out companions, with their own quirks and quips, challenging enemies, dungeons and tombs full of loot (some fixed, some random), and mysterious, foreboding arch-enemy. Game is very accessible for more casual players, as well as hardcore, meta-gamers - lots of different builds, classes and the possibility to create a party, you create from ground up - perfect for hardest difficulty.
If you like cRPG's and have the time - buy it, it's worth the price.
The game is really immersive and it has great characters and story.

A very enjoyable game with beautiful graphics, rich story, and very strategical gameplay. It takes a while to get used to the combat but once you have that down, this game is a LOT of fun and you will easily lose track of how many hours have passed since you started up a session of PiOE (Pillars of Eternity for short since PoE could also refer to Path of Exile which this game is NOT). Definitely 5/5 stars!

Its fantastic!*

Narratively, its incredible! The presentation hits hard and the plot is quite clever, at least I found it so. But more than that, its a whole universe of very well written characters and lore, backed by beautiful landscapes. Countless hours on a single play-through this game is nothing but impressive. Fair warning though, it gets pretty dark at times.

Combat is real-time with pause and slo-mo, there's also fast-mode as well if you want to die faster, sometimes fast-mode can kill you when you're out of combat too. Class, ability, equipment, item and enemy variety is HUGE! You could spend days coming up with new builds and strategies, and there's a ton of cheese built in as well. People solo this game idk how tf you do that. Easy they say, fuck you I say. There's a LOT of combat in this game and it begs to be replayed, you could come up with a dozen different challenge runs in a few minutes!

Outside of combat the game offers you a lot of meaningful variety, Stealth mechanics are exceptionally polished, and you can talk your way out of almost any situation if you got the reputation and/or skills for it. There's often multiple paths to both a peaceful and murderous resolution, and the game does a fantastic job of making you feel the consequences of your actions, both in the long and short-term, and always surprisingly fairly. It really gets you invested in the world and role-playing, helped out by the fantastic soundtrack.

If you have the patience for it, this is one of the greatest RPGs of all time! You should definitely play it. The sequel is also very very good.

cRPG fans beware and think twice.

I like cRPGs and after finishing a trilogy run of Baldurs Gate I felt it was time to finally come back and give PoE another shot. This review is as much for future me as it is for a few buyer, so that I can look back at this and go "Ah ha" at why I ever didn't finish what otherwise seems like a good game. I'm just going to list out cons, as the pros are readily apparent, but what might kill the game for a lot of people is hidden deeper than what a trailer might suggest.

Cons

Characters
1. Immersion breaking kickstarter backer content shoved directly in your face at every step, which then leads io a revelation that if it were not for the kickstarter goal NPC inserts the game would be almost dead and devoid of actual people to talk to. After walking into a tavern upon arrival to the first big city area of the game reminisce of Baldurs Gate or other similar hubs, I'm greeted with about 12 characters scattered around with interesting names and gold plates.  You can't actually talk to them. Click them and you get to read a short story which is unrelated to the plot and not written by the games creators. They got rid of this in PoE2, but the fact that they still exist here and you can't turn them off is horrible choice and not helping the brand of this series since people will likely want to play the series from the beginning. They totally take you out of immersion and therefore are even worse than generic commoner/thief/warrior npcs. At least when you talk to those, they might actually say something relevant to the game they are in, or speak of something ACTUALLY happening in town. Absolutely inexcusable. The knife in the heart of this game. I shouldn't find more kickstarter NPCs than do real people in any given area. This happens in many of the "populated" areas!

Story
2. I'm sure the story ends up getting good towards the end, but I can not sit through the flood of lore dumping that this game considers a "conversation." More is not always better, and this game's writing is a great example of that. When it's not lore dumping at you, you're having conversations with a lot of words referring to (boring) places, people and concepts that the game somehow expects you to be familiar with already. NPCs in this game do not talk like regular people. Your companions are fine, though from what I got from them, they were still lacking, and suffered from the problem of talking about things that I have no idea or context for despite the lore dumping, and asking me to help them do things I don't understand the relevance of and doing very little to make you actually care about them until much later in. The fact that you can make your own party of generic, storyless NPCs at any Inn is a good measure of how important those characters are to the plot/game. I applaud anyone who does their own world building and create an original setting, but that's not the problem. The problem is the absolutely poorly written characters and dialogue, and the heavy focus on dreamlike sequences and esoteric concepts. I LOVE esoteric concepts, but I also like playing a cRPG with good characters and storyline. This game, despite being very well written, is very poorly written. It's like having a hi-tech superweapon in your hands and being tasked with shooting a single target, and instead they just spray wildly and hit everything but the one thing they needed to. They spend 500 words in a section that would have been much better with 100 that got to the point. 

Gameplay
3. The gameplay is decent enough but nothing to write home about at a surface level. My issue with it can be summed up in a couple examples. There are lots of abilities and spells in the game. At first you might think wow, that's a lot of diversity, and they are all original and different. Nope. There are a lot of fancy names for things, but they all come down to doing the same thing with different names. Very little is unique in this game, very little will actually illicate dopamine with their use. The fighting is just a means to an end, and if you're expecting magic to blow your socks off, you are in for a real dissapointment. There was little I found to be interesting, besides a few Cipher abilities that make sure of a beam gimmick. Otherwise it's just DnD spells with their power and lore nerfed for balance.

The game wants you to play it a certain way, from the gameplay, to the story. This is the illusion of a crpg. It pains me to say this, because the game does a lot right, but not nearly enough to overcome the many many many many bad ideas that I can only blame on the project manager and writer.

Some may like this game, but it is by no means for everyone and it is NOT a successor to Baldurs Gate. 

It's not the best, it's not the worst. It's just dissapointing.

This rating is based on preference.

While the worldbuilding was cool, the delivery of the narrative was in shambles. I felt myself struggling to appreciate the story and characters. There were interesting aspects to the classes, and plenty of unique ways to play them, but the gameplay just didn't do it justice (the skills just feel so bad, im sorry).

The best thing about this game, by far, is the non-story lore. Unfortunately, I didn't like how it was presented, and found myself often trying to dig for it. 

Lots of things to like, but the attention this one got baffles me. There are many better crpgs to play, especially if you crave a meaningful story.

Though, the ending was great, completing this game felt like a chore to me.

If you are cool with text boxes, get ready to love this game. It's text heavy, but that gives way to a rich story filled with loveable characters and moments. It may not be full 3-D like its contemporaries, but it doesn't detract from it being a more true RPG. In [i]Pillars[/i], all of your choices matter, from character creation to dialogue and action.

It's [i]Baldur's Gate[/i] with all the old awkward video game jank sanded off, which is surprisingly engaging and fun.

My only real gripe with this game is the way the boss fights are implemented. 
First of all having to go back through the entire text box/cutscene ever time you fail is super annoying. 
Secondly there is no real scaling when it comes to boss fights. I feel like the general mobs were paced pretty well, but when it comes to a boss fight you could be literally cruising through the mobs then BAM! Heres a boss that 1 shots your entire party with an AOE and has defences so high that you can barely scratch them. 

I have no issue with learning how to beat a difficult enemy, or with spending time trying to beat tough boss. However, I dont like the jarring swap between feeling like your party is well balanced, and with a good composition when fighting the mobs, and then getting absolutely crushed by a random boss fight as if you've got the worst group of individuals you could have rounded up. I feel like the bosses needed to be a bit more creative in terms of arena/mechanics rather than just straight up being OP and forcing you to bash your head against the brick wall until you work out what spells you need to spam for 20 minutes to get the job done.

Before I get into the Review, I would like to clear some ideas and tropes. This isn't a "retro" game. This is a modern rendition on a particular style of RPG play. First person dungeon crawlers were some of the first games ever made in graphical format...Is Fallout 3+, Mass Effect and Skyrim "Retro"? This belief about isometric RPG's actually came about from certain game developers feeling the need to trash this style of play, perhaps in response to customer feedback. 

POE is a faithful and modern interpretation of a tabletop style RPG on a computer, with a complex set of rules and environments to create a consistent world to play a set story in. I won't mince words, this style of play is not for everyone, and much of the criticism of this type of game comes not from the game itself, but an expectation from the player of a generic "fun" or engagement based on vague assumptions. Games like this have random numbers, dice rolls, large amounts of reading and an requirement for the player to be part of the enjoyment process. If you can do that, you will enjoy this game, If you can't, I recommend something that requires a little less thought and patience. 

I'll only review 2 aspects of the game, the most important ones: Combat and Story

Combat: The skill system is vast, the classes very customizable and options almost unlimited...which is both good and bad. For the good, you can do anything you want, and for a roleplayer invested in playing to type, the building of the character is great (other problems with the story however, I will discuss in STORY). The action is a bit frantic. If you are used to Baldur's Gate or (amazing if you remember and played this) Ultima 7, you will feel right at home with your hand on the pause button. I prefer the control of turn based, but it's not bad at all. The game does reward you for knowing what you want and pushing for it early, and the sad truth is there is a "right way" to build your character amid options that will cause you nothing but trouble. 

Story: This  is pretty subjective, and I can't help but appreciate the tremendous work and time that went into the world building, story and characters. It's truly vast and epic. So I'm a little sad to say over the years of owning this game, I've never really enjoyed the story that much, or got invested in it's world. Much of the worldbuilding is too vague. It's hard to tell a real cultural difference between the races and factions of the game. The Characters do a little better with the myriad twists and connections. The Dyrwood is a diverse collection of races who fought for independence from the Aedyr empire...another diverse collection of races, and there's another country...which is also a diverse collection of races. All with very similar attitudes, social mores and prejudices. 

I'm not a fan of animancy either, which I feel turns a gritty world into play-do and makes literally "anything" possible which just means there's no foundation for anything. The world loses it's heft as everything just becomes a plaything of an overarching ability. Dragon age suffered from this sort of plot design too, where the darkspawn were just a mindless evil thing that has no ecology of it's own. Evil is just an attitude, rather than calculated decision making...except from the mastermind of it all...playing with play-do. 

That said, the confrontations and story beats are exciting, and I enjoyed it from an adventure standpoint, even as I kind of wished the world they worked so hard to build had better foundations.

I highly recommend this game for those that like isometric play and a solid party rpg experience

Having finished the game, I'm going to update my review. I went into this game with pretty positive expectations, and came away uncertain with how I feel about the title as a whole. Though, I think I can chalk it up to a mostly positive experience. Albeit, with a lot of very notable shortcomings, pitfalls, and issues along the way.

To keep this edit short, I'll try to focus on the main points.

Gameplay:
There is a lot of fun in the gameplay early on. while the litany of terms that change and get bandied about take hours to get used to, its not so bad. I wish they were more straight forward in some instances, but otherwise it's to be expected with an RPG like this. Especially one that does do its best to bring out interesting tactical choices and options. However, I feel the gameplay gets very stale, very fast, and the difficulty curves on Normal and above really don't do you any favors. Pathing failures are constant. Conversations denying you party formations can raise the difficulty on fights severely. Even further along, there are cardinal sins where standard enemies you're used to 1-tapping suddenly have unmarked, unrelated, unidentified, and unnoticeable upgraded variants that jump you in almost the same numbers you'd expect trashier versions. The only way to tell is to mouse over them, wait, and see the tooltip pop up with their stats - or lackthereof. Especially since the niche tactics never really advance beyond early game levels; if anything, they devolve as you can afford to use fewer elaborations and take fewer hits.

RPG Mechanics & Framework / Meta-gameplay / Genre Accuracy:
We already discussed gameplay, yes. Though, this is the framing of that gameplay as a title, and how it interacts with the story, text elements, and the rewards of the system. And this is where the game REALLY fails for me. This game commits EVERY cardinal RPG Game sin in the book, despite having come out with knowledge of the genre from devs with industry experience. Crafting is abundant, but doesn't seem to be wholly worthwhile until the absolute endgame with an extreme resource crunch. Even then, you run into the problem of only getting the best gear after you've toppled all your foes in an area. Side content offers barely any XP except for a few "mainstory-adjacent" storylines, and so your seriously gatekept by mainstory progression. The voiced, storied companions have some of the WORST pre-existing build configurations I've seen - so you either need to rebuild them (if you can), or skip them for empty husks you create yourself at taverns. This game's framing really hurts it as an RPG, and it required many long breaks and bouts of frustration for me to finish the story. But it's not the story or base gameplay that fails.

Story:
Pretty darn good. The beginning is really slow, even for someone like me that really likes slow-start stories. Though, I think the main issues in meta-gameplay and genre-accuracy are what make that worse. Act 2 really shines. Act 3 slows down again, and I have to admit, due to my frustrations, I rushed down the mainquest in a day. The epilogue spikes back up with a great twist that brings us full circle. Its not terribly original. It strikes as a very Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind type story, but original enough to still be fun. I think there are some issues with the conclusion that match the issues of pacing in the beginning, and maybe some buyer-beware over potential plot-threads that are never really resolved.

In the end, we get a game that is probably worth playing through on its easiest difficulties. I wouldn't really recommend anything else. There are RPGs that are way older, and way newer, and contemporary with this one, with stories that are just as good, if not better. Not to mention, they're more rewarding to play as a game itself.

Still, I'd say give this one a shot!

Pillars of Eternity is a game that asks a lot of questions. Questions such as: "Does religion undermine the concept of free will?", "Is it ethical for positivist science to ignore the mental well-being of the majority in exchange for progress in the abstract?", and most importantly: "How the heck do you make a game like Baldur's Gate enjoyable for a modern audience?"
Pillars is a major improvement on retro RPG's that, unlike other latecomers, takes into account all the innovations that have come since, adding a lot of convenience while still maintaining the retro feel.
The story and setting were a pleasant surprise, with the standard chosen one plot gradually expanding as the game progresses, while the world shifts from standard fantasy to late medieval/early renaissance to tribal. Main quests also escalate in complexity, but always involve moral choice, as do quite a lot of side stories. Unfortunately, these outcomes aren't well telegraphed, and often seem illogical, especially when it comes to side and companion quests. The writing itself is standard Chris Avelone: decent ideas and easily readable, but lacking character and literary craftsmanship. As a result, player companions have interesting gimmicks and personal quests, but lack individuality. 
Combat is also enjoyable, with well-designed encounters and solid soundscape, especially for spells and buffs. The ability to upgrade equipment, including uniques, ensures the Skyrim-like loot system where you can strip every character down to their pants remains useful.
Finally, the music is quite decent as well, with most major locations having a unique theme. Though it is not as memorable as, say Baldur's Gate, it serves its purpose of adding a quality atmosphere to exploration and combat. Where sound truly shines, though, is voice acting: it took me until the credits to figure out that the first two companions you meet are voiced by the same actor. The game is far from fully voiced, as even a lot of cutscenes rely on speech bubbles, but your companions are all enjoyable (Except for Durance, who is the worst companion in the game: annoying voice, unpleasant personality, useless role, and nonexistent quest).

Even as someone who could never get into retro RPG's (I only got on board after 2004, when we got Neverwinter Nights and VTM Bloodlines) I found Pillars to be highly enjoyable. While its sequel has higher production value, it is not nearly as interesting as the first game. This is an easy recommend for fans of the genre, as well as people who are trying to get into old-fashioned RPG's.

FINAL SCORE: 8/10

Pillars is a heavily D&D/Baldur's Gate inspired CRPG made with clear love for the genre by the guys from obsidian, although few of the original devs remain in the company.
First thing that got my attention is that there is a lot of loading. Plenty of transitioning between areas, many tiny areas like houses would be best if they were pre-loaded for faster access, or load in the background while you roam the map. It gets significantly worse as time goes on since every transition of the game autosaves, and more data keeps adding to the game, making the save time longer. The game keeps 3 autosaves that you can not disable in the options. After years later and plenty of people asking for a simple box to disable autosaves that prolong the already numerous loading screens, the developers decided to not add this simple option.
The fights are pretty straight forward real time with pause with two health bars system that's not great. Plenty of per encounter abilities and daily spells are at your disposal. At higher levels, the fights become quite a mess of many abilities and spells being used constantly, especially because of the real time with pause style. This game would gain much from a turn based system similar to old games like Fallout, Arcanum, or the new Pathfinders. Micromanaging 6 characters in real time with pause can be a nightmare at higher levels, especially dealing with area spells. An option to make the combat straight turn based would be great, but it was never implemented. One of my favorite crpgs, Arcanum, did it in 2000.
The story is just some noise in the background. Something about The Watcher and the evil guy dynamic, or the ending twist simply did not got me interested. It is not objectively bad but simply not charming enough, fun or spectacular to engage, especially with the many, many exposition dump ghosts you find along the way.
If you just focus on the main quests the game is surprisingly short, making it easier to get certain achievements. A short main story is not necessarily a bad thing since it does not constrain you with dumb timed events or pressure you into progressing (like Pathfinder's), letting you free to explore the pretty maps and find plenty of treasure and side quests, althought few of them are interesting, chiefly the souldbound ones.
It's not a bad game, but it is kinda bland and forgetful. You will not see people talking about Eder, Aloth, Pallegina, other companions or any of the npcs. I never saw on forums anyone mention the main villain, ever. It simply does not hit the spot of greatness. The game will give you a fun time, but I think it is difficult to make a remark because of its blandness.
If it wasn't for the beautiful maps, care for new combat mechanics, many spells and abilities and obvious love put by the devs I would not recommend Pillars.
Also, locking an achievement for kickstarter backers only is evil, don't do this kind of thing.

This game is, for me, a dream come true, this is why:
Since I've discovered D&D which is the pinnacle of RPG, I just couldnt play any RPG out there, I felt pretty much no satisfaction on grinding my days off or just doing quests all day long for just a piece of lore and a bunch of coins, and this game right here had all the answers I was seeking (heres the review part):
•U have the lore as you explore and complete the main campaigns, this, plus dialogues with the pre-made chars that can join your party while u play the game make for a very lore friendly game and content in a manner that is rarely seen these days
•Gameplay is pretty much the same always, but u will constantly have to change your strategy once u level up and/or face new/different enemies, since some enemies will strike u down in a matter of seconds if  you're to close to each other, others will rush down some of your characters if they're too far away from each other, and bad decisions are paid costly, but all of this at a reasonable rate, it doesnt feel like the game is hard, it feels like u need to improve and adapt, which is too, something thats rearely seen these days, chars are overcompensated or you just become a godlike being that cant be matched anyway, this wont happen here even if you decide to max out your whole party (the encounters will be easier).
•U're told what to do, u arent told how to do it, so, if, say, u have to go from A to B, u'll need to find ur way trough dialogue, quest journal and exploration, there are no map markers here nor a path, this is bliss, exploration in this game is well rewarded and a necessary thing, other games just go straight to the point which just kill immersion (if not even entirely disrupting it).
•U can try out builds, party mixes and so on, maybe not as much as u would like because u'll need a new party member each time (which in the late game is not hard at all because money stops being a problem, mostly), this allows u to try plenty of combinations, doesnt feel like u're stuck with the things u chose first and have to go on like that, makes freedom of choice a real feel,
•Dialogue with NPCs is key, spending time talking to people or mobs can change the final result of things entirely
•Reputation in cities is a thing, u just cant do everything carefree, sometimes is worth being a feind, and somethimes its better to be well liked (and this feature is one of my favorites even tho it could go even further on the implications it has).

I could go on, but those are the biggest details I can give without really spoiling everything about the game and making the review feel like an eternity to read. Well invested money right here.

I know some people are put off by the lack of voiced dialogue but the writing in this game is superb in my opinion and I enjoy reading it. I had played Wasteland 2 and the original Divinity before this game, but this was the game that made me appreciate the CRPG genre the most.

This is a love letter to classic CRPGs, and it does a really good job of it. The gameplay had that classic feel while avoiding some of the overcomplicated pitfalls, it has fantastic lore, a well-written story, and some incredibly likeable characters. The graphics are fine, but clearly not the main focus, and the gameplay is just full of cool little bits, like selecting where in the world your character is from, that make it feel more like classic tabletop RPGs. It does have a few pitfalls though - occasionally it is frustratingly difficult (I had to turn off level scaling for the White March DLC) and I think the end, avoiding spoilers, really robbed the player of a lot of agency compared to the rest of the game. Still an extremely good RPG overall.

There are many people on the internet who says you need 100hrs to fully "grasp" a game to be able to realy say if it is good or not, to which I say... nonsense. It is more like 1-2hrs, if the game does not have you by than, it is game over. I have "just" 4hrs on pillars of eternity and I hated every minute of those, had to force me to play through each minute.

Basicaly on the outside everything seems fine. You check gameplay videos, ingame screenshots and it is ok, thats why you decide to buy, and then you start playing. The character creation is normal, just what you would expect, nothing special, but not bad, you read through races, then clases, then the stats, then the abilities, you can select your own custom made picture, seems fine. At some point you start and are thrown into the game. And thats where the problems seem to start.

My starting character was killed twice in the first two fights of the game. Fun thing, I start every game on easy to learn the ropes first. So it should not have happened, thats why tutorials, prologues etc are in a game. Start slow, draw the player in. Not here. Something like that did not happen in any other I played (not to such degree). Whatever, I figured it out, but also, the whole fight mechanic is no fun to me. There is no taunt, no engaging, nothing, all enemies go for the most weak character on the field, so your "tank" fihts them and the other just runs around. 

The GUI seems functional and ok in videos and screenshots, but ingame it is weird, I could not get used to it. Weird positioning, weird functions. Keybindings also seem not to work properly, like ALT is used by default for something, I chaged it, want to use ALT for something else, but that does not work. Nothing happens. So there are functions you can change the keybind and some where you can change but it does not work, also some keys do not work for a specific function you want.

SFX is solid, BGM reminds me of baldurs gate ... Gfx is .... well everything is too small.

The text, world, story seems to me dry and clumsy, uninspired, uninteresting. I had no fun reading it all. And there is a lot of reading, much more then actualy action to do something.

But what realy killed the game for me are the loading times... the maps to play on are small, maybe they get bigger later on, but in the beginning, they are realy small... and there is a lot of loading. Like in the first "town", that is not even a village. 4 buildings... like 2s walking time from each other... click door... 10s loading time...talk to the NPC for 4s... and get realy bored as the text is meh... and leave the house for another 10s loading, then walk to next house for 2s, enter... load... read... load...
the writing isnt in the same league as Disco Elysium and the lore get laid on a little too thick at times, but a rewarding experience in the same vein of baldurs gate.
Deep Story, great characters, and lots of combat.

Obsidian nailed it with this one. A classic CRPG that attempts to revive an almost forgotten genre. I know I've barely scratched the surface of this game so far, but I am impressed. If you take the time to follow all of the lore, the team built an amazingly detailed world for us to play through. This game is definitely not for you if you are looking for non-stop action, or you just hate reading. But if you're okay with wandering around towns, talking to random NPC's and doing random odd jobs for them you will get submersed into a wildly detailed world. The visuals never disappoint. The combat can be rather difficult at times, and takes way more thought than most modern games. I didn't grow up around CRPG's, but have been slowly picking through the "classics". I am so glad that Obsidian took the time to bring live to this genre once again. I've already purchased PoE 2 and can't wait to play through both stories. 

Extra bonus, you can run this game on practically any modern computer. And with one hand for that matter. I've been playing on a 2017 macbook that has a terrible built in intel GPU and it runs and looks flawless.

10/10 you must buy.
Has the feeling of a good old Baldur's Gate.

Pillars of Eternity is one of my favorite games of all times even with its issues with a mediocre leveling system and difficult to read combat at times. 

Obsidian are experts with enthralling stories and meaningful player choice and PoE delivers on both fronts almost as well as Fallout New Vegas. Though New Vegas is better than this due to a more original setting and wacky characters, this is easily one of the greatest fantasy stories in video games with mature themes and fantastically interesting and deep companions (Eder, Aloth, Durance, Pallegina). 

Combat is similar to classic cRPG's (Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale) but the screen gets too busy to understand what goes on at times and the leveling system feels unrewarding but is still very, very fun. 

If cRPG's don't seem interesting enough or you don't feel willing to try it for a steep price, then just pick the game up on sale. The story alone is worth it and you might even fall in love with a new RPG subgenre you never expected like me.
It's my favorite game.

This game has a beautiful story. An absolute masterpiece compared to other RPGs. 
The graphics and textures are what they are, and the art is great in my opinion. Be willing to let your mind fill in the graphical blanks, and you'll find a beautiful game reminiscent of ye olde Baldur's Gate. 
The combat and class progression are fun after a time investment, but they probably won't be at first. Real-time combat in a DnD based combat system was never something I enjoyed much, but it manages to be passable in Pillars. Just be willing to use party AI lest you spend 75% of every combat encounter with a beetle paused to delegate actions. Chain commands are a thing, but I find that the flow of combat will often make my chain of commands redundant after two actions. Class progression is not as complex as other DnD style RPGs, but it's still enjoyable. Max level is 16 with the expansions so be prepared for a slow progression. 
Overall, I highly recommend the game. Importing your character to Deadfire is very satisfying, and I don't recommend playing it without completing Pillars 1 first.

The core gameplay is rather janky, a lot of things that even older games like Baldurs' Gate 2 could get right. There's a lot of good in it, the combat was fun and I enjoyed the classes, but it's the little niggling things, like the pathing getting stuck on someone despite the fact that there's a clear path to the side if they just take two steps to the left.

The story was phenomenal. I loved every step of the way. It had a lot of fantastic story-telling tips, that let it tailor itself well to you, and a lot of things that DM's could learn for their D&D campaigns. Making the companions truly feel like they matter, instead of just being followers.

But the part that gets this a No instead of a Yes despite the jank, is what I offer as a warning.

Despite the fact that The White March Part 2 does nothing to draw you in, and make it feel worth continuing (due to how perfectly they end Part 1, and the intro to Part 2 feeling so disconnected and unrelated to it), if you do not complete it, it will impact the ending in a way that is incredibly unsatisfying. Absolutely do not skip it.

You are a fresh arrival in the fictional country of Dyrwood, just in time to discover it's been wracked by an ongoing, fifteen-year long epidemic that has resulted in more than half the country's children being born with missing souls. You also encounter a mysterious cult leader, after which you gain the ability to see ghosts, and are haunted by memories of your past life that will drive you insane unless you and your (optional) ragtag band of adventuring companions can find him again before you succumb to madness. Oh, and maybe you'll save the country in the process.

Explore the countryside, fight monsters, get involved in politics, and bathe yourself in Deep Lore (TM) as you adventure with your own curated band of DnD OCs, or team up with other adventurers with their own goals and ambitions, all the while making memorable allies and enemies over the course of your quest, featuring voice talents such as:

Matthew Mercer,
Coffee Dad from Persona 5,
Matthew Mercer,
Mitsuru Kirijo from Persona 3,
Matthew Mercer,
Joseph Jostar from Jojo's Bizarre Adventure: Stardust Crusaders,
And Matthew Mercer!

For the best experience, also install the White March: Parts 1 and 2 DLCs, where you start your adventure by saving a remote fishing village from a raiding ogre clan, and ends with you doing couples' therapy for a pair of estranged gods.

As you depart on your quest, remember: do not dump might on your casters, spam overwhelming amounts of CC, and Charisma (Resolve) is an amazing stat.

With over 240 hours on record, this is one of my top 3 favorite games on Steam at the moment. 

This is hands down THE spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate 1&2 (please ignore Baldur's Gate 3, which should probably be titled Divinity: Original Sin 3, instead 3--long story). 

But back to this game: 

Pro's:
--Lots of options for character customization and developement. 
--Large cast of Party NPCs with classes that feel very unique
--Choices and quest outcomes matter, with interesting and sometimes surprising outcomes
--Exploration highly rewarded with items and "hidden" items, similar to BG1&2
--Expansive Dialogue--it's a lot but it's also very interesting. 
--Not a cookie-cutter setting: Fantasy with elements of gothic/cosmic horror and at times dystopian bent. 
--Social interactions interesting and very rewarding from a gameplay sense. 
--Active strategic combat with pause feature to issue commands to party members (very similar to BG1&2).
--Magic is pretty fun.
--has an optional megadungeon with lots of secrets.

Con's:
--successful kickstarter led to dozens/hundreds of nameplate inclusions throughout game (graveyards, random plaques, etc) so at first you will go up to read something and then realize it's a kickstarter icon. Eventually you learn which icons are kickstarter icons and you learn to ignore it, but it can hurt immersion. 
--At times is very dialogue heavy. In a similar vein to BG1&2. Voice acting does help. 

Overall: 9.5/10 

Note; PoE is wayyyy better than PoE 2 (Sequel has much weaker story imo, and also tended to be buggy).

Need distinction between, "not recommended," and, "recommend against." I don't recommend against this, but, can't recommend it. 

While mostly enjoyable, it has some serious drawbacks that you apparently only learn through trial and error. READ EVERYTHING, do not ASSume that anything is logical or like other games. 

Be completely thorough (including all info pages), don't miss anything (in game or in its rules), or the game punishes you.  It has a specific order it wants things done in, otherwise enemies are ridiculously difficult or easy (and that's one of those trial-and-error things).  While bonus increases commonly seem low, at one level, a certain type of enemy slaughters the party casually, then, two levels later, you can let AI drive with everyone set not to use limited abilities and barely suffer scratches. 

The info pop-ups (hovering over highlighted words) are essential, particularly with things like figuring out that NO bonuses stack (it only uses the highest, "suppressing" all others).  But, sometimes that they're most needed, like, "what does it mean that Might helps healing, is that giving, receiving, only recuperating, or some combination?" you get nothing.  (Answer: Might is essential for fighters as usual, plus mages, priests, paladins, chanters, druids & whatnots for all types of spells'/prayers' potency.) 

Also, they confuse a surprising amount of words, especially (as a not-really-as-linguistic example), "clever," for, "rude." 

Really, it was at least as much my fault, just went in playing like other games of its ilk, was 167 hours in (having restarted realizing earlier mistakes) before SEEING that the bonuses on much of the party's equipment were, "suppressed," on the character page, then hovering on that to read why.  But, that was the last straw, there was a lot of just feeling messed with rather than challenged. 

I largely liked the text-heavy aspect, but, it seems like, they took into account that a lot of D&D players seem to love just scouring rule books for hours at a time, and made it more for those. 

Might go back to it, and if opinion improves, I'll update this.  Otherwise, if it says I've played a hundred hours since, that just means I kept being hopeful. If a thousand since, and not updated, I've been being an overly optimistic moron, and the opining above still stands. 

[Edit: at 233 hours, mods help a little, but, the above still stands, and no game should NEED them.]

Pillars of Eternity is one of those games that we can thank for the new golden age of cRPGs. It is clear that the developers at Obsidian weren't the only ones craving for new adventures in worlds full of dungeons and dragons since they actually managed to fund this game using Kickstarter.

Obsidian has really tried to create a new fantasy world to stand out in the crowd. The events happen in a world of Eora, in a country called Dyrwood. Different fantasy races inhabit the world, but again, the humans are the most common. Dyrwood is a place, where the locals still remember a war against a neighboring country that happened some ten years ago. A god named Eothas was leading an army via earthly vessel called Waidwen. The Dyrwoodians stood against the assault and eventually blew up the god. Soon after the war people start being born without a soul, rendering them Hollowborn. People believe this is Eothas' doing for getting blown up, so people start calling the phenomenon Waidwen's Legacy.

Several years later the player arrives in Dyrwood, but not without problems. The travel caravan gets assaulted and the player must seek shelter from a rare soulstorm in a sacred old ruins. In its backyard the player encounters a shady cult doing some kind of a ritual with a machine that seems to devour souls. At the same time the player's soul experiences an Awakening, which allows the player to see some events of their soul's former life times. The player want's to know what's going on and learns that they are a Watcher, someone who can inspect other creatures' souls. What caused the Waidwen's Legacy? Can the shady cult give you answers about soul's Awakening? To these questions the player and the adventurers you'll meet along the way try to find answers.

The world of Pillars of Eternity is crafted with love and care, and the same can be said about the graphical design. The graphics weren't cutting edge even during this game's launch, but the style is distinctive and they seem to stand the test of time. Played from isometric viewpoint, the player can experience these nice, painting like landscapes in their best form. The game has an okay soundtrack and the sound effects are good. Especially the spells during combat sound cool. The voice acting is very good, at least when there is voice acting. Probably like half of the dialogue unfortunately lacks voice overs.

Pillars of Eternity uses a character creation system that is familiar to fans of tabletop RPGs, yet this is Obsidian's unique system. For example, points in Might increase character's damage dealt and healing, while Intellect increases the area of AOE abilities. You can't increase your ability points by leveling up, but some items or consumables may increase them for a while. After that you give your character some talents and abilities, which you also unlock more by leveling up.

The player travels the world doing all sorts of quests. For example, you'll come across a merchant, who'll warn you of a mighty bear who killed his friend. After investigating further, with your Watcher abilities you'll discover it was in fact the merchant, who wounded his friend in a way he wouldn't be able to escape the bear. You can avenge the friend's spirit by attacking the merchant or you can demand money from him. Or you might talk to the merchant, and he may reveal that his friend abused his wife, and now the merchant and said wife are starting new life together. This theme of grey choices is with you the whole game, you can't ever really say which is the right choice. You'll just make decisions and live with them.

Apparently a relic from some older cRPGs is the fortress you can acquire pretty early on in the game. The fortress serves as a home for the player and their companions. You can spend resources to upgrade the fortress, but a mighty hall attracts all kinds of outlaws, so you'll also have to spend money in your defenses so you don't lose all your taxes to bandits. You get a prison in your fort, where you can place some characters you'll end up capturing during the game. Tough the fortress has a major pest problem. In the 15 levels of dungeons below the castle lies all sorts of dangerous foes from beetles to forest trolls. Maybe the most hardest fight of the base game is located in the lowest level. At least I couldn't beat that fight.

The fights happen like in the classic cRPGs: Real time strategy with pause. When a battle begins, you'll want to pause the combat immediately, issue orders for your characters and the un-pause the combat to see what happens. After a few seconds the battle goes to some direction and you may want to pause again to issue new commands. It may get tiresome after a while to issue the same commands every time, especially if your party consist of six people. Luckily you can give your characters AI scripts that determine how they'll act during the combat. Basically you'll set how aggressive or defensive they are and what kind of skill sets they'll use, for example whether your wizard is more focused on casting damaging or crowd controlling spells. You can also determine if they are allowed to use per rest skills. Resting is an important feature. When your characters get wounded or they have used all of their spells, resting in tavern, fort or in wilderness with camping supplies, will restore all health and spells.

Even though I'm a big fan of real time strategy games such as StarCraft and WarCraft, I found the combat in Pillars of Eternity to be quite difficult at times, especially at the beginning. One of the reasons was that it takes some time in the game to gain a well balanced party, since you'll encounter some of the companions well past the mid game. For example, on my first two tries of trying to play this game I was struggling in the beginning. I just couldn't do enough damage, since the first two companions you'll encounter are a crowd controller and a tank. At my third attempt at the game I chose monk class for dealing damage and then I started to slowly make some progress. You could solve this problem by recruiting some adventurers in taverns, but why would you do that when the developers have created such cool companion characters in the game? A better fix would be that if you could find all the companions in the beginning of the game, but unfortunately not.

The game runs reasonably well. My system has a Ryzen 5 5600X, RTX 3060 Ti and 16 GB of RAM, and I played the game at 1440p resolution. The game definitely doesn't have a lot of graphical options to choose from, but I had the graphics quality slider set to high. The game ran most of the time at around 90 frames per second. Except in late game areas and in The White March expansions the game would often drop to around 40 fps. This indicates a lack of optimization. But other than that the game ran well without crashing even once.

Pillars of Eternity brings this old genre back to newer generation, but maybe it has too much outdated mechanics from the older games. For example the inventory is horrible. You'll end up picking up things and putting them in the endless stash, except when you are going to sell stuff from the stash and you have 10 pages worth of stuff there, the game seems to start running quite slowly. Also the character creation is kind of annoying since you don't know what kind of skills and stuff you'll unlock down the road, you'll just have to experience them by yourself.

Anyhow, great story, interesting world and companions make this game a nice experience. Once you get the hang of the combat mechanics and manage to gather a competent party, the game is nice to play. There are still a few boss fights and encounters that'll make you throw your keyboard across the room. After my around 60 hour long journey I still don't know everything about how the combat works, but at least I managed to get by. I'll give Pillars of Eternity my recommendation and a score of 3/5.

Have owned the game and played it on and off for years.  Enjoyed it, loved the polish, scratched my itch for the genre, but always lost interest.  Just completed it for the first time.  Previously I'd always struggled to get involved in the story - seemed convoluted and disjointed.  But now after really taking the time to delve into it and see how each individual story (of companions or regions) interconnects naturally and masterfully, I can say this is one of the real strengths of the game.  The writing is phenomenal - like a well written novel.  

I also wish I'd understood more about the combat and class mechanics when dabbling previously.  I never bothered following specific min-max builds offered by others, always just played around with builds on the fly until I got past certain difficulty spikes (one of the few real frustrations I felt in playing - some of the spikes are HUGE, but once accepted the battles were unwinnable, I'd sometimes come back well later with more levels under my belt and be fine - if it's too tough, walk away for a while).  

But the main advice I would give myself if starting for the first time is make sure I really prepare 2 tanks and 4 DPS (or 3 and 3 maybe?  But 2 worked well).  Not enough to just have a fighter and a paladin or berserker and spec them whichever way I liked.    I found it far preferable to make sure any choice for those frontline characters was always defensive.  This is different to how I'd approach Baldur's Gate for instance.  I also frequently mixed up my NPCs - changing the party balance over and over, and loved the experimentation.  It's nice to be able to have an NPC auto level to match the party so you don't feel like you have to stick with the same ones through the whole game.  There's no real downside to switching party members and that made the game feel more expansive and opened up my options for fun enormously.

As mentioned before, I was initially baffled by the combat and class mechanics - thought of it all as inconsequential - many options didn't really seem to offer much "oomph" on the face of it.  Many spells seemed a bit bland.  But I was wrong.  The little things count in this game.   

Final comment is about the story again.  Best ending to any RPG I've played over the years - purely because of the impact my actions and choices made in the end (and during play too), and the consequences, many unimagined but very believable.  I won't be more specific than that, but for someone who often fears ending a game and prefers starting new characters when I'm only part way through "to keep the magic alive," just so the game will never lose its appeal to me (I think I've "finished" maybe 2% of all the RPGs I've ever started 100s of times over but enjoyed them anyway) I can honestly say I'm very glad I finished this one and that I left some side quests unfinished - as I now know I want to play through again to see what might have been (and there are some battles I still needed to win).  Very satisfying.  Before I start a new playthrough though, I'm going to finally start a game I've wanted to play for years but had to do something else first: Pillars of Eternity II here I come.

One of the most important games to an entire genre of RPGs. It revitalized people's interest in CRPGs like Baldur's Gate thankfully to the credit of Kickstarter. 

It's an incredibly narrative-dense game. The more you put in to learning about the world and the story, the more you are going to get back. The classes all feel very unique, and have very specific functions within a party. No class is necessarily "bad," and you can make any combination of them work. The best part of character creation is how the skill point allocation system works. You create characters more based on personality traits that have effects on how they behave in combat. For example, if you create a Warrior (Fighter) character and keep them at 10 Might (the default skill level) +0, but increase their Intelligence to 16 (+6), you will have created a Fighter character that is an intelligent individual but the Intelligence statistic will affect the duration of effects in combat, instead of a generic increase to "magic strength" or something of the like. This particular Fighter character may not hit very hard with only 10 Might, but when they knock someone down with a Shield Bash, the duration of the knockdown will be longer. Inside of conversations, they will have wit and charisma because they are "smart" from the +6 Intelligence.  Therefore, you can create any type of personality you want while not sacrificing a characters ability to perform inside of combat scenarios. 

+ I found the story to be incredibly engaging even though its an incredibly slow-burn.
+ Once you begin to understand how the combat works, the game becomes very addictive.
+ The artwork is gorgeous.
+ The music is gorgeous. 
+ The skill allocation system is extremely unique and unlike any other RPG I've played.
+ Character customization is deep and very engaging. I love building out various characters. Imagination can run wild. 
- The tutorials in this game leave much to be desired. Using the internet as a resource is almost a must to understand exactly how some combat scenarios play out. 
- You will have to read the in-game Journal to really understand things and nothing really points you in that direction.
- The story takes a while to get going, but I was engaged right from the beginning. I like slow paced narratives however. 
- The concepts of the narrative may have a niche audience. I however resonated with the main message of the game. It fucks.

I recommend this game to people who enjoy the CRPG experience. I do not recommend it to anyone else. If you're coming from Divinity or Dragon Age -- trust me; this ain't it, chief. I'll still (halfheartedly) recommend it because it wasn't bad for a fundraiser game, and I support the developers in general.

What annoyed me: 

1. It's not optimized. I have no idea why I'm getting bad frames in certain fights on a game from 2016 that looks as bad as this. 

2. I have an SSD and this game is still a loading screen simulator. Literally hundreds and hundreds of loading screens. Beware. It felt like I was minimized and looking at memes for half the game.

3. AI pathfinding and behavior. I hate it. My people don't go where I want them to, and sometimes don't do what I want them to.

4. Missing voice lines. Some of the voice work was pretty good, but it felt weirdly disjointed when someone is talking to me and they suddenly stop talking to me and it's just silent text....then they maybe start talking again. I understand the budget constraints and the desire to add more dialogue slides to give more information to the player, but it still bugs me.

5. I'm a hoarder and this game is bad for my addiction. I barely upgraded anything until near the end-game because so many great "best in slot" items come very late. I had tons of crafting materials and barely crafted anything. I'm not sure how to change the design around this personally, but I know better systems do exist because I haven't had this much of a challenge managing resources in a long time.

6. For those of us who aren't obsessive about each combat encounter to the point where we are familiar with all 100+ spells across all six characters in your party and what each mechanic does to help or hinder you, it can get rather repetitive. There were some things I just never used. I understand this is the nature of classic RPGs sometimes, so this will not bother most people familiar with the genre and I won't say this is a detriment to the experience. Better to have more choices during combat than not enough, I suppose.

7. Not allowing me to murder all the backer NPCs without impunity (this is a joke). My character was a benevolent/honest Paladin, but he had zero tolerance for these fourth wall breaking creatures that serve solely as a vehicle for some GoFundMe backer's shitty RP character backstory. I lead a holy crusade against them, and in my head canon I didn't send their souls back to the Wheel of reincarnation, but into an eternal eldritch hellscape that exists outside both time and space -- the likes of which would give David Cronenberg nightmares.

What I liked:

1. Story was half decent.

2. Voice work was pretty good. Matt Mercer is the MVP.

3. Lore is pretty fleshed out and interesting. Not many games have reincarnation as a central theme so I found it to be a fun thought experiment.

4. It's not a one-off and there's a sequel that actually adds some consequence to your choices in the first game here. I also like that Avowed is being made, so my understanding and appreciation for Eora will not be unrewarded beyond just a sequel. A Skyrim-esque experience may be what the Pillars franchise needs to have new life breathed into it.

Overall not a bad experience and I look forward to the next one. I hope it improves on most of these areas I mentioned, and if they do, I'll happily make note of it in my next review for that game.
